 ==Overview==
 In July, 1920 the Moscow congress of Ukrainian Bolsheviks rescinded the resolution, and the Ukrainian party was declared a part of the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union|Russian Communist Party (bolsheviks)]].
 
-On [[October 13]], 1952 the party officially was renamed into the '''Communist Party of Ukraine'''.
+On October 13, 1952 the party officially was renamed into the '''Communist Party of Ukraine'''.
 
-On [[August 26]], 1991 the Communist Party was outlawed in Ukraine. Different sectors reconstituted themselves in different parties. One group led by moderate members under [[Oleksandr Moroz]] formed the [[Socialist Party of Ukraine]] (SPU) out of most of the former members, another group re-created in 1993 the [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] in [[Donetsk]] under the leadership of [[Petro Symonenko]] when the ban was lifted. 
+On August 26, 1991 the Communist Party was outlawed in Ukraine. Different sectors reconstituted themselves in different parties. One group led by moderate members under [[Oleksandr Moroz]] formed the [[Socialist Party of Ukraine]] (SPU) out of most of the former members, another group re-created in 1993 the [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] in [[Donetsk]] under the leadership of [[Petro Symonenko]] when the ban was lifted. 
 
-On [[October 2]], 1942 was created the Illegal Central Committee of the Party consisting of 17 members. The committee was dissolved on [[June 29]], 1943. Among the members of the committee were such personalities as [[Sydir Kovpak]], [[Leonid Korniets]], Oleksiy Fedorov, and others.
+On October 2, 1942 was created the Illegal Central Committee of the Party consisting of 17 members. The committee was dissolved on June 29, 1943. Among the members of the committee were such personalities as [[Sydir Kovpak]], [[Leonid Korniets]], Oleksiy Fedorov, and others.
 
 ===Polit-Bureau===
-The party also had its own Polit-Bureau which was created on [[March 6]], 1919. On September 25, 1952 the committee was renamed into the Bureau of the Central Committee (CC) of CP(b)U, and in October the same year as the Bureau of the CC CPU. On October 10, 1952 it became the Presidium of the CC CPU. On June 26, 1966 again the bureau was finally left with its original name as the Polit-Bureau of the CC CPU.

On September 25, 1952 the committee was renamed into the Bureau of the Central Committee (CC) of CP(b)U, and in October the same year as the Bureau of the CC CPU. changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -3,11 +3,21 @@
 
 The '''Communist Party (Bolshevik) of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|Комуністична Партія (більшовиків) України}} ''Komunistychna Partiya (bilshovykiv) Ukrayiny'', КП(б)У, ''KP(b)U'') was formed at a conference in [[Taganrog]], in July<ref>[http://www.knowbysight.info/1_UKRA/04996.asp Guide to the history of the Communist Party and the Soviet Union 1898 - 1991]</ref> 1918. This party advocated strong ties with Russia, unlike the [[Ukrainian Communist Party]] which was established in 1920.
 
+==Overview==
 In July, 1920 the Moscow congress of Ukrainian Bolsheviks rescinded the resolution, and the Ukrainian party was declared a part of the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union|Russian Communist Party (bolsheviks)]].
 
 On [[October 13]], 1952 the party officially was renamed into the '''Communist Party of Ukraine'''.
 
 On [[August 26]], 1991 the Communist Party was outlawed in Ukraine. Different sectors reconstituted themselves in different parties. One group led by moderate members under [[Oleksandr Moroz]] formed the [[Socialist Party of Ukraine]] (SPU) out of most of the former members, another group re-created in 1993 the [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] in [[Donetsk]] under the leadership of [[Petro Symonenko]] when the ban was lifted. 
+
+On [[October 2]], 1942 was created the Illegal Central Committee of the Party consisting of 17 members. The committee was dissolved on [[June 29]], 1943. Among the members of the committee were such personalities as [[Sydir Kovpak]], [[Leonid Korniets]], Oleksiy Fedorov, and others.
+
+===Polit-Bureau===
+The party also had its own Polit-Bureau which was created on [[March 6]], 1919. On September 25, 1952 the committee was renamed into the Bureau of the Central Committee (CC) of CP(b)U, and in October the same year as the Bureau of the CC CPU. On October 10, 1952 it became the Presidium of the CC CPU. On June 26, 1966 again the bureau was finally left with its original name as the Polit-Bureau of the CC CPU. 
+
+At first it consisted of five members and later another one was added. The first Polit-Bureau included [[Andriy Bubnov]], [[Emmanuel Kviring]], [[Volodymyr Mescheriakov]], [[Heorhiy Pyatakov]], [[Khrystian Rakovsky]], and later [[Stanislav Kosior]].
+
+From March 23 until April 15, 1920 there was elected a Provisional Bureau which the next day was ratified by the Russian Communist Party (bolsheviks).
 
 ==Congresses==
 There were 28 Congresses with the last one consisting out of two stages. There also were three consolidated conferences of the party from 1926 to 1932. At the second stage of the last Congress there were 273 members in the Central Committee.

-The '''Communist Party (Bolshevik) of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|Комуністична Партія (більшовиків) України}} ''Komunistychna Partiya (bilshovykiv) Ukrayiny'', КП(б)У, ''KP(b)U'') was formed at a conference in [[Taganrog]], in July<ref>[http://www.knowbysight.info/1_UKRA/04996.asp Guide to the history of the Communist Party and the Soviet Union 1898 - 1991]</ref> 1918 out of the ''Ukrainian'' members of the [[RSDLP]] (bolsheviks) including former members of the [[Central Rada]]. +The '''Communist Party (Bolshevik) of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|Комуністична Партія (більшовиків) України}} ''Komunistychna Partiya (bilshovykiv) Ukrayiny'', КП(б)У, ''KP(b)U'') was formed at a conference in [[Moscow]], in July<ref>[http://www.knowbysight.info/1_UKRA/04996.asp Guide to the history of the Communist Party and the Soviet Union 1898 - 1991]</ref> 1918 out of the ''Ukrainian'' members of the [[RSDLP]] (bolsheviks) including former members of the [[Central Rada]]. This party advocated undivided union with Russia, unlike the [[Ukrainian Communist Party]] which was established in 1920.
 
 ==Overview==
 In July, 1920 the Moscow congress of Ukrainian Bolsheviks rescinded the resolution, and the Ukrainian party was declared a part of the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union|Russian Communist Party (bolsheviks)]].
 
 On October 13, 1952 the party officially was renamed into the '''Communist Party of Ukraine'''.
 
-On August 26, 1991 the Communist Party was outlawed in Ukraine. Different sectors reconstituted themselves in different parties. One group led by moderate members under [[Oleksandr Moroz]] formed the [[Socialist Party of Ukraine]] (SPU) out of most of the former members, another group re-created in 1993 the [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] in [[Donetsk]] under the leadership of [[Petro Symonenko]] when the ban was lifted. 
+On August 26, 1991 the Communist Party was outlawed in Ukraine. Different sectors reconstituted themselves in different parties. One group led by moderate members under [[Oleksandr Moroz]] formed the [[Socialist Party of Ukraine]] (SPU) out of most of the former members, another group re-created in 1993 the [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] in [[Donetsk]] under the leadership of [[Petro Symonenko]] when the ban was lifted, the rest members either changed their political "compass" or created their own parties of the left orientation such as the Vitrenko bloc, Social-Democratic (United) party, and others. 
 
-On October 2, 1942 was created the Illegal Central Committee of the Party consisting of 17 members. The committee was dissolved on June 29, 1943. Among the members of the committee were such personalities as [[Sydir Kovpak]], [[Leonid Korniets]], Oleksiy Fedorov, and others.
+During the [[World War]] II an interesting event took place on October 2, 1942 when there was created the Illegal Central Committee of the Party consisting of 17 members. The committee was dissolved on June 29, 1943. Among the members of the committee were such personalities as [[Sydir Kovpak]], [[Leonid Korniets]], Oleksiy Fedorov, and others.
 
 ===Polit-Bureau===
 The party also had its own Polit-Bureau which was created on March 6, 1919. On September 25, 1952 the committee was renamed into the Bureau of the Central Committee (CC) of CP(b)U, and in October the same year as the Bureau of the CC CPU. On October 10, 1952 it became the Presidium of the CC CPU. On June 26, 1966 again the bureau was finally left with its original name as the Polit-Bureau of the CC CPU.

@@ -45,6 +45,8 @@
 This also took place in Moscow.  Later was introduced the Revision Committee out three members and another two candidates.
 
 ===Later congresses===
+===Later congresses===
+===Later congresses===
 From 1919 to 1934 all meetings were conducted in [[Kharkov]].{{cn|date=January 2011}}
 
 There were three major Committees and several Bureaus. Each committee had members and candidates to members each with certain degree of obligations. The members and candidates to the committees were elected at the Party Congress. The number of members varied from one gathering to the next usually in ascending sequence. During the [[Great Purge]] the numbers remarkably declined as well as one of the committees, Central Control Committee, was disbanded. The first members were elected in 1918, 15 members of the Central Committee, six candidates as well as three members and two candidates of the Revision Committee. In 1920 the Central Control Committee was formed and by 1934 the Party accounted for some 191 members and 45 candidates in all committees. In 1937 there were only 71 members and 40 candidates in two committees. By 1990 the number of members grew just over 300 members.

During the [[Great Purge]] the numbers remarkably declined as well as one of the committees, Central Control Committee, was disbanded. The first members were elected in 1918, 15 members of the Central Committee, six candidates as well as three members and two candidates of the Revision Committee. In 1920 the Central Control Committee was formed and by 1934 the Party accounted for some 191 members and 45 candidates in all committees. In 1937 there were only 71 members and 40 candidates in two committees. By 1990 the number of members grew just over 300 members.

+The '''Communist Party (Bolshevik) of Ukraine''' ({{lang-uk|Комуністична Партія (більшовиків) України}} ''Komunistychna Partiya (bilshovykiv) Ukrayiny'', КП(б)У, ''KP(b)U''; {{lang-ru|Коммунистическая партия (большевиков) Украины}}) was a sub-branch of the Bolshevik faction of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party (RSDLP)that in March 1918 renamed itself the Russian Communist Party (RCP). Central leaders in Moscow agreed in March 1918 to requests from Ukrainian party members to form a single "Ukrainian" branch encompassing the 8 Ukrainian provinces of the former Russian empire. This sub-branch was formally proclaimed  at a conference in [[Moscow]], in July.<ref>[http://www.knowbysight.info/1_UKRA/04996.asp Guide to the history of the Communist Party and the Soviet Union 1898 - 1991]</ref>  This party was composed overwhelmingly of Russians in Ukraine who did  not represent Ukrainians as "an oppressed peoples" and  did not envisage an independent soviereign Ukrainian socialist national state. Their party was totally subordinated to  and formally had a status of a oblast (provincial) committee within the RCP. A minority within the party's Ukrainian branch represented by men such as Mykola Skrypnyk did call for an independent Ukrainian party and a socialist Ukraine free of Russian domination but was overruled both by the RUssian majority and Lenin. Dissidents who refused to accept Russian domination called for the creation of an independent Ukrainian Communist Party that would lead a national-liberation struggle as a member of the Third International.
 
 ==Overview==
 On October 13, 1952 the party officially was renamed into the '''Communist Party of Ukraine'''.

 ===Third Congress, March 1919===
 This congress took place in Kharkov. A new central committee with a majority of [[Left communism|Left Communists]] was elected. This prompted the [[8th Congress of the Russian Communist Party (Bolsheviks)|Eight Congress]] of the [[Russian Communist Party (Bolsheviks)|Russian Communist Party]] to pass the following motion: ""It is necessary to have a unified communist party with a unified central committee ... All decisions of the RCP and its leading organs are absolutely binding for all parts of the party, independent of their national composition. The central committees of the Ukrainian, Lettish and Lithuanian communists are conferred the rights of regional committees of the party; they are to be unreservedly subordinate to the central committee of the RCP."<ref>[http://www.whatnextjournal.co.uk/pages/theory/Hollis.html The Self-Determination of Nations: The Theory and Practice (Ukraine and Georgia)] by Annette Franz and Dave Hollis accessed 24 January 2011</ref>

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -91,6 +91,9 @@
 
 There were three major Committees and several Bureaus. Each committee had members and candidates to members each with certain degree of obligations. The members and candidates to the committees were elected at the Party Congress. The number of members varied from one gathering to the next usually in ascending sequence. During the [[Great Purge]] the numbers remarkably declined as well as one of the committees, Central Control Committee, was disbanded. The first members were elected in 1918, 15 members of the Central Committee, six candidates as well as three members and two candidates of the Revision Committee. In 1920 the Central Control Committee was formed and by 1934 the Party accounted for some 191 members and 45 candidates in all committees. In 1937 there were only 71 members and 40 candidates in two committees. By 1990 the number of members grew just over 300 members.
 
+==See also==
+* [[List of secretaries of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of Ukraine]]
+
 ==References==
 {{reflist}}
 J. Borys, The Sovietization of Ukraine 1917-1923 : the Communist doctrine and practice of national self-determination (1980)

Central leaders in Moscow agreed in March 1918 to requests from Ukrainian party members to form a single "Ukrainian" branch encompassing the 8 Ukrainian provinces of the former Russian empire. This party was composed overwhelmingly of Russians in Ukraine who did  not represent Ukrainians as "an oppressed peoples" and  did not envisage an independent soviereign Ukrainian socialist national state. Dissidents who refused to accept Russian domination called for the creation of an independent Ukrainian Communist Party that would lead a national-liberatoin struggle as a member of the Third International. 
 
 ==Overview==
 On October 13, 1952 the party officially was renamed into the '''Communist Party of Ukraine'''.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -6,6 +6,8 @@
 The CPSU originally began as the Bolshevik faction of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party (RSDLP), renaming itself the Russian Communist Party (RCP) in March 1918. Central leaders in Moscow agreed in March 1918 to requests from party members in Ukraine to form a single "Ukrainian" branch encompassing the 8 Ukrainian provinces of the former Russian empire. This sub-branch was formally proclaimed at a conference in [[Moscow]], in July.<ref>[http://www.knowbysight.info/1_UKRA/04996.asp Guide to the history of the Communist Party and the Soviet Union 1898 - 1991]</ref> This party was composed overwhelmingly of Russians in Ukraine who did not believe that Ukrainians were an oppressed people and did not envisage an independent sovereign Ukrainian socialist national state. Their party was subordinated to the RCP (later renamed the CPSU), and formally had a status of a oblast (provincial) committee within the RCP. A minority within the party's Ukrainian branch represented by men such as Mykola Skrypnyk did call for an independent Ukrainian party and a socialist Ukraine free of Russian domination, but was overruled both by the Russian majority and Lenin. Dissidents who refused to accept Russian domination called for the creation of an independent Ukrainian Communist Party that would lead a national-liberation struggle as a member of the Third International.
 
 ==Overview==
+The Communist Party of Ukraine was created in July of 1918 in Moscow. Most of its constituent members were former members of the Russian Bolsheviks who in 1917 pronounced themselves ''Social-Democracy of Ukraine'' and with the help of the Antonov-Ovseyenko expeditionary forces of Petrograd and Moscow Red Guards instigated a civil war in Ukraine by routing a local Red Guards. After the signing of the [[Treaty of Brest-Litovsk]] the Bolsheviks faction ''Social-Democracy of Ukraine'' was forced to dissolve as all Bolsheviks were forced out of Ukraine.
+
 On October 13, 1952 the party officially was renamed into the '''Communist Party of Ukraine'''.
 
 On August 26, 1991 the Communist Party was outlawed in Ukraine. Different sectors reconstituted themselves in different parties. One group led by moderate members under [[Oleksandr Moroz]] formed the [[Socialist Party of Ukraine]] (SPU) out of most of the former members, another group re-created in 1993 the [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] in [[Donetsk]] under the leadership of [[Petro Symonenko]] when the ban was lifted, the rest members either changed their political "compass" or created their own parties of the left orientation such as the Vitrenko bloc, Social-Democratic (United) party, and others.
llm_output:
The change made in the revision is the addition of new content regarding the history of the Communist Party of Ukraine, specifically detailing its creation, the involvement of Russian Bolsheviks, and subsequent developments in the party's history.

Weaponised: Not Weaponised. The added content provides historical context without employing weaponisation terms or narratives that could be seen as politically charged or biased.

@@ -11,7 +11,7 @@
 On August 26, 1991 the Communist Party was outlawed in Ukraine. Different sectors reconstituted themselves in different parties. One group led by moderate members under [[Oleksandr Moroz]] formed the [[Socialist Party of Ukraine]] (SPU) out of most of the former members, another group re-created in 1993 the [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] in [[Donetsk]] under the leadership of [[Petro Symonenko]] when the ban was lifted, the rest members either changed their political "compass" or created their own parties of the left orientation such as the Vitrenko bloc, Social-Democratic (United) party, and others.
 
 ==Central Committees==
-During [[World War II]] an interesting event took place on October 2, 1942 when there was created the Illegal Central Committee of the Party consisting of 17 members. The committee was dissolved on June 29, 1943. Among the members of the committee were such personalities as [[Sydir Kovpak]], [[Leonid Korniets]], Oleksiy Fedorov, and others.
+During [[World War II]] an interesting event took place on October 2, 1942 when there was created the Illegal Central Committee of the Party consisting of 17 members. The committee was dissolved on June 29, 1943. Among the members of the committee were such personalities as [[Sydir Kovpak]], [[Leonid Korniets]], Oleksiy Fedorov, and others. Initial composition of the committee was elected at the 1st party Congress on July 12, 1918 and consisted of the following people: [[Ivan Amosov]], [[Andrei Bubnov]], [[Afanasiy Butsenko]], [[Shulim Gruzman]], [[Vladimir Zatonsky]], [[Lavrentiy Kartvelishvili]], [[Emmanuil Kviring]], [[Stanislav Kocior]], [[Isaak Kreisberg]], [[Yuriy Lutovinov]], [[Yuriy Pyatakov]], [[Rafail Farbman]], [[Pinkhus Rovner]], [[Leonid Tarsky]] (Sokolovsky), [[Isaak Shvarts]]. Beside full members there also were candidate to the committee. The initial composition included [[Yan Hamarnik]] (Yakov Pudikovich), [[Dmitriy Lebed]], [[Mikhail Mayorov]] (Meyer Biberman), [[Mykola Skrypnyk]], [[Petro Slynko]], [[Yakov Yakovlev]] (Epshtein). On September 9, 1918 Mayorov and Slynko replaced Kertvelishvili and Farbman as full members, while the last two lost their membership.
 
 ===Politburo===
 The party  had its own Politburo  created on March 6, 1919. On September 25, 1952 the committee was renamed into the Bureau of the Central Committee (CC) of CP(b)U, and in October the same year as the Bureau of the CC CPU. On October 10, 1952 it became the Presidium of the CC CPU. On June 26, 1966 again the bureau was finally left with its original name as the Politburo of the CC CPU.
llm_output:
The change made in this revision is the addition of detailed information regarding the initial composition of the Illegal Central Committee of the Party, including the names of its members and their roles. 

Weaponised: Not Weaponised. The added content provides historical context without employing language that could be interpreted as weaponising cultural heritage or promoting a specific narrative.

@@ -118,7 +118,7 @@
 The [[Borotbists]] were forced to dissolve themselves and their erstwile members were permitted to join the CP(b)U.<ref>[http://www.marxists.org/archive/lenin/works/1920/feb/06b.htm Draft Resolution on the Ukrainian Borotbist Party (Notes)] accessed 24 January 2011</ref> Vasyl Ellan-Blakytny and Shumsky drawn from the Borotbist leadership were elected to the Committee and the Borotbist Central Committee passed a resolution dissolving the Borotbist party and its central committee. All members were instructed to apply for CP(B)U membership. Nearly 4,000 out of approximately 5,000 Borotbists  were admitted to the CP(B)U.<ref>[http://www.day.kiev.ua/258303/ A great experiment`; Towards the history of national communism in Ukraine] By James Mace, accessed 24 January 2011</ref>
 
 ===Later congresses===
-From 1919 to 1934 all meetings were conducted in [[Kharkov]].{{citation needed|date=January 2011}}
+From 1919 to 1934 all meetings were conducted in [[Kharkiv]], capital of the [[Ukrainian SSR]].
 
 There were three major Committees and several Bureaus. Each committee had members and candidates to members each with certain degree of obligations. The members and candidates to the committees were elected at the Party Congress. The number of members varied from one gathering to the next usually in ascending sequence. During the [[Great Purge]] the numbers remarkably declined as well as one of the committees, Central Control Committee, was disbanded. The first members were elected in 1918, 15 members of the Central Committee, six candidates as well as three members and two candidates of the Revision Committee. In 1920 the Central Control Committee was formed and by 1934 the Party accounted for some 191 members and 45 candidates in all committees. In 1937 there were only 71 members and 40 candidates in two committees. By 1990 the number of members grew just over 300 members.

@@ -28,7 +28,7 @@
 
 On August 26, 1991 the Communist Party was outlawed in Ukraine. Different sectors reconstituted themselves in different parties. One group led by moderate members under [[Oleksandr Moroz]] formed the [[Socialist Party of Ukraine]] (SPU) out of most of the former members, another group re-created in 1993 the [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] in [[Donetsk]] under the leadership of [[Petro Symonenko]] when the ban was lifted, the rest members either changed their political "compass" or created their own parties of the left orientation such as the Vitrenko bloc, Social-Democratic (United) party, and others.
 
-==Central Committees==
+===Central Committees===
 Initial composition of the committee was elected at the 1st party Congress on July 12, 1918 and consisted of the following people: [[Ivan Amosov]], [[Andrei Bubnov]], [[Afanasiy Butsenko]], [[Shulim Gruzman]], [[Vladimir Zatonsky]], [[Lavrentiy Kartvelishvili]], [[Emmanuil Kviring]], [[Stanislav Kosior]], [[Isaak Kreisberg]], [[Yuriy Lutovinov]], [[Yuriy Pyatakov]], [[Rafail Farbman]], [[Pinkhus Rovner]], [[Leonid Tarsky]] (Sokolovsky), [[Isaak Shvarts]]. Beside full members there also were candidate to the committee. The initial composition included [[Yan Hamarnik]] (Yakov Pudikovich), [[Dmitriy Lebed]], [[Mikhail Mayorov]] (Meyer Biberman), [[Mykola Skrypnyk]], [[Petro Slynko]], [[Yakov Yakovlev]] (Epshtein). On September 9, 1918 Mayorov and Slynko replaced Kertvelishvili and Farbman as full members, while the last two lost their membership.
 
 During [[World War II]] on October 2, 1942 there was created the Illegal Central Committee of the Party consisting of 17 members. The committee was dissolved on June 29, 1943. Among the members of the committee were such personalities as [[Sydir Kovpak]], [[Leonid Korniets]], Oleksiy Fedorov, and others.

@@ -22,6 +22,7 @@
 The '''Communist Party of Ukraine'''  ({{lang-uk|Комуністична Партія України}} ''Komunistychna Partiya Ukrayiny'', КПУ, ''KPU''; {{lang-ru|Коммунистическая партия (большевиков) Украины}}), known as the '''Communist Party (Bolshevik) of Ukraine''' until 1952, was the Ukrainian branch of the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] (CPSU).
 
 ==Overview==
+{{also|Ukrainian People's Republic of Soviets}}
 The Communist Party (Bolsheviks) of Ukraine was created in July of 1918 in Moscow. Most of its constituent members were former members of the Russian Bolsheviks who in 1917 pronounced themselves ''Social-Democracy of Ukraine'' and with the help of the Antonov-Ovseyenko expeditionary forces of Petrograd and Moscow Red Guards instigated a civil war in Ukraine by routing a local Red Guards. After the signing of the [[Treaty of Brest-Litovsk]] the Bolsheviks faction ''Social-Democracy of Ukraine'' was forced to dissolve as all Bolsheviks were forced out of Ukraine.
 
 On October 13, 1952 the party officially was renamed into the '''Communist Party of Ukraine'''.

@@ -20,8 +20,6 @@
 {{Refimprove|date=July 2007}}
 
 The '''Communist Party of Ukraine'''  ({{lang-uk|Комуністична Партія України}} ''Komunistychna Partiya Ukrayiny'', КПУ, ''KPU''; {{lang-ru|Коммунистическая партия (большевиков) Украины}}), known as the '''Communist Party (Bolshevik) of Ukraine''' until 1952, was the Ukrainian branch of the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] (CPSU).
-
-The CPSU originally began as the Bolshevik faction of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party (RSDLP), renaming itself the Russian Communist Party (RCP) in March 1918. Central leaders in Moscow agreed in March 1918 to requests from party members in Ukraine to form a single "Ukrainian" branch encompassing the 8 Ukrainian provinces of the former Russian empire. This sub-branch was formally proclaimed at a conference in [[Moscow]], in July.<ref>[http://www.knowbysight.info/1_UKRA/04996.asp Guide to the history of the Communist Party and the Soviet Union 1898 - 1991]</ref> This party was composed overwhelmingly of Russians in Ukraine who did not believe that Ukrainians were an oppressed people and did not envisage an independent sovereign Ukrainian socialist national state. Their party was subordinated to the RCP (later renamed the CPSU), and formally had a status of a oblast (provincial) committee within the RCP. A minority within the party's Ukrainian branch represented by men such as Mykola Skrypnyk did call for an independent Ukrainian party and a socialist Ukraine free of Russian domination, but was overruled both by the Russian majority and Lenin. Dissidents who refused to accept Russian domination called for the creation of an independent Ukrainian Communist Party that would lead a national-liberation struggle as a member of the Third International.
 
 ==Overview==
 The Communist Party (Bolsheviks) of Ukraine was created in July of 1918 in Moscow. Most of its constituent members were former members of the Russian Bolsheviks who in 1917 pronounced themselves ''Social-Democracy of Ukraine'' and with the help of the Antonov-Ovseyenko expeditionary forces of Petrograd and Moscow Red Guards instigated a civil war in Ukraine by routing a local Red Guards. After the signing of the [[Treaty of Brest-Litovsk]] the Bolsheviks faction ''Social-Democracy of Ukraine'' was forced to dissolve as all Bolsheviks were forced out of Ukraine.

The position also was changing names between being called the First Secretary or the General Secretary, depending on a political atmosphere in the Soviet Union. The position was not officially of the head of state, but certainly was very influential, especially within the republic. @@ -23,7 +23,7 @@
 
 ==Overview==
 {{also|Ukrainian People's Republic of Soviets|All-Ukrainian Congress of Soviets}}
-The Communist Party (Bolsheviks) of Ukraine was created in July of 1918 in Moscow. Most of its constituent members were former members of the Russian Bolsheviks who in 1917 pronounced themselves ''Social-Democracy of Ukraine'' and with the help of the Antonov-Ovseyenko expeditionary forces of Petrograd and Moscow Red Guards instigated a civil war in Ukraine by routing a local Red Guards. After the signing of the [[Treaty of Brest-Litovsk]] the Bolsheviks faction ''Social-Democracy of Ukraine'' was forced to dissolve as all Bolsheviks were forced out of Ukraine.
+The Communist Party (Bolsheviks) of Ukraine was created in July of 1918 in Moscow. Most of its constituent members were former members of the Russian [[Bolshevik]]s who in 1917 pronounced themselves ''Social-Democracy of Ukraine'' and with the help of the Antonov-Ovseyenko expeditionary forces of Petrograd and Moscow Red Guards instigated a civil war in Ukraine by routing a local Red Guards. After the signing of the [[Treaty of Brest-Litovsk]] the Bolsheviks faction ''Social-Democracy of Ukraine'' was forced to dissolve as all Bolsheviks were forced out of Ukraine.
 
 On October 13, 1952 the party officially was renamed into the '''Communist Party of Ukraine'''.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -28,7 +28,7 @@
 
 On October 13, 1952 the party officially was renamed into the '''Communist Party of Ukraine'''.
 
-On August 26, 1991 the Communist Party was outlawed in Ukraine. Different sectors reconstituted themselves in different parties. One group led by moderate members under [[Oleksandr Moroz]] formed the [[Socialist Party of Ukraine]] (SPU) out of most of the former members, another group re-created in 1993 the [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] in [[Donetsk]] under the leadership of [[Petro Symonenko]] when the ban was lifted, the remaining members either changed their political "compass" or created their own parties of the left orientation such as the Vitrenko bloc, Social-Democratic (United) party, and others.
+On August 26, 1991 the Communist Party was outlawed in Ukraine. Different sectors reconstituted themselves in different parties. One group led by moderate members under [[Oleksandr Moroz]] formed the [[Socialist Party of Ukraine]] (SPU) out of most of the former members, another group re-created in 1993 the [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] in [[Donetsk]] under the leadership of [[Petro Symonenko]] when the ban was lifted, the remaining members either changed political direction, or created their own parties of the left orientation such as the Vitrenko bloc, Social-Democratic (United) party, and others.
 
 ===Central Committees===
 Initial composition of the committee was elected at the 1st party Congress on July 12, 1918 and consisted of the following people: [[Ivan Amosov]], [[Andrei Bubnov]], [[Afanasiy Butsenko]], [[Shulim Gruzman]], [[Vladimir Zatonsky]], [[Lavrentiy Kartvelishvili]], [[Emmanuil Kviring]], [[Stanislav Kosior]], [[Isaak Kreisberg]], [[Yuriy Lutovinov]], [[Yuriy Pyatakov]], [[Rafail Farbman]], [[Pinkhus Rovner]], [[Leonid Tarsky]] (Sokolovsky), [[Isaak Shvarts]]. Beside full members there also were candidate to the committee. The initial composition included [[Yan Hamarnik]] (Yakov Pudikovich), [[Dmitriy Lebed]], [[Mikhail Mayorov]] (Meyer Biberman), [[Mykola Skrypnyk]], [[Petro Slynko]], [[Yakov Yakovlev]] (Epshtein). On September 9, 1918 Mayorov and Slynko replaced Kertvelishvili and Farbman as full members, while the last two lost their membership.
llm_output:
Rephrased a phrase for clarity: "changed their political 'compass'" to "changed political direction".

Not Weaponised. The change is a minor rephrasing for clarity and does not introduce any weaponised language or narratives related to cultural heritage.

+++ 
@@ -23,8 +23,8 @@
 The '''Communist Party of Ukraine'''  ({{lang-uk|Комуністична Партія України}} ''Komunistychna Partiya Ukrayiny'', КПУ, ''KPU''; {{lang-ru|Коммунистическая партия (большевиков) Украины}}), known as the '''Communist Party (Bolshevik) of Ukraine''' until 1952, was the Ukrainian branch of the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] (CPSU).
 
 ==Overview==
-{{also|Ukrainian People's Republic of Soviets|All-Ukrainian Congress of Soviets}}
-The Communist Party (Bolsheviks) of Ukraine was created in July of 1918 in Moscow. Most of its constituent members were former members of the Russian [[Bolshevik]]s who in 1917 pronounced themselves ''Social-Democracy of Ukraine'' and with the help of the Antonov-Ovseyenko expeditionary forces of Petrograd and Moscow Red Guards instigated a civil war in Ukraine by routing a local Red Guards. After the signing of the [[Treaty of Brest-Litovsk]] the Bolsheviks faction ''Social-Democracy of Ukraine'' was forced to dissolve as all Bolsheviks were forced out of Ukraine.
+{{see also|Ukrainian People's Republic of Soviets|All-Ukrainian Congress of Soviets}}
+The Communist Party (Bolsheviks) of Ukraine was created in July 1918 in Moscow. Most of its constituent members were former members of the Russian [[Bolshevik]]s who in 1917 pronounced themselves ''Social-Democracy of Ukraine'' and with the help of the Antonov-Ovseyenko expeditionary forces of Petrograd and Moscow Red Guards instigated a civil war in Ukraine by routing a local Red Guards. After the signing of the [[Treaty of Brest-Litovsk]] the Bolsheviks faction ''Social-Democracy of Ukraine'' was forced to dissolve as all Bolsheviks were forced out of Ukraine.
 
 On October 13, 1952 the party officially was renamed into the '''Communist Party of Ukraine'''.
 
@@ -33,12 +33,12 @@
 ===Central Committees===
 Initial composition of the committee was elected at the 1st party Congress on July 12, 1918 and consisted of the following people: [[Ivan Amosov]], [[Andrei Bubnov]], [[Afanasiy Butsenko]], [[Shulim Gruzman]], [[Vladimir Zatonsky]], [[Lavrentiy Kartvelishvili]], [[Emmanuil Kviring]], [[Stanislav Kosior]], [[Isaak Kreisberg]], [[Yuriy Lutovinov]], [[Yuriy Pyatakov]], [[Rafail Farbman]], [[Pinkhus Rovner]], [[Leonid Tarsky]] (Sokolovsky), [[Isaak Shvarts]]. Beside full members there also were candidate to the committee. The initial composition included [[Yan Hamarnik]] (Yakov Pudikovich), [[Dmitriy Lebed]], [[Mikhail Mayorov]] (Meyer Biberman), [[Mykola Skrypnyk]], [[Petro Slynko]], [[Yakov Yakovlev]] (Epshtein). On September 9, 1918 Mayorov and Slynko replaced Kertvelishvili and Farbman as full members, while the last two lost their membership.
 
-During [[World War II]] on October 2, 1942 there was created the Illegal Central Committee of the Party consisting of 17 members. The committee was dissolved on June 29, 1943. Among the members of the committee were such personalities as [[Sydir Kovpak]], [[Leonid Korniets]], Oleksiy Fedorov, and others. 
+During [[World War II]] on October 2, 1942 there was created the Illegal Central Committee of the Party consisting of 17 members. The committee was dissolved on June 29, 1943. Among the members of the committee were such personalities as [[Sydir Kovpak]], [[Leonid Korniets]], Oleksiy Fedorov, and others.
 
 ===Politburo===
-The party  had its own Politburo  created on March 6, 1919. On September 25, 1952 the committee was renamed into the Bureau of the Central Committee (CC) of CP(b)U, and in October the same year as the Bureau of the CC CPU. On October 10, 1952 it became the Presidium of the CC CPU. On June 26, 1966 again the bureau was finally left with its original name as the Politburo of the CC CPU. 
-
-At first it consisted of five members and later another one was added. The first Politburo included [[Andriy Bubnov]], [[Emanuel Kviring]], [[Volodymyr Mescheriakov]], [[Heorhiy Pyatakov]], [[Christian Rakovsky]], and later [[Stanislav Kosior]], all centrists. 
+The party  had its own Politburo  created on March 6, 1919. On September 25, 1952 the committee was renamed into the Bureau of the Central Committee (CC) of CP(b)U, and in October the same year as the Bureau of the CC CPU. On October 10, 1952 it became the Presidium of the CC CPU. On June 26, 1966 again the bureau was finally left with its original name as the Politburo of the CC CPU.
+
+At first it consisted of five members and later another one was added. The first Politburo included [[Andriy Bubnov]], [[Emanuel Kviring]], [[Volodymyr Mescheriakov]], [[Heorhiy Pyatakov]], [[Christian Rakovsky]], and later [[Stanislav Kosior]], all centrists.
 
 From March 23 until April 15, 1920 there was elected a Provisional Bureau which the next day was ratified by the Russian Communist Party (Bolsheviks).

 On October 13, 1952 the party officially was renamed into the '''Communist Party of Ukraine'''.
 
-On August 26, 1991 the Communist Party was outlawed in Ukraine. Different sectors reconstituted themselves in different parties. One group led by moderate members under [[Oleksandr Moroz]] formed the [[Socialist Party of Ukraine]] (SPU) out of most of the former members, another group re-created in 1993 the [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] in [[Donetsk]] under the leadership of [[Petro Symonenko]] when the ban was lifted, the remaining members either changed political direction, or created their own parties of the left orientation such as the Vitrenko bloc, Social-Democratic (United) party, and others.
+On August 26, 1991 the Communist Party was outlawed in Ukraine. Different sectors reconstituted themselves in different parties. One group led by moderate members under [[Oleksandr Moroz]] formed the [[Socialist Party of Ukraine]] (SPU) out of most of the former members, a group of agrarian led by [[Serhiy Dovhan]] and [[Oleksandr Tkachenko (politician)|Oleksandr Tkachenko]] formed the [[Peasant Party of Ukraine]] (SelPU), another group the [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] was re-created in 1993 in [[Donetsk]] under the leadership of [[Petro Symonenko]] when the ban was lifted, the remaining members either changed political direction, or created their own parties of the left orientation such as the Vitrenko bloc, Social-Democratic (United) party, and others.
 
 ===Central Committees===
 Initial composition of the committee was elected at the 1st party Congress on July 12, 1918 and consisted of the following people: [[Ivan Amosov]], [[Andrei Bubnov]], [[Afanasiy Butsenko]], [[Shulim Gruzman]], [[Vladimir Zatonsky]], [[Lavrentiy Kartvelishvili]], [[Emmanuil Kviring]], [[Stanislav Kosior]], [[Isaak Kreisberg]], [[Yuriy Lutovinov]], [[Yuriy Pyatakov]], [[Rafail Farbman]], [[Pinkhus Rovner]], [[Leonid Tarsky]] (Sokolovsky), [[Isaak Shvarts]]. Beside full members there also were candidate to the committee. The initial composition included [[Yan Hamarnik]] (Yakov Pudikovich), [[Dmitriy Lebed]], [[Mikhail Mayorov]] (Meyer Biberman), [[Mykola Skrypnyk]], [[Petro Slynko]], [[Yakov Yakovlev]] (Epshtein). On September 9, 1918 Mayorov and Slynko replaced Kertvelishvili and Farbman as full members, while the last two lost their membership.

+On August 26, 1991 the Communist Party was outlawed in Ukraine. Different sectors reconstituted themselves in different parties. One group led by moderate members under [[Oleksandr Moroz]] formed the [[Socialist Party of Ukraine]] (SPU) out of most of the former members, another group re-created in 1993 the [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] in [[Donetsk]] under the leadership of [[Petro Symonenko]] when the ban was lifted, the remaining members either changed their political "compass" or created their own parties of the left orientation such as the Vitrenko bloc, Social-Democratic (United) party, and others.
 
 ===Central Committees===
 Initial composition of the committee was elected at the 1st party Congress on July 12, 1918 and consisted of the following people: [[Ivan Amosov]], [[Andrei Bubnov]], [[Afanasiy Butsenko]], [[Shulim Gruzman]], [[Vladimir Zatonsky]], [[Lavrentiy Kartvelishvili]], [[Emmanuil Kviring]], [[Stanislav Kosior]], [[Isaak Kreisberg]], [[Yuriy Lutovinov]], [[Yuriy Pyatakov]], [[Rafail Farbman]], [[Pinkhus Rovner]], [[Leonid Tarsky]] (Sokolovsky), [[Isaak Shvarts]]. Beside full members there also were candidate to the committee. The initial composition included [[Yan Hamarnik]] (Yakov Pudikovich), [[Dmitriy Lebed]], [[Mikhail Mayorov]] (Meyer Biberman), [[Mykola Skrypnyk]], [[Petro Slynko]], [[Yakov Yakovlev]] (Epshtein). On September 9, 1918 Mayorov and Slynko replaced Kertvelishvili and Farbman as full members, while the last two lost their membership.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -31,11 +31,11 @@
 
 ==Overview==
 {{see also|Ukrainian People's Republic of Soviets|All-Ukrainian Congress of Soviets}}
-The Communist Party (Bolsheviks) of Ukraine was created in July 1918 in Moscow. Most of its constituent members were former members of the Russian [[Bolshevik]]s who in 1917 pronounced themselves ''Social-Democracy of Ukraine'' and with the help of the Antonov-Ovseyenko expeditionary forces of Petrograd and Moscow Red Guards instigated a civil war in Ukraine by routing a local Red Guards. After the signing of the [[Treaty of Brest-Litovsk]] the Bolsheviks faction ''Social-Democracy of Ukraine'' was forced to dissolve as all Bolsheviks were forced out of Ukraine.
-
-On October 13, 1952 the party officially was renamed into the '''Communist Party of Ukraine'''.
-
-On August 26, 1991 the Communist Party was outlawed in Ukraine. Different sectors reconstituted themselves in different parties. One group led by moderate members under [[Oleksandr Moroz]] formed the [[Socialist Party of Ukraine]] (SPU) out of most of the former members, a group of agrarians led by [[Serhiy Dovhan]] and [[Oleksandr Tkachenko (politician)|Oleksandr Tkachenko]] formed the [[Peasant Party of Ukraine]] (SelPU), another group the [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] was re-created in 1993 in [[Donetsk]] under the leadership of [[Petro Symonenko]] when the ban was lifted, the remaining members either changed political direction, or created their own parties of the left orientation such as the Vitrenko bloc, Social-Democratic (United) party, and others.
+The Communist Party (Bolsheviks) of Ukraine was created in July 1918 in Moscow. Most of its constituent members were former members of the Russian [[Bolshevik]]s who in 1917 pronounced themselves "Social-Democracy of Ukraine" and with the help of the Antonov-Ovseyenko expeditionary forces of Petrograd and Moscow Red Guards instigated a civil war in Ukraine by routing local Red Guards. After the signing of the [[Treaty of Brest-Litovsk]] the Bolshevik faction Social-Democracy of Ukraine was forced to dissolve as all Bolsheviks were forced out of Ukraine.
+
+On October 13, 1952 the party officially was renamed as the '''Communist Party of Ukraine'''.
+
+On August 26, 1991 the Communist Party was outlawed in Ukraine. Different sectors reconstituted themselves in different parties. One group led by moderate members under [[Oleksandr Moroz]] formed the [[Socialist Party of Ukraine]] (SPU) out of most of the former members, a group of agrarians led by [[Serhiy Dovhan]] and [[Oleksandr Tkachenko (politician)|Oleksandr Tkachenko]] formed the [[Peasant Party of Ukraine]] (SelPU), and another group, the [[Communist Party of Ukraine]], was re-created in 1993 in [[Donetsk]] under the leadership of [[Petro Symonenko]] when the ban was lifted. The remaining members either changed political direction or created their own left-wing parties such as the Vitrenko bloc, Social-Democratic (United) party, and others.
 
 ===Central Committees===
 Initial composition of the committee was elected at the 1st party Congress on July 12, 1918 and consisted of the following people: [[Ivan Amosov]], [[Andrei Bubnov]], [[Afanasiy Butsenko]], [[Shulim Gruzman]], [[Vladimir Zatonsky]], [[Lavrentiy Kartvelishvili]], [[Emmanuil Kviring]], [[Stanislav Kosior]], [[Isaak Kreisberg]], [[Yuriy Lutovinov]], [[Yuriy Pyatakov]], [[Rafail Farbman]], [[Pinkhus Rovner]], [[Leonid Tarsky]] (Sokolovsky), [[Isaak Shvarts]]. Beside full members there also were candidate to the committee. The initial composition included [[Yan Hamarnik]] (Yakov Pudikovich), [[Dmitriy Lebed]], [[Mikhail Mayorov]] (Meyer Biberman), [[Mykola Skrypnyk]], [[Petro Slynko]], [[Yakov Yakovlev]] (Epshtein). On September 9, 1918 Mayorov and Slynko replaced Kertvelishvili and Farbman as full members, while the last two lost their membership.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -28,40 +28,26 @@
 {{for|the post-Soviet party|Communist Party of Ukraine|Communist Party of Ukraine (renewed)}}
 {{Refimprove|date=July 2007}}
 {{History of Soviet government of Ukraine}}
-
 The '''Communist Party of Ukraine'''  ({{lang-uk|Комуністична Партія України}} ''Komunistychna Partiya Ukrayiny'', КПУ, ''KPU''; {{lang-ru|Коммунистическая партия Украины}}), was the founding and ruling political party of the [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]] operated as the Ukrainian branch of the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] (CPSU). The CPU was the sole governing party was founded in 1918 as the ''Communist Party (Bolshevik) of Ukraine'' until 1952, when it became the ''Communist Party of Ukraine''. The party was abolished in 26 August 1991 after the [[1991_Soviet_coup_d%27état_attempt|failed Soviet coup]].
-
 The CPU was organized on the basis of [[democratic centralism]], a principle conceived by [[Vladimir Lenin]] that entails democratic and open discussion of policy issues within the party followed by the requirement of total unity in upholding the agreed policies.  The CPU's highest body was the Party Congress, convened every held every five years. When the Congress was not in session, the Central Committee was the highest body, but because the Central Committee met twice a year, most duties and responsibilities were vested in the Politburo. The party leader held the office of [[First Secretary of the Communist Party of Ukraine|First Secretary]] who served as the head of government.
-
 Like all other CPSU republican branches, The CPU was committed, in accordance to the party statute, adhered to [[Marxism–Leninism]] ideology based on the writings of [[Vladimir Lenin]] and [[Karl Marx]], and formalized under [[Joseph Stalin]]. The party had pursued [[state socialism]], under which all industries were nationalized and a [[planned economy]] was introduced. Prior to the introduction of [[Economic planning|central planning]] was adopted in 1929, Lenin had introduced a [[mixed economy]], commonly referred to as the [[New Economic Policy]], in the 1920s, which allowed to introduce certain capitalist elements in the Soviet economy.
-
 ==Overview==
 {{see also|Ukrainian People's Republic of Soviets|All-Ukrainian Congress of Soviets}}
 The Communist Party (Bolsheviks) of Ukraine was created in July 1918 in Moscow. Most of its constituent members were former members of the Russian [[Bolshevik]]s who in 1917 pronounced themselves "Social-Democracy of Ukraine" and with the help of the Antonov-Ovseyenko expeditionary forces of Petrograd and Moscow Red Guards instigated a civil war in Ukraine by routing local Red Guards. After the signing of the [[Treaty of Brest-Litovsk]] the Bolshevik faction Social-Democracy of Ukraine was forced to dissolve as all Bolsheviks were forced out of Ukraine.
-
 On October 13, 1952 the party officially was renamed as the '''Communist Party of Ukraine'''.
-
 On August 26, 1991 the Communist Party was outlawed in Ukraine. Different sectors reconstituted themselves in different parties. One group led by moderate members under [[Oleksandr Moroz]] formed the [[Socialist Party of Ukraine]] (SPU) out of most of the former members, a group of agrarians led by [[Serhiy Dovhan]] and [[Oleksandr Tkachenko (politician)|Oleksandr Tkachenko]] formed the [[Peasant Party of Ukraine]] (SelPU), and another group, the [[Communist Party of Ukraine]], was re-created in 1993 in [[Donetsk]] under the leadership of [[Petro Symonenko]] when the ban was lifted. The remaining members either changed political direction or created their own left-wing parties such as the Vitrenko bloc, Social-Democratic (United) party, and others.
 {{History of Ukraine}}
-
 ===Central Committees===
 Initial composition of the committee was elected at the 1st party Congress on July 12, 1918 and consisted of the following people: [[Ivan Amosov]], [[Andrei Bubnov]], [[Afanasiy Butsenko]], [[Shulim Gruzman]], [[Vladimir Zatonsky]], [[Lavrentiy Kartvelishvili]], [[Emmanuil Kviring]], [[Stanislav Kosior]], [[Isaak Kreisberg]], [[Yuriy Lutovinov]], [[Yuriy Pyatakov]], [[Rafail Farbman]], [[Pinkhus Rovner]], [[Leonid Tarsky]] (Sokolovsky), [[Isaac Izrailevich Schwartz|Isaak Shvarts]]. Beside full members there also were candidate to the committee. The initial composition included [[Yan Hamarnik]] (Yakov Pudikovich), [[Dmitriy Lebed]], [[Mikhail Mayorov]] (Meyer Biberman), [[Mykola Skrypnyk]], [[Petro Slynko]], [[Yakov Yakovlev]] (Epshtein). On September 9, 1918 Mayorov and Slynko replaced Kertvelishvili and Farbman as full members, while the last two lost their membership.
-
 During [[World War II]] on October 2, 1942 there was created the Illegal Central Committee of the Party consisting of 17 members. The committee was dissolved on June 29, 1943. Among the members of the committee were such personalities as [[Sydir Kovpak]], [[Leonid Korniets]], Oleksiy Fedorov, and others.
-
 ===Politburo===
 The party  had its own Politburo  created on March 6, 1919. On September 25, 1952 the committee was renamed into the Bureau of the Central Committee (CC) of CP(b)U, and in October the same year as the Bureau of the CC CPU. On October 10, 1952 it became the Presidium of the CC CPU. On June 26, 1966 again the bureau was finally left with its original name as the Politburo of the CC CPU.
-
 At first it consisted of five members and later another one was added. The first Politburo included [[Andriy Bubnov]], [[Emanuel Kviring]], [[Volodymyr Mescheriakov]], [[Heorhiy Pyatakov]], [[Christian Rakovsky]], and later [[Stanislav Kosior]], all centrists.
-
 From March 23 until April 15, 1920 there was elected a Provisional Bureau which the next day was ratified by the Russian Communist Party (Bolsheviks).
-
 ===Orgburo===
 Along with Politburo the party like its Russian counterpart had its own Orgburo that was created the same day as Politburo.
-
 ==Party leader==
 The party was headed by its secretary. The position was highly influential and often was considered to be more important than the head of state (see [[Ukrainian SSR]]).
-
 {| class="wikitable"
 |-
 ! Years !! Name !! Remarks
@@ -74,9 +60,7 @@

 | 1934 - 1991 || 1st Secretary of Central Committee ||
 |}
-
 The following list is composed of the secretary of the Central Committee of the party who were the leaders of the Party. The position also was changing names between being called the First Secretary or the General Secretary, depending on a political atmosphere in the Soviet Union. The position was not officially of the head of state, but certainly was very influential, especially within the republic. The longest serving secretary was Vladimir Shcherbitsky with some 17 years as the head of the Communist Party, the second best is split between Stanislav Kosior and Nikita Khrushchev, both of which have 11 years.
-
 *[[Mykola Skrypnyk|Mykola Oleksiiovych Skrypnyk]] (20 April–26 May 1918) (Secretary of the Organizational Bureau)
 {|class="wikitable" width="100%"
 !#
@@ -360,35 +344,24 @@
 |-
 |align=center|Grigoriy Kharchenko
 |}
-
 ==Party Congresses==
 There were 28 Congresses with the last one consisting out of two stages. There also were three consolidated conferences of the party from 1926 to 1932. At the second stage of the last Congress there were 273 members in the Central Committee.
-
 ===First Congress, July 1918===
 This took place in Moscow and decided to call for preparations for an armed uprising against the occupying [[Central Powers]] forces and [[Hetman]] [[Pavlo Skoropadskyi]]’s dictatorship.<ref>[http://encyclopedia2.thefreedictionary.com/Partisan+Movement+of+1918%E2%80%9322 ] accessed 24 January 2011</ref> There were only 15 members in the Central Committee and six candidates.It reversed the decision adopted that April by a preliminary council in Tahanroh to established an independent Ukrainian bolshevik party with a membership in the envisaged Third International apart from the Russian party.
-
 ====Central Committee====
 Ivan Amosov, [[Andrei Bubnov]], Afanasiy Butsenko, Shulim Gruzman, [[Vladimir Zatonsky]], Lavrentiy Kartvelishvili (excl.), [[Emmanuil Kviring]], [[Stanislaw Kosior]], Isaak Kreisberg, Yuriy Lutovinov, Georgiy Pyatakov, Rafail Farbman (excl.), Pinkhus Rovner, Leonid Tarskiy (Sokolovsky), Isaak Shvarts.
-
 Promoted to members: Mikhail Mayorov (Meyer Biberman) and Pyotr Slinko
-
 ===Second Congress, October 1918===
 This also took place in Moscow. [[Joseph Stalin]] was elected to the Central Committee.<ref>[http://www.stel.ru/stalin/civil_war_in_russia_1918.htm Joseph Stalin, Biographical Chronicle] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524091951/http://www.stel.ru/stalin/civil_war_in_russia_1918.htm |date=2011-05-24 }} accessed 24 January 2011</ref>
-
 ====Central Committee====
 [[Artyom]] (Fyodor Sergeyev), Nikolai Beschetvertnoi, Shulim Gruzman
-
 ===Third Congress, March 1919===
 This congress took place in Kharkov. A new central committee with a majority of [[Left communism|Left Communists]] was elected. This prompted the [[8th Congress of the Russian Communist Party (Bolsheviks)|Eight Congress]] of the [[Russian Communist Party (Bolsheviks)|Russian Communist Party]] to pass the following motion: ""It is necessary to have a unified communist party with a unified central committee ... All decisions of the RCP and its leading organs are absolutely binding for all parts of the party, independent of their national composition. The central committees of the Ukrainian, Lettish and Lithuanian communists are conferred the rights of regional committees of the party; they are to be unreservedly subordinate to the central committee of the RCP."<ref>[http://www.whatnextjournal.co.uk/pages/theory/Hollis.html The Self-Determination of Nations: The Theory and Practice (Ukraine and Georgia)] by Annette Franz and Dave Hollis accessed 24 January 2011</ref>
-
 ===Fourth Congress, March 17–23, 1920===
 The [[Borotbists]] were forced to dissolve themselves and their erstwile members were permitted to join the CP(b)U.<ref>[http://www.marxists.org/archive/lenin/works/1920/feb/06b.htm Draft Resolution on the Ukrainian Borotbist Party (Notes)] accessed 24 January 2011</ref> Vasyl Ellan-Blakytny and Shumsky drawn from the Borotbist leadership were elected to the Committee and the Borotbist Central Committee passed a resolution dissolving the Borotbist party and its central committee. All members were instructed to apply for CP(B)U membership. Nearly 4,000 out of approximately 5,000 Borotbists  were admitted to the CP(B)U.<ref>[http://www.day.kiev.ua/258303/ A great experiment`; Towards the history of national communism in Ukraine] By James Mace, accessed 24 January 2011</ref>
-
 ===Later congresses===
 From 1919 to 1934 all meetings were conducted in [[Kharkiv]], capital of the [[Ukrainian SSR]].
-
 There were three major Committees and several Bureaus. Each committee had members and candidates to members each with certain degree of obligations. The members and candidates to the committees were elected at the Party Congress. The number of members varied from one gathering to the next usually in ascending sequence. During the [[Great Purge]] the numbers remarkably declined as well as one of the committees, Central Control Committee, was disbanded. The first members were elected in 1918, 15 members of the Central Committee, six candidates as well as three members and two candidates of the Revision Committee. In 1920 the Central Control Committee was formed and by 1934 the Party accounted for some 191 members and 45 candidates in all committees. In 1937 there were only 71 members and 40 candidates in two committees. By 1990 the number of members grew just over 300 members.
-

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -366,6 +366,7 @@
 ===Later congresses===
 From 1919 to 1934 all meetings were conducted in [[Kharkiv]], capital of the [[Ukrainian SSR]].
 There were three major Committees and several Bureaus. Each committee had members and candidates to members each with certain degree of obligations. The members and candidates to the committees were elected at the Party Congress. The number of members varied from one gathering to the next usually in ascending sequence. During the [[Great Purge]] the numbers remarkably declined as well as one of the committees, Central Control Committee, was disbanded. The first members were elected in 1918, 15 members of the Central Committee, six candidates as well as three members and two candidates of the Revision Committee. In 1920 the Central Control Committee was formed and by 1934 the Party accounted for some 191 members and 45 candidates in all committees. In 1937 there were only 71 members and 40 candidates in two committees. By 1990 the number of members grew just over 300 members.
+
 ==Party headquarters==
 {| class="wikitable"
 |-

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -40,6 +40,7 @@
 ===Central Committees===
 Initial composition of the committee was elected at the 1st party Congress on July 12, 1918 and consisted of the following people: [[Ivan Amosov]], [[Andrei Bubnov]], [[Afanasiy Butsenko]], [[Shulim Gruzman]], [[Vladimir Zatonsky]], [[Lavrentiy Kartvelishvili]], [[Emmanuil Kviring]], [[Stanislav Kosior]], [[Isaak Kreisberg]], [[Yuriy Lutovinov]], [[Yuriy Pyatakov]], [[Rafail Farbman]], [[Pinkhus Rovner]], [[Leonid Tarsky]] (Sokolovsky), [[Isaac Izrailevich Schwartz|Isaak Shvarts]]. Beside full members there also were candidate to the committee. The initial composition included [[Yan Hamarnik]] (Yakov Pudikovich), [[Dmitriy Lebed]], [[Mikhail Mayorov]] (Meyer Biberman), [[Mykola Skrypnyk]], [[Petro Slynko]], [[Yakov Yakovlev]] (Epshtein). On September 9, 1918 Mayorov and Slynko replaced Kertvelishvili and Farbman as full members, while the last two lost their membership.
 During [[World War II]] on October 2, 1942 there was created the Illegal Central Committee of the Party consisting of 17 members. The committee was dissolved on June 29, 1943. Among the members of the committee were such personalities as [[Sydir Kovpak]], [[Leonid Korniets]], Oleksiy Fedorov, and others.
+
 ===Politburo===
 The party  had its own Politburo  created on March 6, 1919. On September 25, 1952 the committee was renamed into the Bureau of the Central Committee (CC) of CP(b)U, and in October the same year as the Bureau of the CC CPU. On October 10, 1952 it became the Presidium of the CC CPU. On June 26, 1966 again the bureau was finally left with its original name as the Politburo of the CC CPU.
 At first it consisted of five members and later another one was added. The first Politburo included [[Andriy Bubnov]], [[Emanuel Kviring]], [[Volodymyr Mescheriakov]], [[Heorhiy Pyatakov]], [[Christian Rakovsky]], and later [[Stanislav Kosior]], all centrists.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -362,6 +362,7 @@
 [[Artyom]] (Fyodor Sergeyev), Nikolai Beschetvertnoi, Shulim Gruzman
 ===Third Congress, March 1919===
 This congress took place in Kharkov. A new central committee with a majority of [[Left communism|Left Communists]] was elected. This prompted the [[8th Congress of the Russian Communist Party (Bolsheviks)|Eight Congress]] of the [[Russian Communist Party (Bolsheviks)|Russian Communist Party]] to pass the following motion: ""It is necessary to have a unified communist party with a unified central committee ... All decisions of the RCP and its leading organs are absolutely binding for all parts of the party, independent of their national composition. The central committees of the Ukrainian, Lettish and Lithuanian communists are conferred the rights of regional committees of the party; they are to be unreservedly subordinate to the central committee of the RCP."<ref>[http://www.whatnextjournal.co.uk/pages/theory/Hollis.html The Self-Determination of Nations: The Theory and Practice (Ukraine and Georgia)] by Annette Franz and Dave Hollis accessed 24 January 2011</ref>
+
 ===Fourth Congress, March 17–23, 1920===
 The [[Borotbists]] were forced to dissolve themselves and their erstwile members were permitted to join the CP(b)U.<ref>[http://www.marxists.org/archive/lenin/works/1920/feb/06b.htm Draft Resolution on the Ukrainian Borotbist Party (Notes)] accessed 24 January 2011</ref> Vasyl Ellan-Blakytny and Shumsky drawn from the Borotbist leadership were elected to the Committee and the Borotbist Central Committee passed a resolution dissolving the Borotbist party and its central committee. All members were instructed to apply for CP(B)U membership. Nearly 4,000 out of approximately 5,000 Borotbists  were admitted to the CP(B)U.<ref>[http://www.day.kiev.ua/258303/ A great experiment`; Towards the history of national communism in Ukraine] By James Mace, accessed 24 January 2011</ref>
 ===Later congresses===

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -29,8 +29,11 @@
 {{Refimprove|date=July 2007}}
 {{History of Soviet government of Ukraine}}
 The '''Communist Party of Ukraine'''  ({{lang-uk|Комуністична Партія України}} ''Komunistychna Partiya Ukrayiny'', КПУ, ''KPU''; {{lang-ru|Коммунистическая партия Украины}}), was the founding and ruling political party of the [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]] operated as the Ukrainian branch of the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] (CPSU). The CPU was the sole governing party was founded in 1918 as the ''Communist Party (Bolshevik) of Ukraine'' until 1952, when it became the ''Communist Party of Ukraine''. The party was abolished in 26 August 1991 after the [[1991_Soviet_coup_d%27état_attempt|failed Soviet coup]].
+
 The CPU was organized on the basis of [[democratic centralism]], a principle conceived by [[Vladimir Lenin]] that entails democratic and open discussion of policy issues within the party followed by the requirement of total unity in upholding the agreed policies.  The CPU's highest body was the Party Congress, convened every held every five years. When the Congress was not in session, the Central Committee was the highest body, but because the Central Committee met twice a year, most duties and responsibilities were vested in the Politburo. The party leader held the office of [[First Secretary of the Communist Party of Ukraine|First Secretary]] who served as the head of government.
+
 Like all other CPSU republican branches, The CPU was committed, in accordance to the party statute, adhered to [[Marxism–Leninism]] ideology based on the writings of [[Vladimir Lenin]] and [[Karl Marx]], and formalized under [[Joseph Stalin]]. The party had pursued [[state socialism]], under which all industries were nationalized and a [[planned economy]] was introduced. Prior to the introduction of [[Economic planning|central planning]] was adopted in 1929, Lenin had introduced a [[mixed economy]], commonly referred to as the [[New Economic Policy]], in the 1920s, which allowed to introduce certain capitalist elements in the Soviet economy.
+
 ==Overview==
 {{see also|Ukrainian People's Republic of Soviets|All-Ukrainian Congress of Soviets}}
 The Communist Party (Bolsheviks) of Ukraine was created in July 1918 in Moscow. Most of its constituent members were former members of the Russian [[Bolshevik]]s who in 1917 pronounced themselves "Social-Democracy of Ukraine" and with the help of the Antonov-Ovseyenko expeditionary forces of Petrograd and Moscow Red Guards instigated a civil war in Ukraine by routing local Red Guards. After the signing of the [[Treaty of Brest-Litovsk]] the Bolshevik faction Social-Democracy of Ukraine was forced to dissolve as all Bolsheviks were forced out of Ukraine.
llm_output:
**Added context about the Communist Party of Ukraine's organization and ideology.**

Weaponised: Not Weaponised. The changes provide historical context and details about the Communist Party of Ukraine without employing weaponisation terms or narratives that could be seen as politically charged or biased.

 ===First Congress, July 1918===
 This took place in Moscow and decided to call for preparations for an armed uprising against the occupying [[Central Powers]] forces and [[Hetman]] [[Pavlo Skoropadskyi]]’s dictatorship.<ref>[http://encyclopedia2.thefreedictionary.com/Partisan+Movement+of+1918%E2%80%9322 ] accessed 24 January 2011</ref> There were only 15 members in the Central Committee and six candidates.It reversed the decision adopted that April by a preliminary council in Tahanroh to established an independent Ukrainian bolshevik party with a membership in the envisaged Third International apart from the Russian party.
+
 ====Central Committee====
 Ivan Amosov, [[Andrei Bubnov]], Afanasiy Butsenko, Shulim Gruzman, [[Vladimir Zatonsky]], Lavrentiy Kartvelishvili (excl.), [[Emmanuil Kviring]], [[Stanislaw Kosior]], Isaak Kreisberg, Yuriy Lutovinov, Georgiy Pyatakov, Rafail Farbman (excl.), Pinkhus Rovner, Leonid Tarskiy (Sokolovsky), Isaak Shvarts.
 Promoted to members: Mikhail Mayorov (Meyer Biberman) and Pyotr Slinko
 
 ===Second Congress, October 1918===
 This also took place in Moscow. [[Joseph Stalin]] was elected to the Central Committee.<ref>[http://www.stel.ru/stalin/civil_war_in_russia_1918.htm Joseph Stalin, Biographical Chronicle] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524091951/http://www.stel.ru/stalin/civil_war_in_russia_1918.htm |date=2011-05-24 }} accessed 24 January 2011</ref>
+
 ====Central Committee====
 [[Artyom]] (Fyodor Sergeyev), Nikolai Beschetvertnoi, Shulim Gruzman
+
 ===Third Congress, March 1919===
 This congress took place in Kharkov. A new central committee with a majority of [[Left communism|Left Communists]] was elected. This prompted the [[8th Congress of the Russian Communist Party (Bolsheviks)|Eight Congress]] of the [[Russian Communist Party (Bolsheviks)|Russian Communist Party]] to pass the following motion: ""It is necessary to have a unified communist party with a unified central committee ... All decisions of the RCP and its leading organs are absolutely binding for all parts of the party, independent of their national composition. The central committees of the Ukrainian, Lettish and Lithuanian communists are conferred the rights of regional committees of the party; they are to be unreservedly subordinate to the central committee of the RCP."<ref>[http://www.whatnextjournal.co.uk/pages/theory/Hollis.html The Self-Determination of Nations: The Theory and Practice (Ukraine and Georgia)] by Annette Franz and Dave Hollis accessed 24 January 2011</ref>
 
 ===Fourth Congress, March 17–23, 1920===
-The [[Borotbists]] were forced to dissolve themselves and their erstwile members were permitted to join the CP(b)U.<ref>[http://www.marxists.org/archive/lenin/works/1920/feb/06b.htm Draft Resolution on the Ukrainian Borotbist Party (Notes)] accessed 24 January 2011</ref> Vasyl Ellan-Blakytny and Shumsky drawn from the Borotbist leadership were elected to the Committee and the Borotbist Central Committee passed a resolution dissolving the Borotbist party and its central committee. All members were instructed to apply for CP(B)U membership. Nearly 4,000 out of approximately 5,000 Borotbists  were admitted to the CP(B)U.<ref>[http://www.day.kiev.ua/258303/ A great experiment`; Towards the history of national communism in Ukraine] By James Mace, accessed 24 January 2011</ref>
+The [[Borotbists]] were forced to dissolve themselves and their erstwhile members were permitted to join the CP(b)U.<ref>[http://www.marxists.org/archive/lenin/works/1920/feb/06b.htm Draft Resolution on the Ukrainian Borotbist Party (Notes)] accessed 24 January 2011</ref> Vasyl Ellan-Blakytny and Shumsky drawn from the Borotbist leadership were elected to the Committee and the Borotbist Central Committee passed a resolution dissolving the Borotbist party and its central committee. All members were instructed to apply for CP(B)U membership. Nearly 4,000 out of approximately 5,000 Borotbists  were admitted to the CP(B)U.<ref>[http://www.day.kiev.ua/258303/ A great experiment`; Towards the history of national communism in Ukraine] By James Mace, accessed 24 January 2011</ref>
+
 ===Later congresses===
 From 1919 to 1934 all meetings were conducted in [[Kharkiv]], capital of the [[Ukrainian SSR]].
 There were three major Committees and several Bureaus. Each committee had members and candidates to members each with certain degree of obligations. The members and candidates to the committees were elected at the Party Congress. The number of members varied from one gathering to the next usually in ascending sequence. During the [[Great Purge]] the numbers remarkably declined as well as one of the committees, Central Control Committee, was disbanded. The first members were elected in 1918, 15 members of the Central Committee, six candidates as well as three members and two candidates of the Revision Committee. In 1920 the Central Control Committee was formed and by 1934 the Party accounted for some 191 members and 45 candidates in all committees. In 1937 there were only 71 members and 40 candidates in two committees. By 1990 the number of members grew just over 300 members.

''[http://www.dsnews.ua/nasha_revolyutsiya_1917/vpered-do-sovitskoyi-rosiyi-yak-ukrayinski-komunisti-nepravilniy-22102018200000 To the Soviet Russia. How the Ukrainian Communists "incorrect direction" were electing (До совітської Росії. Як комуністи України "неправильний напрям" обрали)]''. DS News. 22 October 2018</ref> 
+
+After the signing of the [[Treaty of Brest-Litovsk]] the Bolshevik faction Social-Democracy of Ukraine was forced to dissolve as all Bolsheviks were forced out of Ukraine.
+
 On October 13, 1952 the party officially was renamed as the '''Communist Party of Ukraine'''.
 On August 26, 1991 the Communist Party was outlawed in Ukraine. Different sectors reconstituted themselves in different parties. One group led by moderate members under [[Oleksandr Moroz]] formed the [[Socialist Party of Ukraine]] (SPU) out of most of the former members, a group of agrarians led by [[Serhiy Dovhan]] and [[Oleksandr Tkachenko (politician)|Oleksandr Tkachenko]] formed the [[Peasant Party of Ukraine]] (SelPU), and another group, the [[Communist Party of Ukraine]], was re-created in 1993 in [[Donetsk]] under the leadership of [[Petro Symonenko]] when the ban was lifted. The remaining members either changed political direction or created their own left-wing parties such as the Vitrenko bloc, Social-Democratic (United) party, and others.
 {{History of Ukraine}}

The CPU was the sole governing party was founded in 1918 as the ''Communist Party (Bolshevik) of Ukraine'' until 1952, when it became the ''Communist Party of Ukraine''. -

+The '''Communist Party of Ukraine'''  ({{lang-uk|Комуністична Партія України}} ''Komunistychna Partiya Ukrayiny'', КПУ, ''KPU''; {{lang-ru|Коммунистическая партия Украины}}), was the founding and ruling political party of the [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]] operated as a republican branch ([[union republics]]) of the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] (CPSU).<ref name=eoupyrih2007>Pyrih, R. ''[http://resource.history.org.ua/cgi-bin/eiu/history.exe?Z21ID=&I21DBN=EIU&P21DBN=EIU&S21STN=1&S21REF=10&S21FMT=eiu_all&C21COM=S&S21CNR=20&S21P01=0&S21P02=0&S21P03=TRN=&S21COLORTERMS=0&S21STR=Kom_partiya_Ukr_Radyanska_doba Communist Party of Ukraine, the Soviet period (КОМУНІСТИЧНА ПАРТІЯ УКРАЇНИ РАДЯНСЬКОЇ ДОБИ)]''. Encyclopedia of History of Ukraine. 2007</ref> The CPU was the sole governing party was founded in 1918 as the ''Communist Party (Bolshevik) of Ukraine'' until 1952, when it became the ''Communist Party of Ukraine''. The party was abolished in 26 August 1991 after the [[1991 Soviet coup d'état attempt|failed Soviet coup]] in [[Moscow]].
+
+The CPU was organized on the basis of [[democratic centralism]],<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> a principle conceived by [[Vladimir Lenin]] that entails democratic and open discussion of policy issues within the party followed by the requirement of total unity in upholding the agreed policies. The party's ideological platform was [[Marxism-Leninism]].<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> The main goal of the party's program was construction of socialist and communist society.<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> The norms of the party's internal life were determined by the status of the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]].<ref name=eoupyrih2007/>
+
+The CPU's highest body was the Party Congress, convened every held every five years. When the Congress was not in session, the Central Committee was the highest body, but because the Central Committee met twice a year, most duties and responsibilities were vested in the Politburo. The party leader held the office of [[First Secretary of the Communist Party of Ukraine|First Secretary]] who served as the head of government.
 
 Like all other CPSU republican branches, The CPU was committed, in accordance to the party statute, adhered to [[Marxism–Leninism]] ideology based on the writings of [[Vladimir Lenin]] and [[Karl Marx]], and formalized under [[Joseph Stalin]]. The party had pursued [[state socialism]], under which all industries were nationalized and a [[planned economy]] was introduced. Prior to the introduction of [[Economic planning|central planning]] was adopted in 1929, Lenin had introduced a [[mixed economy]], commonly referred to as the [[New Economic Policy]], in the 1920s, which allowed to introduce certain capitalist elements in the Soviet economy.

+
 The Communist Party (Bolsheviks) of Ukraine was created in July 1918 in Moscow.

''[https://www.jnsm.com.ua/h/07051918T/ Creation of the Communist Party (Bolsheviks) of Ukraine (Створення Комуністичної партії (більшовиків) України)]''. ''[http://www.dsnews.ua/nasha_revolyutsiya_1917/vpered-do-sovitskoyi-rosiyi-yak-ukrayinski-komunisti-nepravilniy-22102018200000 To the Soviet Russia. How the Ukrainian Communists "incorrect direction" were electing (До совітської Росії. Як комуністи України "неправильний напрям" обрали)]''. DS News. 22 October 2018</ref> 
@@ -45,6 +47,7 @@
 On August 26, 1991 the Communist Party was outlawed in Ukraine. Different sectors reconstituted themselves in different parties. One group led by moderate members under [[Oleksandr Moroz]] formed the [[Socialist Party of Ukraine]] (SPU) out of most of the former members, a group of agrarians led by [[Serhiy Dovhan]] and [[Oleksandr Tkachenko (politician)|Oleksandr Tkachenko]] formed the [[Peasant Party of Ukraine]] (SelPU), and another group, the [[Communist Party of Ukraine]], was re-created in 1993 in [[Donetsk]] under the leadership of [[Petro Symonenko]] when the ban was lifted. The remaining members either changed political direction or created their own left-wing parties such as the Vitrenko bloc, Social-Democratic (United) party, and others.
 {{History of Ukraine}}
 
+==Organizational structure==
 ===Central Committees===
 Initial composition of the committee was elected at the 1st party Congress on July 12, 1918 and consisted of the following people: [[Ivan Amosov]], [[Andrei Bubnov]], [[Afanasiy Butsenko]], [[Shulim Gruzman]], [[Vladimir Zatonsky]], [[Lavrentiy Kartvelishvili]], [[Emmanuil Kviring]], [[Stanislav Kosior]], [[Isaak Kreisberg]], [[Yuriy Lutovinov]], [[Yuriy Pyatakov]], [[Rafail Farbman]], [[Pinkhus Rovner]], [[Leonid Tarsky]] (Sokolovsky), [[Isaac Izrailevich Schwartz|Isaak Shvarts]]. Beside full members there also were candidate to the committee. The initial composition included [[Yan Hamarnik]] (Yakov Pudikovich), [[Dmitriy Lebed]], [[Mikhail Mayorov]] (Meyer Biberman), [[Mykola Skrypnyk]], [[Petro Slynko]], [[Yakov Yakovlev]] (Epshtein). On September 9, 1918 Mayorov and Slynko replaced Kertvelishvili and Farbman as full members, while the last two lost their membership.
 During [[World War II]] on October 2, 1942 there was created the Illegal Central Committee of the Party consisting of 17 members. The committee was dissolved on June 29, 1943. Among the members of the committee were such personalities as [[Sydir Kovpak]], [[Leonid Korniets]], Oleksiy Fedorov, and others.
