 The party traces its beginning to committees and party's cells of the [[Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] (RSDLP) that existed at the end of the 19th century in all bigger cities and industrial centers on Ukrainian territory which was part of the Russian Empire.<ref name=useyk>Yurchuk, V., Kuras, I. ''[http://leksika.com.ua/10441202/ure/komunistichna_partiya_ukrayini Communist Party of Ukraine (КОМУНІСТИЧНА ПАРТІЯ УКРАЇНИ)]''. [[Ukrainian Soviet Encyclopedia]].</ref><ref name=eoupyrih2007/> Under influence from the [[League of Struggle for the Emancipation of the Working Class]] in [[Saint Petersburg]], in 1897 such organization was also formed in [[Kiev]] and [[Yekaterinoslav]] which also were taking part in preparation and convocation of the [[1st Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] in 1898.<ref name=useyk/> With release of newspaper [[Iskra]] in December of 1900 in Germany, on territory of Ukraine spread out a network of the Lenin's Iskra group and organizations.<ref name=useyk/> Among the most notable activists in Ukraine during that period were [[Ivan Babushkin]], [[Rosalia Zemlyachka]], [[Pyotr Krasikov]], [[Isaak Lalayants]], [[Friedrichs Lengniks]], [[Maxim Litvinov]], [[Grigory Petrovsky]], [[Mykola Skrypnyk]] (Nikolay Skripnik), [[Dmitry Ilyich Ulyanov|Dmitry Ulyanov]], [[Vasiliy Shelgunov]], [[Alexander Schlichter]], [[Alexander Tsiurupa]], and others.<ref name=useyk/> Following the [[2nd Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] (1903) in social-democratic organizations has developed a struggle between Mensheviks and Bolsheviks.<ref name=useyk/> On behalf of [[Vladimir Lenin]], in 1904 [[Vatslav Vorovsky]] with Lalayants and Levitskiy created in [[Odessa]] the Southern Bureau of the RSDLP that led activities of Odessa, Yekaterinoslav, Nikolayev committees, brought together around itself Bolshevik organizations of the South, conducted great deal of work in preparation to the [[3rd Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] in 1905.<ref name=useyk/>
 
 During the [[1905 Russian Revolution]] Bolsheviks in Ukraine guided by decisions of the 3rd Congress led working people to fight against autocracy.<ref name=useyk/> In more than 50 cities and settlements were created Soviets of working deputies.<ref name=useyk/> In December of 1905 Bolsheviks led number of armed uprisings in Ukraine, among which were in [[Horlivka]], Alexandrovsk ([[Zaporizhia]]), [[Kharkiv]].<ref name=useyk/> Kiev, Mykolaiv and many other cities were covered with political strikes.<ref name=useyk/> In course of the revolution the RSDLP organizations in Ukraine grew significantly and in 1907 they were accounted for over 20,000 men.<ref name=useyk/> Organizers and leaders
 of party's activities during this time were Comrade Artyom ([[Fyodor Sergeev]]), [[Vladimir Bonch-Bruyevich]], [[Myron Kostyantynovych Vladymyrov|Miron Vladimirov]], [[Kliment Voroshilov]], [[Serafima Hopner|Serafima Gopner]], [[Sergey Ivanovich Gusev|Sergey Gusev]], [[Lidia Knipovich]], [[Gleb Krzhizhanovsky]], Grigory Petrovsky, Nikolay Skripnik, Alexander Schlichter, [[Yemelyan Yaroslavsky]], and others.<ref name=useyk/>
 
+===Communist Party of Ukraine===
 The Communist Party (Bolsheviks) of Ukraine was created in July 1918 in Moscow. 
 
 Most of its constituent members were former members of the Russian [[Bolshevik]]s who in 1917 pronounced themselves "[[Communist Party of the Soviet Union|RSDRP(b)]] – Social-Democracy of Ukraine"<ref>Yefimenko, H. ''[https://www.jnsm.com.ua/h/07051918T/ Creation of the Communist Party (Bolsheviks) of Ukraine (Створення Комуністичної партії (більшовиків) України)]''. V tsei den istorii. 5 July 2018</ref> and with the help of the [[Vladimir Antonov-Ovseyenko|Antonov-Ovseyenko]] [[Group of forces in battle with the counterrevolution in the South of Russia|expeditionary forces of Petrograd and Moscow Red Guards]] instigated a civil war in Ukraine by routing local Red Guards. Number of Ukrainian politicians from left faction of the [[Ukrainian Social Democratic Labour Party]] (also known as Left Ukrainian Social Democrats or unofficially as "Ukrainian Bolsheviks") joined the Bolsheviks in January 1918.<ref>Yefimenko, H. ''[http://www.dsnews.ua/nasha_revolyutsiya_1917/vpered-do-sovitskoyi-rosiyi-yak-ukrayinski-komunisti-nepravilniy-22102018200000 To the Soviet Russia. How the Ukrainian Communists "incorrect direction" were electing (До совітської Росії. Як комуністи України "неправильний напрям" обрали)]''. DS News. 22 October 2018</ref>

 During the [[1905 Russian Revolution]] Bolsheviks in Ukraine guided by decisions of the 3rd Congress led working people to fight against autocracy.<ref name=useyk/> In more than 50 cities and settlements were created Soviets of working deputies.<ref name=useyk/> In December of 1905 Bolsheviks led number of armed uprisings in Ukraine, among which were in [[Horlivka]], Alexandrovsk ([[Zaporizhia]]), [[Kharkiv]].<ref name=useyk/> Kiev, Mykolaiv and many other cities were covered with [[strike action]].<ref name=useyk/> In course of the revolution the RSDLP organizations in Ukraine grew significantly and in 1907 they were accounted for over 20,000 men.<ref name=useyk/> Organizers and leaders
 of party's activities during this time were Comrade Artyom ([[Fyodor Sergeev]]), [[Vladimir Bonch-Bruyevich]], [[Myron Kostyantynovych Vladymyrov|Miron Vladimirov]], [[Kliment Voroshilov]], [[Serafima Hopner|Serafima Gopner]], [[Sergey Ivanovich Gusev|Sergey Gusev]], [[Lidia Knipovich]], [[Gleb Krzhizhanovsky]], Grigory Petrovsky, Nikolay Skripnik, Alexander Schlichter, [[Yemelyan Yaroslavsky]], and others.<ref name=useyk/> During the following year of government reaction in 1907–10 Bolshevik organizations in Ukraine have suffered significant losses, yet continued their revolutionary activities.<ref name=useyk/> Guided by decisions of the 1912 [[Prague Conference]], those Bolsheviks carried out work to expand and strengthen ties with the masses, their international upbringing, preparing workers to new revolutionary battles, were exposing supporters of what was labeled as "[[liquidationism]]", "otzovizm" (recalling representatives from the State Duma), [[trotskyism]] and [[bourgeois nationalism]].<ref name=useyk/> During the years of [[World War I]] (1914–18) the Bolsheviks of Ukraine propagated the Lenin's slogan of transforming the [[imperialist war]]<ref>Brian Becker. -During the 1917 [[February Revolution]], known as the February bourgeois democratic revolution in communist lingo, the Bolshevik organizations guided by the Central Committee of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party claimed that they led the struggle of the working people against [[Russian autocracy]], and after overthrowing it launched a struggle for the masses against whom communists named as conciliators and bourgeois nationalists.<ref name=useyk/>
+During the 1917 [[February Revolution]], known as the February bourgeois democratic revolution in communist jargon, the Bolshevik organizations guided by the Central Committee of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party claimed that they led the struggle of the working people against [[Russian autocracy]], and after overthrowing it launched a struggle for the masses against whom communists named as conciliators and bourgeois nationalists.<ref name=useyk/> The process of differentiation of the Bolsheviks and the Mensheviks in the joint organizations of the RSDLP intensified and as well as the process of creation of independent Bolshevik organizations that on July 1917 accounted for around 33,000 men.<ref name=useyk/>
 
 ===Communist Party of Ukraine===
 The Communist Party (Bolsheviks) of Ukraine was created in July 1918 in Moscow.

 During the [[1905 Russian Revolution]] Bolsheviks in Ukraine guided by decisions of the 3rd Congress led working people to fight against autocracy.<ref name=useyk/> In more than 50 cities and settlements were created Soviets of working deputies.<ref name=useyk/> In December of 1905 Bolsheviks led number of armed uprisings in Ukraine, among which were in [[Horlivka]], Alexandrovsk ([[Zaporizhia]]), [[Kharkiv]].<ref name=useyk/> Kiev, Mykolaiv and many other cities were covered with [[strike action]].<ref name=useyk/> In course of the revolution the RSDLP organizations in Ukraine grew significantly and in 1907 they were accounted for over 20,000 men.<ref name=useyk/> Organizers and leaders
 of party's activities during this time were Comrade Artyom ([[Fyodor Sergeev]]), [[Vladimir Bonch-Bruyevich]], [[Myron Kostyantynovych Vladymyrov|Miron Vladimirov]], [[Kliment Voroshilov]], [[Serafima Hopner|Serafima Gopner]], [[Sergey Ivanovich Gusev|Sergey Gusev]], [[Lidia Knipovich]], [[Gleb Krzhizhanovsky]], Grigory Petrovsky, Nikolay Skripnik, Alexander Schlichter, [[Yemelyan Yaroslavsky]], and others.<ref name=useyk/> During the following year of government reaction in 1907–10 Bolshevik organizations in Ukraine have suffered significant losses, yet continued their revolutionary activities.<ref name=useyk/> Guided by decisions of the 1912 [[Prague Conference]], those Bolsheviks carried out work to expand and strengthen ties with the masses, their international upbringing, preparing workers to new revolutionary battles, were exposing supporters of what was labeled as "[[liquidationism]]", "otzovizm" (recalling representatives from the State Duma), [[trotskyism]] and [[bourgeois nationalism]].<ref name=useyk/> During the years of [[World War I]] (1914–18) the Bolsheviks of Ukraine propagated the Lenin's slogan of transforming the [[imperialist war]]<ref>Brian Becker. ''[https://liberationschool.org/from-inter-imperialist-war-to-global-class-war-understanding-distinct-stages-of-imperialism/ From inter-imperialist war to global class war: Understanding distinct stages of imperialism]''. +
 ===Communist Party of Ukraine===
 The Communist Party (Bolsheviks) of Ukraine was created in July 1918 in Moscow.

 The Communist Party (Bolsheviks) of Ukraine was created in July 1918 in Moscow. 
 
 Most of its constituent members were former members of the Russian [[Bolshevik]]s who in 1917 pronounced themselves "[[Communist Party of the Soviet Union|RSDRP(b)]] – Social-Democracy of Ukraine"<ref>Yefimenko, H. ''[https://www.jnsm.com.ua/h/07051918T/ Creation of the Communist Party (Bolsheviks) of Ukraine (Створення Комуністичної партії (більшовиків) України)]''. Number of Ukrainian politicians from left faction of the [[Ukrainian Social Democratic Labour Party]] (also known as Left Ukrainian Social Democrats or unofficially as "Ukrainian Bolsheviks") joined the Bolsheviks in January 1918.<ref>Yefimenko, H. ''[http://www.dsnews.ua/nasha_revolyutsiya_1917/vpered-do-sovitskoyi-rosiyi-yak-ukrayinski-komunisti-nepravilniy-22102018200000 To the Soviet Russia. How the Ukrainian Communists "incorrect direction" were electing (До совітської Росії. Як комуністи України "неправильний напрям" обрали)]''. DS News. 22 October 2018</ref>

On September 9, 1918 Mayorov and Slynko replaced Kertvelishvili and Farbman as full members, while the last two lost their membership.
 During [[World War II]] on October 2, 1942 there was created the Illegal Central Committee of the Party consisting of 17 members. The committee was dissolved on June 29, 1943. Among the members of the committee were such personalities as [[Sydir Kovpak]], [[Leonid Korniets]], Oleksiy Fedorov, and others.

@@ -44,7 +44,7 @@
 During the 1917 [[February Revolution]], known as the February bourgeois democratic revolution in communist jargon, the Bolshevik organizations guided by the Central Committee of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party claimed that they led the struggle of the working people against [[Russian autocracy]], and after overthrowing it launched a struggle for the masses against whom communists named as conciliators and bourgeois nationalists.<ref name=useyk/> The process of differentiation of the Bolsheviks and the Mensheviks in the joint organizations of the RSDLP intensified and as well as the process of creation of independent Bolshevik organizations that on July 1917 accounted for around 33,000 men.<ref name=useyk/>{{efn|name=estimation}}
 
 Following the "[[July Days]]" and the semi-legal [[6th Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]], Bolsheviks of Ukraine began to prepare the workers for an armed uprising "for the [[Soviet regime]]" ({{lang-uk|за владу Рад}}, {{lang-ru|за власть Советов}}).<ref name=useyk/> Big help was provided to them by the Central Committee of the RSDLP(b) that maintained connection with more than 50 of its party organizations in Ukraine.<ref name=useyk/> Active role in the preparation process of the masses to the "Socialist Revolution" ([[October Revolution]]) was conducted by [[Vasiliy Averin]], [[Yevgenia Bosch]], [[Kliment Voroshilov]], [[Yan Gamarnik]], [[Serafima Hopner|Serafima Gopner]], [[Volodymyr Zatonsky|Vladimir Zatonsky]], [[Andriy Ivanov|Andrei Ivanov]], [[Emanuel Kviring]], [[Yuriy Kotsiubynsky]], [[Dmitriy Lebed]], [[Grigory Petrovsky]], [[Vitaly Primakov]], [[Fyodor Sergeyev]], [[Ivan Smirnov]], and others.<ref name=useyk/> During the summer of 1917 on territory of modern Ukraine were formed two regional (oblast) branches of the [[Russian Social Democratic Labour Party (Bolsheviks)|RSFLP(b)]] of '''[[Southwestern Krai]]''' and '''Donets-Krivoi Rog Basin''' and later in the fall the bureau of the RSFLP(b) military organizations of the '''[[Southwestern Front (Russian Empire)|Southwestern Front]]'''<ref name=useyk/> (due to ongoing [[World War I]]). Also membership of the party in Ukraine grew significantly in 1917 from 7,000 in April to 50,000 in October.<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> Following the Bolshevik coup-d'état, at the [[All-Russian Congress of Soviets#Second Congress|2nd All-Russian Congress of Soviets]] in [[Petrograd]] among its delegates, there were 65 Bolsheviks from Ukraine.<ref name=useyk/>

@@ -39,11 +39,11 @@
 The party traces its beginning to committees and party's cells of the [[Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] (RSDLP) that existed at the end of the 19th century in all bigger cities and industrial centers on Ukrainian territory which was part of the Russian Empire.<ref name=useyk>Yurchuk, V., Kuras, I. ''[http://leksika.com.ua/10441202/ure/komunistichna_partiya_ukrayini Communist Party of Ukraine (КОМУНІСТИЧНА ПАРТІЯ УКРАЇНИ)]''. [[Ukrainian Soviet Encyclopedia]].</ref><ref name=eoupyrih2007/> Under influence from the [[League of Struggle for the Emancipation of the Working Class]] in [[Saint Petersburg]], in 1897 such organization was also formed in [[Kiev]] and [[Yekaterinoslav]] which also were taking part in preparation and convocation of the [[1st Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] in 1898.<ref name=useyk/> With release of newspaper [[Iskra]] in December of 1900 in Germany, on territory of Ukraine spread out a network of the Lenin's Iskra group and organizations.<ref name=useyk/> Among the most notable activists in Ukraine during that period were [[Ivan Babushkin]], [[Rosalia Zemlyachka]], [[Pyotr Krasikov]], [[Isaak Lalayants]], [[Friedrichs Lengniks]], [[Maxim Litvinov]], [[Grigory Petrovsky]], [[Mykola Skrypnyk]] (Nikolay Skripnik), [[Dmitry Ilyich Ulyanov|Dmitry Ulyanov]], [[Vasiliy Shelgunov]], [[Alexander Schlichter]], [[Alexander Tsiurupa]], and others.<ref name=useyk/> Following the [[2nd Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] (1903) in social-democratic organizations has developed a struggle between Mensheviks and Bolsheviks.<ref name=useyk/> On behalf of [[Vladimir Lenin]], in 1904 [[Vatslav Vorovsky]] with Lalayants and Levitskiy created in [[Odessa]] the Southern Bureau of the RSDLP that led activities of Odessa, Yekaterinoslav, Nikolayev committees, brought together around itself Bolshevik organizations of the South, conducted great deal of work in preparation to the [[3rd Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] in 1905.<ref name=useyk/>
 
 During the [[1905 Russian Revolution]] Bolsheviks in Ukraine guided by decisions of the 3rd Congress led working people to fight against autocracy.<ref name=useyk/> In more than 50 cities and settlements were created Soviets of working deputies.<ref name=useyk/> In December of 1905 Bolsheviks led number of armed uprisings in Ukraine, among which were in [[Horlivka]], Alexandrovsk ([[Zaporizhia]]), [[Kharkiv]].<ref name=useyk/> Kiev, Mykolaiv and many other cities were covered with [[strike action]].<ref name=useyk/> In course of the revolution the RSDLP organizations in Ukraine grew significantly and in 1907 they were accounted for over 20,000 men.<ref name=useyk/>{{efn|name=estimation|Due to [[russification of Ukraine]], the [[Ukrainian Soviet Encyclopedia]] does not differentiate between two homonymic words in both languages (Russian and Ukrainian) that have different semantics. The Russian word for people "chelovek" ({{lang-ru|человек}}) looks as it was adopted in Ukrainian here as <u>[male]</u> men "cholovik" ({{lang-uk|чоловік}}). Given estimation for men, possibly includes estimation for people in whole.}} Organizers and leaders
-of party's activities during this time were Comrade Artyom ([[Fyodor Sergeev]]), [[Vladimir Bonch-Bruyevich]], [[Miron Vladimirov]], [[Kliment Voroshilov]], [[Serafima Hopner|Serafima Gopner]], [[Sergey Ivanovich Gusev|Sergey Gusev]], [[Lidia Knipovich]], [[Gleb Krzhizhanovsky]], Grigory Petrovsky, Nikolay Skripnik, Alexander Schlichter, [[Yemelyan Yaroslavsky]], and others.<ref name=useyk/> During the following year of government reaction in 1907–10 Bolshevik organizations in Ukraine have suffered significant losses, yet continued their revolutionary activities.<ref name=useyk/> Guided by decisions of the 1912 [[Prague Conference]], those Bolsheviks carried out work to expand and strengthen ties with the masses, their international upbringing, preparing workers to new revolutionary battles, were exposing supporters of what was labeled as "[[liquidationism]]", "otzovizm" (recalling representatives from the State Duma), [[trotskyism]] and [[bourgeois nationalism]].<ref name=useyk/> During the years of [[World War I]] (1914–18) the Bolsheviks of Ukraine propagated the Lenin's slogan of transforming the [[imperialist war]]<ref>Brian Becker. ''[https://liberationschool.org/from-inter-imperialist-war-to-global-class-war-understanding-distinct-stages-of-imperialism/ From inter-imperialist war to global class war: Understanding distinct stages of imperialism]''. -The very next day after the Petrograd's coup-d'état, on 8–13 November (26–31 October by old style), 1917 Bolsheviks headquartered at the [[Mariyinsky Palace]] attempted to [[Kiev Bolshevik Uprising|secure power in Kiev]] with less success and, after the Bolshevik's victory, the authority in Kiev was secured by the [[Regional Committee in Protection of Revolution in Ukraine]] where important role played the [[Central Council of Ukraine]].
+The very next day after the Petrograd's coup-d'état, on 8–13 November (26–31 October by old style), 1917 Bolsheviks headquartered at the [[Mariyinsky Palace]] attempted to [[Kiev Bolshevik Uprising|secure power in Kiev]] with less success and, after the Bolshevik's victory, the authority in Kiev was secured by the [[Regional Committee in Protection of Revolution in Ukraine]] where important role played the [[Central Council of Ukraine]]. In a week the Central Council adopted its Third [[Universal]] where it condemned the Bolshevik coup-d'état and declared Ukraine in federative union with the [[Russian Republic]]. In response to that on 26 November 1917 the Bolshevik [[Sovnarkom]] published its [[manifesto]] to the all population "[https://web.archive.org/web/20190422174556/http://istmat.info/node/27999 About struggle with counter-revolutionary insurgency of Kaledin, Kornilov, Dutov, and supported by the Central Rada (О борьбе с контрреволюционным восстанием Каледина, Корнилова, Дутова, поддерживаемым Центральной Радой)]".

 The party traces its beginning to committees and party's cells of the [[Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] (RSDLP) that existed at the end of the 19th century in all bigger cities and industrial centers on Ukrainian territory which was part of the Russian Empire.<ref name=useyk>Yurchuk, V., Kuras, I. ''[http://leksika.com.ua/10441202/ure/komunistichna_partiya_ukrayini Communist Party of Ukraine (КОМУНІСТИЧНА ПАРТІЯ УКРАЇНИ)]''. [[Ukrainian Soviet Encyclopedia]].</ref><ref name=eoupyrih2007/> Under influence from the [[League of Struggle for the Emancipation of the Working Class]] in [[Saint Petersburg]], in 1897 such organization was also formed in [[Kiev]] and [[Yekaterinoslav]] which also were taking part in preparation and convocation of the [[1st Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] in 1898.<ref name=useyk/> With release of newspaper [[Iskra]] in December of 1900 in Germany, on territory of Ukraine spread out a network of the Lenin's Iskra group and organizations.<ref name=useyk/> Among the most notable activists in Ukraine during that period were [[Ivan Babushkin]], [[Rosalia Zemlyachka]], [[Pyotr Krasikov]], [[Isaak Lalayants]], [[Friedrichs Lengniks]], [[Maxim Litvinov]], [[Grigory Petrovsky]], [[Mykola Skrypnyk]] (Nikolay Skripnik), [[Dmitry Ilyich Ulyanov|Dmitry Ulyanov]], [[Vasiliy Shelgunov]], [[Alexander Schlichter]], [[Alexander Tsiurupa]], and others.<ref name=useyk/> Following the [[2nd Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] (1903) in social-democratic organizations has developed a struggle between Mensheviks and Bolsheviks.<ref name=useyk/> On behalf of [[Vladimir Lenin]], in 1904 [[Vatslav Vorovsky]] with Lalayants and Levitskiy created in [[Odessa]] the Southern Bureau of the RSDLP that led activities of Odessa, Yekaterinoslav, Nikolayev committees, brought together around itself Bolshevik organizations of the South, conducted great deal of work in preparation to the [[3rd Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] in 1905.<ref name=useyk/>
 
 During the [[1905 Russian Revolution]] Bolsheviks in Ukraine guided by decisions of the 3rd Congress led working people to fight against autocracy.<ref name=useyk/> In more than 50 cities and settlements were created Soviets of working deputies.<ref name=useyk/> In December of 1905 Bolsheviks led number of armed uprisings in Ukraine, among which were in [[Horlivka]], Alexandrovsk ([[Zaporizhia]]), [[Kharkiv]].<ref name=useyk/> Kiev, Mykolaiv and many other cities were covered with [[strike action]].<ref name=useyk/> In course of the revolution the RSDLP organizations in Ukraine grew significantly and in 1907 they were accounted for over 20,000 men.<ref name=useyk/>{{efn|name=estimation|Due to [[russification of Ukraine]], the [[Ukrainian Soviet Encyclopedia]] does not differentiate between two homonymic words in both languages (Russian and Ukrainian) that have different semantics. -of party's activities during this time were Comrade Artyom ([[Fyodor Sergeev]]), [[Vladimir Bonch-Bruyevich]], [[Myron Kostyantynovych Vladymyrov|Miron Vladimirov]], [[Kliment Voroshilov]], [[Serafima Hopner|Serafima Gopner]], [[Sergey Ivanovich Gusev|Sergey Gusev]], [[Lidia Knipovich]], [[Gleb Krzhizhanovsky]], Grigory Petrovsky, Nikolay Skripnik, Alexander Schlichter, [[Yemelyan Yaroslavsky]], and others.<ref name=useyk/> During the following year of government reaction in 1907–10 Bolshevik organizations in Ukraine have suffered significant losses, yet continued their revolutionary activities.<ref name=useyk/> Guided by decisions of the 1912 [[Prague Conference]], those Bolsheviks carried out work to expand and strengthen ties with the masses, their international upbringing, preparing workers to new revolutionary battles, were exposing supporters of what was labeled as "[[liquidationism]]", "otzovizm" (recalling representatives from the State Duma), [[trotskyism]] and [[bourgeois nationalism]].<ref name=useyk/> During the years of [[World War I]] (1914–18) the Bolsheviks of Ukraine propagated the Lenin's slogan of transforming the [[imperialist war]]<ref>Brian Becker. @@ -44,7 +44,7 @@
 During the 1917 [[February Revolution]], known as the February bourgeois democratic revolution in communist jargon, the Bolshevik organizations guided by the Central Committee of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party claimed that they led the struggle of the working people against [[Russian autocracy]], and after overthrowing it launched a struggle for the masses against whom communists named as conciliators and bourgeois nationalists.<ref name=useyk/> The process of differentiation of the Bolsheviks and the Mensheviks in the joint organizations of the RSDLP intensified and as well as the process of creation of independent Bolshevik organizations that on July 1917 accounted for around 33,000 men.<ref name=useyk/>{{efn|name=estimation}}
 
 ===Struggle for establishment of the Soviet regime in Ukraine===
-Following the "[[July Days]]" and the semi-legal [[6th Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]], Bolsheviks of Ukraine began to prepare the workers for an armed uprising "for the [[Soviet regime]]" ({{lang-uk|за владу Рад}}, {{lang-ru|за власть Советов}}).<ref name=useyk/> Big help was provided to them by the Central Committee of the RSDLP(b) that maintained connection with more than 50 of its party organizations in Ukraine.<ref name=useyk/> Active role in the preparation process of the masses to the "Socialist Revolution" ([[October Revolution]]) was conducted by [[Vasiliy Averin]], [[Yevgenia Bosch]], [[Kliment Voroshilov]], [[Yan Gamarnik]], [[Serafima Hopner|Serafima Gopner]], [[Volodymyr Zatonsky|Vladimir Zatonsky]], [[Andriy Ivanov|Andrei Ivanov]], [[Emanuel Kviring]], [[Yuriy Kotsiubynsky]], [[Dmitriy Lebed]], [[Grigory Petrovsky]], [[Vitaly Primakov]], [[Fyodor Sergeyev]], [[Ivan Smirnov]], and others.<ref name=useyk/> During the summer of 1917 on territory of modern Ukraine were formed two regional (oblast) branches of the [[Russian Social Democratic Labour Party (Bolsheviks)|RSDLP(b)]] of '''[[Southwestern Krai]]''' and '''Donets-Krivoi Rog Basin''' and later in the fall the bureau of the RSDLP(b) military organizations of the '''[[Southwestern Front (Russian Empire)|Southwestern Front]]'''<ref name=useyk/> (due to ongoing [[World War I]]). Also membership of the party in Ukraine grew significantly in 1917 from 7,000 in April to 50,000 in October.<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> Following the [[October Revolution|Bolshevik coup-d'état]] in [[Petrograd]], at the [[All-Russian Congress of Soviets#Second Congress|2nd All-Russian Congress of Soviets]] among its delegates, there were 65 Bolsheviks from Ukraine.<ref name=useyk/>
+Following the "[[July Days]]" and the semi-legal [[6th Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]], Bolsheviks of Ukraine began to prepare the workers for an armed uprising "for the [[Soviet regime]]" ({{lang-uk|за владу Рад}}, {{lang-ru|за власть Советов}}).<ref name=useyk/> Big help was provided to them by the Central Committee of the RSDLP(b) that maintained connection with more than 50 of its party organizations in Ukraine.<ref name=useyk/> Active role in the preparation process of the masses to the "Socialist Revolution" ([[October Revolution]]) was conducted by [[Vasiliy Averin]], [[Yevgenia Bosch]], [[Kliment Voroshilov]], [[Yan Gamarnik]], [[Serafima Hopner|Serafima Gopner]], [[Volodymyr Zatonsky|Vladimir Zatonsky]], [[Andriy Ivanov|Andrei Ivanov]], [[Emanuel Kviring]], [[Yuriy Kotsiubynsky]], [[Dmitriy Lebed]], [[Grigory Petrovsky]], [[Vitaly Primakov]], [[Fyodor Sergeyev]], [[Ivan Smirnov]], and others.<ref name=useyk/> During the summer of 1917 on territory of modern Ukraine were formed two regional (oblast) branches of the [[Russian Social Democratic Labour Party (Bolsheviks)|RSDLP(b)]] of '''[[Southwestern Krai]]''' and '''Donets-Krivoi Rog Basin''' and later in the fall the bureau of the RSDLP(b) military organizations of the '''[[Southwestern Front (Russian Empire)|Southwestern Front]]'''<ref name=useyk/> (due to ongoing [[World War I]]). Originally the regional branch of the RSDLP(b) was supposed to consist of 7 guberniyas (Governorates): Kiev, Chernigov, Podolia, Volhynia, Poltava, Kherson, and Yekaterinoslav.<ref>[[Yevgenia Bosch]]. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=PrY2CwAAQBAJ&pg=PT272&lpg=PT272&dq=%D0%9A%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9+%D0%92%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BD%D0%BE-%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8E%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9+%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%82+%D0%B1%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8C%D1%88%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B2&source=bl&ots=gIN_rGd2ae&sig=ACfU3U3Oqq-PFkkbWoU_0e2gzSPimId_pA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwiOibf7peThAhUT7FQKHcDDBmoQ6AEwBnoECAkQAQ#v=onepage&q=%D0%9A%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9%20%D0%92%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BD%D0%BE-%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8E%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9%20%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%82%20%D0%B1%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8C%D1%88%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B2&f=false Years of Struggle. The struggle for power in Ukraine from April of 1917 to the German occupation (Год борьбы: борьба за власть на Украине с апреля 1917 г. до немецкой оккупации)].'' (Chapter 2. Regional branch of the RSDLP(b) of the South-western Krai). Directmedia, 2015. (page 22)</ref> Also membership of the party in Ukraine grew significantly in 1917 from 7,000 in April to 50,000 in October.<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> Following the [[October Revolution|Bolshevik coup-d'état]] in [[Petrograd]], at the [[All-Russian Congress of Soviets#Second Congress|2nd All-Russian Congress of Soviets]] among its delegates, there were 65 Bolsheviks from Ukraine.<ref name=useyk/>
 
 {{Campaignbox Bolshevik Uprisings in Ukraine}}
 The very next day after the Petrograd's coup-d'état, on 8–13 November (26–31 October by old style), 1917 Bolsheviks headquartered at the [[Mariyinsky Palace]] attempted to [[Kiev Bolshevik Uprising|secure power in Kiev]] with less success and, after the Bolshevik's victory, the authority in Kiev was secured by the [[Regional Committee in Protection of Revolution in Ukraine]] where important role played the [[Central Council of Ukraine]]. In a week the Central Council adopted its "Third [[Universal (act)|Universal]]" where it condemned the Bolshevik coup-d'état and declared Ukraine in federative union with the [[Russian Republic]] (instead of the [[Soviet Russia]]). In response to that on 26 November 1917 the Bolshevik [[Sovnarkom]] published its [[manifesto]] to the all population "[https://web.archive.org/web/20190422174556/http://istmat.info/node/27999 About struggle with counter-revolutionary insurgency of Kaledin, Kornilov, Dutov, and supported by the Central Rada (О борьбе с контрреволюционным восстанием Каледина, Корнилова, Дутова, поддерживаемым Центральной Радой)]".

-During the 1917 [[February Revolution]], known as the February bourgeois democratic revolution in communist jargon, the Bolshevik organizations guided by the Central Committee of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party claimed that they led the struggle of the working people against [[Russian autocracy]], and after overthrowing it launched a struggle for the masses against whom communists named as conciliators and bourgeois nationalists.<ref name=useyk/> The process of differentiation of the Bolsheviks and the Mensheviks in the joint organizations of the RSDLP intensified and as well as the process of creation of independent Bolshevik organizations that on July 1917 accounted for around 33,000 men.<ref name=useyk/>{{efn|name=estimation}}
+During the 1917 [[February Revolution]], known as the February bourgeois democratic revolution in communist jargon, the Bolshevik organizations guided by the Central Committee of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party claimed that they led the struggle of the working people against [[Russian autocracy]], and after overthrowing it launched a struggle for the masses against whom communists named as conciliators and bourgeois nationalists.<ref name=useyk/> The process of differentiation of the Bolsheviks and the Mensheviks in the joint organizations of the RSDLP intensified and as well as the process of creation of independent Bolshevik organizations that on July 1917 accounted for around 33,000 men.<ref name=useyk/>{{efn|name=estimation}} According to [[Yevgenia Bosch]], the Kiev party organization after the February Revolution accounted for only near 200 members.{{efn|Bosch, Ye., page 11}}
 
 ===Struggle for establishment of the Soviet regime in Ukraine===
 Following the "[[July Days]]" and the semi-legal [[6th Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]], Bolsheviks of Ukraine began to prepare the workers for an armed uprising "for the [[Soviet regime]]" ({{lang-uk|за владу Рад}}, {{lang-ru|за власть Советов}}).<ref name=useyk/> Big help was provided to them by the Central Committee of the RSDLP(b) that maintained connection with more than 50 of its party organizations in Ukraine.<ref name=useyk/> Active role in the preparation process of the masses to the "Socialist Revolution" ([[October Revolution]]) was conducted by [[Vasiliy Averin]], [[Yevgenia Bosch]], [[Kliment Voroshilov]], [[Yan Gamarnik]], [[Serafima Hopner|Serafima Gopner]], [[Volodymyr Zatonsky|Vladimir Zatonsky]], [[Andriy Ivanov|Andrei Ivanov]], [[Emanuel Kviring]], [[Yuriy Kotsiubynsky]], [[Dmitriy Lebed]], [[Grigory Petrovsky]], [[Vitaly Primakov]], [[Fyodor Sergeyev]], [[Ivan Smirnov]], and others.<ref name=useyk/> During the summer of 1917 on territory of modern Ukraine were formed two regional (oblast) branches of the [[Russian Social Democratic Labour Party (Bolsheviks)|RSDLP(b)]] of '''[[Southwestern Krai]]''' and '''Donets-Krivoi Rog Basin''' and later in the fall the bureau of the RSDLP(b) military organizations of the '''[[Southwestern Front (Russian Empire)|Southwestern Front]]'''<ref name=useyk/> (due to ongoing [[World War I]]). According to [[Yevgenia Bosch]], the regional branch of the RSDLP(b) was supposed to consist of 7 guberniyas (Governorates): Kiev, Chernigov, Podolia, Volhynia, Poltava, Kherson, and Yekaterinoslav.{{efn|name=bosch|Bosch, Ye., page 22}} Also membership of the party in Ukraine grew significantly in 1917 from 7,000 in April to 50,000 in October.<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> Following the [[October Revolution|Bolshevik coup-d'état]] in [[Petrograd]], at the [[All-Russian Congress of Soviets#Second Congress|2nd All-Russian Congress of Soviets]] among its delegates, there were 65 Bolsheviks from Ukraine.<ref name=useyk/>

According to [[Yevgenia Bosch]], the regional branch of the RSDLP(b) was supposed to consist of 7 guberniyas (Governorates): Kiev, Chernigov, Podolia, Volhynia, Poltava, Kherson, and Yekaterinoslav.{{efn|name=bosch|Bosch, Ye., page 22}} Also membership of the party in Ukraine grew significantly in 1917 from 7,000 in April to 50,000 in October.<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> Following the [[October Revolution|Bolshevik coup-d'état]] in [[Petrograd]], at the [[All-Russian Congress of Soviets#Second Congress|2nd All-Russian Congress of Soviets]] among its delegates, there were 65 Bolsheviks from Ukraine.<ref name=useyk/>
 
 {{Campaignbox Bolshevik Uprisings in Ukraine}}
 The very next day after the Petrograd's coup-d'état, on 8–13 November (26–31 October by old style), 1917 Bolsheviks headquartered at the [[Mariyinsky Palace]] attempted to [[Kiev Bolshevik Uprising|secure power in Kiev]] with less success and, after the Bolshevik's victory, the authority in Kiev was secured by the [[Regional Committee in Protection of Revolution in Ukraine]] where important role played the [[Central Council of Ukraine]]. In a week the Central Council adopted its "Third [[Universal (act)|Universal]]" where it condemned the Bolshevik coup-d'état and declared Ukraine in federative union with the [[Russian Republic]] (instead of the [[Soviet Russia]]). In response to that on 26 November 1917 the Bolshevik [[Sovnarkom]] published its [[manifesto]] to the all population "[https://web.archive.org/web/20190422174556/http://istmat.info/node/27999 About struggle with counter-revolutionary insurgency of Kaledin, Kornilov, Dutov, and supported by the Central Rada (О борьбе с контрреволюционным восстанием Каледина, Корнилова, Дутова, поддерживаемым Центральной Радой)]".

 During the [[1905 Russian Revolution]] Bolsheviks in Ukraine guided by decisions of the 3rd Congress led working people to fight against autocracy.<ref name=useyk/> In more than 50 cities and settlements were created Soviets of working deputies.<ref name=useyk/> In December of 1905 Bolsheviks led number of armed uprisings in Ukraine, among which were in [[Horlivka]], Alexandrovsk ([[Zaporizhia]]), [[Kharkiv]].<ref name=useyk/> Kiev, Mykolaiv and many other cities were covered with [[strike action]].<ref name=useyk/> In course of the revolution the RSDLP organizations in Ukraine grew significantly and in 1907 they were accounted for over 20,000 men.<ref name=useyk/>{{efn|name=estimation|Due to [[russification of Ukraine]], the [[Ukrainian Soviet Encyclopedia]] does not differentiate between two homonymic words in both languages (Russian and Ukrainian) that have different semantics. The Russian word for people "chelovek" ({{lang-ru|человек}}) looks as it was adopted in Ukrainian here as <u>[male]</u> men "cholovik" ({{lang-uk|чоловік}}). Given estimation for men, possibly includes estimation for people in whole.}} Organizers and leaders
 of party's activities during this time were Comrade Artyom ([[Fyodor Sergeev]]), [[Vladimir Bonch-Bruyevich]], [[Miron Vladimirov]], [[Kliment Voroshilov]], [[Serafima Hopner|Serafima Gopner]], [[Sergey Ivanovich Gusev|Sergey Gusev]], [[Lidia Knipovich]], [[Gleb Krzhizhanovsky]], [[Grigory Petrovsky]], [[Mykola Skrypnyk|Nikolay Skripnik]], [[Alexander Schlichter]], [[Yemelyan Yaroslavsky]], and others.<ref name=useyk/> During the following year of government reaction in 1907–10 Bolshevik organizations in Ukraine have suffered significant losses, yet continued their revolutionary activities.<ref name=useyk/> Guided by decisions of the 1912 [[Prague Conference]], those Bolsheviks carried out work to expand and strengthen ties with the masses, their international upbringing, preparing workers to new revolutionary battles, were exposing supporters of what was labeled as "[[liquidationism]]", "otzovizm" (recalling representatives from the State Duma), [[trotskyism]] and [[bourgeois nationalism]].<ref name=useyk/> During the years of [[World War I]] (1914–18) the Bolsheviks of Ukraine propagated the Lenin's slogan of transforming the [[imperialist war]]<ref>Brian Becker. ''[https://liberationschool.org/from-inter-imperialist-war-to-global-class-war-understanding-distinct-stages-of-imperialism/ From inter-imperialist war to global class war: Understanding distinct stages of imperialism]''. +During the 1917 [[February Revolution]], known as the February bourgeois democratic revolution in communist jargon, the Bolshevik organizations guided by the Central Committee of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party claimed that they led the struggle of the working people against [[Russian autocracy]], and after overthrowing it launched a struggle for the masses against whom communists named as conciliators and bourgeois nationalists.<ref name=useyk/> The process of differentiation of the Bolsheviks and the Mensheviks in the joint organizations of the RSDLP intensified and as well as the process of creation of independent Bolshevik organizations that on July 1917 accounted for around 33,000 men.<ref name=useyk/>{{efn|name=estimation}} 
+
+According to [[Yevgenia Bosch]], the Kiev party organization after the February Revolution accounted for only near 200 members{{efn|name=bosch11|Bosch, Ye., page 11}} and it mainly was concentrated on elections to the Council of Workers' Deputies.{{efn|name=bosch11}} The performance of the party organization was far from stellar and huge advantage in the council was secured by what Bosch called "petty bourgeois parties".{{efn|name=bosch11}} The majority in the council was formed by [[Mesheviks]].{{efn|name=bosch11}} The council's executive committee (ispolkom) was also dominated by Mesheviks and Bundists, while Bolsheviks managed to have own representative Maks Savelyev.{{efn|name=bosch11}} The Kiev party organization chose not to participate in elections to the Council of Soldiers' Deputies due to lack of relations with local military.{{efn|name=bosch11}}
 
 ===Struggle for establishment of the Soviet regime in Ukraine===
 Following the "[[July Days]]" and the semi-legal [[6th Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]], Bolsheviks of Ukraine began to prepare the workers for an armed uprising "for the [[Soviet regime]]" ({{lang-uk|за владу Рад}}, {{lang-ru|за власть Советов}}).<ref name=useyk/> Big help was provided to them by the Central Committee of the RSDLP(b) that maintained connection with more than 50 of its party organizations in Ukraine.<ref name=useyk/> Active role in the preparation process of the masses to the "Socialist Revolution" ([[October Revolution]]) was conducted by [[Vasiliy Averin]], [[Yevgenia Bosch]], [[Kliment Voroshilov]], [[Yan Gamarnik]], [[Serafima Hopner|Serafima Gopner]], [[Volodymyr Zatonsky|Vladimir Zatonsky]], [[Andriy Ivanov|Andrei Ivanov]], [[Emanuel Kviring]], [[Yuriy Kotsiubynsky]], [[Dmitriy Lebed]], [[Grigory Petrovsky]], [[Vitaly Primakov]], [[Fyodor Sergeyev]], [[Ivan Smirnov]], and others.<ref name=useyk/> During the summer of 1917 on territory of modern Ukraine were formed two regional (oblast) branches of the [[Russian Social Democratic Labour Party (Bolsheviks)|RSDLP(b)]] of '''[[Southwestern Krai]]''' and '''Donets-Krivoi Rog Basin''' and later in the fall the bureau of the RSDLP(b) military organizations of the '''[[Southwestern Front (Russian Empire)|Southwestern Front]]'''<ref name=useyk/> (due to ongoing [[World War I]]). According to [[Yevgenia Bosch]], the regional branch of the RSDLP(b) was supposed to consist of 7 guberniyas (Governorates): Kiev, Chernigov, Podolia, Volhynia, Poltava, Kherson, and Yekaterinoslav.{{efn|name=bosch|Bosch, Ye., page 22}} Also membership of the party in Ukraine grew significantly in 1917 from 7,000 in April to 50,000 in October.<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> Following the [[October Revolution|Bolshevik coup-d'état]] in [[Petrograd]], at the [[All-Russian Congress of Soviets#Second Congress|2nd All-Russian Congress of Soviets]] among its delegates, there were 65 Bolsheviks from Ukraine.<ref name=useyk/>

''[https://books.google.com/books?id=PrY2CwAAQBAJ&pg=PT272&lpg=PT272&dq=%D0%9A%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9+%D0%92%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BD%D0%BE-%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8E%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9+%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%82+%D0%B1%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8C%D1%88%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B2&source=bl&ots=gIN_rGd2ae&sig=ACfU3U3Oqq-PFkkbWoU_0e2gzSPimId_pA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwiOibf7peThAhUT7FQKHcDDBmoQ6AEwBnoECAkQAQ#v=onepage&q=%D0%9A%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9%20%D0%92%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BD%D0%BE-%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8E%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9%20%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%82%20%D0%B1%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8C%D1%88%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B2&f=false Years of Struggle. The struggle for power in Ukraine from April of 1917 to the German occupation (Год борьбы: борьба за власть на Украине с апреля 1917 г. до немецкой оккупации)].'' (Chapter 2. Regional branch of the RSDLP(b) of the South-western Krai). Directmedia, 2015. (page 22)</ref> Also membership of the party in Ukraine grew significantly in 1917 from 7,000 in April to 50,000 in October.<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> Following the [[October Revolution|Bolshevik coup-d'état]] in [[Petrograd]], at the [[All-Russian Congress of Soviets#Second Congress|2nd All-Russian Congress of Soviets]] among its delegates, there were 65 Bolsheviks from Ukraine.<ref name=useyk/>
 
 {{Campaignbox Bolshevik Uprisings in Ukraine}}
 The very next day after the Petrograd's coup-d'état, on 8–13 November (26–31 October by old style), 1917 Bolsheviks headquartered at the [[Mariyinsky Palace]] attempted to [[Kiev Bolshevik Uprising|secure power in Kiev]] with less success and, after the Bolshevik's victory, the authority in Kiev was secured by the [[Regional Committee in Protection of Revolution in Ukraine]] where important role played the [[Central Council of Ukraine]]. In a week the Central Council adopted its "Third [[Universal (act)|Universal]]" where it condemned the Bolshevik coup-d'état and declared Ukraine in federative union with the [[Russian Republic]] (instead of the [[Soviet Russia]]). In response to that on 26 November 1917 the Bolshevik [[Sovnarkom]] published its [[manifesto]] to the all population "[https://web.archive.org/web/20190422174556/http://istmat.info/node/27999 About struggle with counter-revolutionary insurgency of Kaledin, Kornilov, Dutov, and supported by the Central Rada (О борьбе с контрреволюционным восстанием Каледина, Корнилова, Дутова, поддерживаемым Центральной Радой)]".
comment: /* Struggle for establishment of the Soviet regime in Ukraine */
llm_output:
The change made in this revision is the addition of a section titled "Struggle for establishment of the Soviet regime in Ukraine," which includes a detailed description of the Bolshevik preparations for an armed uprising in Ukraine and the involvement of various figures in this process.

Weaponised: Not Weaponised. The content appears to be a historical account of events related to the establishment of the Soviet regime in Ukraine without employing language that overtly weaponizes cultural heritage or promotes a specific narrative.

Changed the text by adding a sentence about the Kiev Bolsheviks ignoring the All-Ukrainian National Congress.

Not Weaponised. The addition provides historical context without employing weaponisation terms or narratives that could be seen as politically charged or divisive.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -45,6 +45,8 @@
 
 According to [[Yevgenia Bosch]], the Kiev party organization after the February Revolution accounted for only near 200 members{{efn|name=bosch11|Bosch, Ye., page 11}} and it mainly was concentrated on elections to the Soviet of Workers' Deputies.{{efn|name=bosch11}} The performance of the party organization was far from stellar and huge advantage in the soviet (council) was secured by what Bosch called "petty bourgeois parties".{{efn|name=bosch11}} The majority in the soviet was formed by [[Mensheviks]].{{efn|name=bosch11}} The soviet's executive committee ([[ispolkom]]) was also dominated by Mensheviks and [[Bundists]], while Bolsheviks managed to have own representative Maks Savelyev.{{efn|name=bosch11}} The Kiev party organization chose not to participate in elections to the Soviet of Soldiers' Deputies due to lack of relations with local military.{{efn|name=bosch11}} Also the Kiev Bolsheviks chose to ignore the [[All-Ukrainian National Congress]] that was convened on proposition of the [[Central Council of Ukraine]] on {{OldStyleDate|18 – 20 April|1917|5 – 7 April}}.{{efn|name=bosch12|Bosch, Ye., page 12}} The most important role for the organization was participation in the [[International Workers' Day|1 May]] street demonstration to the point that the Bolsheviks decided to conducted own one in spite that the event was already organized by the Soviet of Workers' Deputies.{{efn|name=bosch12}}
 
+Unlike any other Bolshevik organizations in Ukraine that adopted the [[Lenin]]'s [[April Theses]] without discussions, on 28 April 1917 the Kiev party cell approved resolution in which it called the April Theses "yet insufficiently substantiated and developed".<ref name=ehukul2007>Kulchytskyi, S. ''[http://resource.history.org.ua/cgi-bin/eiu/history.exe?Z21ID=&I21DBN=EIU&P21DBN=EIU&S21STN=1&S21REF=10&S21FMT=eiu_all&C21COM=S&S21CNR=20&S21P01=0&S21P02=0&S21P03=TRN=&S21COLORTERMS=0&S21STR=Kvitnevi_tezy_Lenina The Lenin's April Theses (КВІТНЕВІ ТЕЗИ В.ЛЕНІНА)]''. Encyclopedia of History of Ukraine. 2007</ref>
+
 ===Struggle for establishment of the Soviet regime in Ukraine===
 Following the "[[July Days]]" and the semi-legal [[6th Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]], Bolsheviks of Ukraine began to prepare the workers for an armed uprising "for the [[Soviet regime]]" ({{lang-uk|за владу Рад}}, {{lang-ru|за власть Советов}}).<ref name=useyk/> Big help was provided to them by the Central Committee of the RSDLP(b) that maintained connection with more than 50 of its party organizations in Ukraine.<ref name=useyk/> Active role in the preparation process of the masses to the "Socialist Revolution" ([[October Revolution]]) was conducted by [[Vasiliy Averin]], [[Yevgenia Bosch]], [[Kliment Voroshilov]], [[Yan Gamarnik]], [[Serafima Hopner|Serafima Gopner]], [[Volodymyr Zatonsky|Vladimir Zatonsky]], [[Andriy Ivanov|Andrei Ivanov]], [[Emanuel Kviring]], [[Yuriy Kotsiubynsky]], [[Dmitriy Lebed]], [[Grigory Petrovsky]], [[Vitaly Primakov]], [[Fyodor Sergeyev]], [[Ivan Smirnov]], and others.<ref name=useyk/> During the summer of 1917 on territory of modern Ukraine were formed two regional (oblast) branches of the [[Russian Social Democratic Labour Party (Bolsheviks)|RSDLP(b)]] of '''[[Southwestern Krai]]''' and '''Donets-Krivoi Rog Basin''' and later in the fall the bureau of the RSDLP(b) military organizations of the '''[[Southwestern Front (Russian Empire)|Southwestern Front]]'''<ref name=useyk/> (due to ongoing [[World War I]]). According to [[Yevgenia Bosch]], the regional branch of the RSDLP(b) was supposed to consist of 7 guberniyas (Governorates): Kiev, Chernigov, Podolia, Volhynia, Poltava, Kherson, and Yekaterinoslav.{{efn|name=bosch|Bosch, Ye., page 22}} Also membership of the party in Ukraine grew significantly in 1917 from 7,000 in April to 50,000 in October.<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> Following the [[October Revolution|Bolshevik coup-d'état]] in [[Petrograd]], at the [[All-Russian Congress of Soviets#Second Congress|2nd All-Russian Congress of Soviets]] among its delegates, there were 65 Bolsheviks from Ukraine.<ref name=useyk/>

**Not Weaponised**: The change appears to be a formatting adjustment for the date rather than a shift in narrative or perspective that could be considered weaponisation of cultural heritage.

--- +++ @@ -1,4 +1,5 @@ {{for|the post-Soviet party|Communist Party of Ukraine|Communist Party of Ukraine (renewed)}} +{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2019}} {{Infobox Political Party | colorcode = {{Communist Party of Ukraine/meta/color}} | name = Communist Party of Ukraine @@ -8,9 +9,9 @@ | leader1_name = [[Stanislav Hurenko]] {{small|(last)}} | leader2_title = Founder | leader2_name = [[Mykola Skrypnyk]] -| foundation = {{Start date|1918|7|17}} +| foundation = {{Start date|df=yes|1918|7|17}} | dissolution = -| banned = {{End date and age|1991|8|26}} +| banned = {{End date and age|df=yes|1991|8|26}} | predecessor = [[Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] | successor = [[Socialist Party of Ukraine]]
[[Communist Party of Ukraine]] (1993) | slogan = [[Workers of the world, unite!]] @@ -39,7 +40,7 @@ The party traces its beginning to committees and party's cells of the [[Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] (RSDLP) that existed at the end of the 19th century in all bigger cities and industrial centers on Ukrainian territory which was part of the Russian Empire.Yurchuk, V., Kuras, I. ''[http://leksika.com.ua/10441202/ure/komunistichna_partiya_ukrayini Communist Party of Ukraine (КОМУНІСТИЧНА ПАРТІЯ УКРАЇНИ)]''. [[Ukrainian Soviet Encyclopedia]]. Under influence from the [[League of Struggle for the Emancipation of the Working Class]] in [[Saint Petersburg]], in 1897 such organization was also formed in [[Kiev]] and [[Yekaterinoslav]] which also were taking part in preparation and convocation of the [[1st Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] in 1898. With release of newspaper [[Iskra]] in December of 1900 in Germany, on territory of Ukraine spread out a network of the Lenin's Iskra group and organizations. Among the most notable activists in Ukraine during that period were [[Ivan Babushkin]], [[Rosalia Zemlyachka]], [[Pyotr Krasikov]], [[Isaak Lalayants]], [[Friedrichs Lengniks]], [[Maxim Litvinov]], [[Grigory Petrovsky]], [[Mykola Skrypnyk]] (Nikolay Skripnik), [[Dmitry Ilyich Ulyanov|Dmitry Ulyanov]], [[Vasiliy Shelgunov]], [[Alexander Schlichter]], [[Alexander Tsiurupa]], and others. Following the [[2nd Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] (1903) in social-democratic organizations has developed a struggle between Mensheviks and Bolsheviks. On behalf of [[Vladimir Lenin]], in 1904 [[Vatslav Vorovsky]] with Lalayants and Levitskiy created in [[Odessa]] the Southern Bureau of the RSDLP that led activities of Odessa, Yekaterinoslav, Nikolayev committees, brought together around itself Bolshevik organizations of the South, conducted great deal of work in preparation to the [[3rd Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] in 1905. During the [[1905 Russian Revolution]] Bolsheviks in Ukraine guided by decisions of the 3rd Congress led working people to fight against autocracy. In more than 50 cities and settlements were created Soviets of working deputies. In December of 1905 Bolsheviks led number of armed uprisings in Ukraine, among which were in [[Horlivka]], Alexandrovsk ([[Zaporizhia]]), [[Kharkiv]]. Kiev, Mykolaiv and many other cities were covered with [[strike action]]. In course of the revolution the RSDLP organizations in Ukraine grew significantly and in 1907 they were accounted for over 20,000 men.{{efn|name=estimation|Due to [[russification of Ukraine]], the [[Ukrainian Soviet Encyclopedia]] does not differentiate between two homonymic words in both languages (Russian and Ukrainian) that have different semantics. The Russian word for people "chelovek" ({{lang-ru|человек}}) looks as it was adopted in Ukrainian here as [male] men "cholovik" ({{lang-uk|чоловік}}). Given estimation for men, possibly includes estimation for people in whole.}} Organizers and leaders -of party's activities during this time were Comrade Artyom ([[Fyodor Sergeev]]), [[Vladimir Bonch-Bruyevich]], [[Miron Vladimirov]], [[Kliment Voroshilov]], [[Serafima Hopner|Serafima Gopner]], [[Sergey Ivanovich Gusev|Sergey Gusev]], [[Lidia Knipovich]], [[Gleb Krzhizhanovsky]], [[Grigory Petrovsky]], [[Mykola Skrypnyk|Nikolay Skripnik]], [[Alexander Schlichter]], [[Yemelyan Yaroslavsky]], and others. During the following year of government reaction in 1907–10 Bolshevik organizations in Ukraine have suffered significant losses, yet continued their revolutionary activities. Guided by decisions of the 1912 [[Prague Conference]], those Bolsheviks carried out work to expand and strengthen ties with the masses, their international upbringing, preparing workers to new revolutionary battles, were exposing supporters of what was labeled as "[[liquidationism]]", "otzovizm" (recalling representatives from the State Duma), [[trotskyism]] and [[bourgeois nationalism]]. During the years of [[World War I]] (1914–18) the Bolsheviks of Ukraine propagated the Lenin's slogan of transforming the [[imperialist war]]Brian Becker. ''[https://liberationschool.org/from-inter-imperialist-war-to-global-class-war-understanding-distinct-stages-of-imperialism/ From inter-imperialist war to global class war: Understanding distinct stages of imperialism]''. Liberation School. 20 July 2018Mervyn F. Bendle. ''[https://quadrant.org.au/magazine/2014/06/imperialist-war-wasnt/ The Imperialist War That Wasn’t]''. Quadrant Online. 25th June 2014 into a [[civil war]] and fought against [[social chauvinism]] and [[revolutionary defeatism]]. +of party's activities during this time were Comrade Artyom ([[Fyodor Sergeev]]), [[Vladimir Bonch-Bruyevich]], [[Miron Vladimirov]], [[Kliment Voroshilov]], [[Serafima Hopner|Serafima Gopner]], [[Sergey Ivanovich Gusev|Sergey Gusev]], [[Lidia Knipovich]], [[Gleb Krzhizhanovsky]], [[Grigory Petrovsky]], [[Mykola Skrypnyk|Nikolay Skripnik]], [[Alexander Schlichter]], [[Yemelyan Yaroslavsky]], and others. During the following year of government reaction in 1907–10 Bolshevik organizations in Ukraine have suffered significant losses, yet continued their revolutionary activities. Guided by decisions of the 1912 [[Prague Conference]], those Bolsheviks carried out work to expand and strengthen ties with the masses, their international upbringing, preparing workers to new revolutionary battles, were exposing supporters of what was labeled as "[[liquidationism]]", "otzovizm" (recalling representatives from the State Duma), [[trotskyism]] and [[bourgeois nationalism]]. During the years of [[World War I]] (1914–18) the Bolsheviks of Ukraine propagated the Lenin's slogan of transforming the [[imperialist war]]Brian Becker. ''[https://liberationschool.org/from-inter-imperialist-war-to-global-class-war-understanding-distinct-stages-of-imperialism/ From inter-imperialist war to global class war: Understanding distinct stages of imperialism]''. Liberation School. 20 July 2018Mervyn F. Bendle. ''[https://quadrant.org.au/magazine/2014/06/imperialist-war-wasnt/ The Imperialist War That Wasn’t]''. Quadrant Online. 25 June 2014 into a [[civil war]] and fought against [[social chauvinism]] and [[revolutionary defeatism]]. During the 1917 [[February Revolution]], known as the February bourgeois democratic revolution in communist jargon, the Bolshevik organizations guided by the Central Committee of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party claimed that they led the struggle of the working people against [[Russian autocracy]], and after overthrowing it launched a struggle for the masses against whom communists named as conciliators and bourgeois nationalists. The process of differentiation of the Bolsheviks and the Mensheviks in the joint organizations of the RSDLP intensified and as well as the process of creation of independent Bolshevik organizations that on July 1917 accounted for around 33,000 men.{{efn|name=estimation}} @@ -393,7 +394,7 @@ [[Artyom]] (Fyodor Sergeyev), Nikolai Beschetvertnoi, Shulim Gruzman ===Third Congress, March 1919=== -This congress took place in Kharkov. A new central committee with a majority of [[Left communism|Left Communists]] was elected. This prompted the [[8th Congress of the Russian Communist Party (Bolsheviks)|Eight Congress]] of the [[Russian Communist Party (Bolsheviks)|Russian Communist Party]] to pass the following motion: ""It is necessary to have a unified communist party with a unified central committee ... All decisions of the RCP and its leading organs are absolutely binding for all parts of the party, independent of their national composition. The central committees of the Ukrainian, Lettish and Lithuanian communists are conferred the rights of regional committees of the party; they are to be unreservedly subordinate to the central committee of the RCP."[http://www.whatnextjournal.co.uk/pages/theory/Hollis.html The Self-Determination of Nations: The Theory and Practice (Ukraine and Georgia)] by Annette Franz and Dave Hollis accessed 24 January 2011 +This congress took place in Kharkov. A new central committee with a majority of [[Left communism|Left Communists]] was elected. This prompted the [[8th Congress of the Russian Communist Party (Bolsheviks)|Eight Congress]] of the [[Russian Communist Party (Bolsheviks)|Russian Communist Party]] to pass the following motion: "It is necessary to have a unified communist party with a unified central committee ... All decisions of the RCP and its leading organs are absolutely binding for all parts of the party, independent of their national composition. The central committees of the Ukrainian, Lettish and Lithuanian communists are conferred the rights of regional committees of the party; they are to be unreservedly subordinate to the central committee of the RCP."[http://www.whatnextjournal.co.uk/pages/theory/Hollis.html The Self-Determination of Nations: The Theory and Practice (Ukraine and Georgia)] by Annette Franz and Dave Hollis accessed 24 January 2011 ===Fourth Congress, March 17–23, 1920=== The [[Borotbists]] were forced to dissolve themselves and their erstwhile members were permitted to join the CP(b)U.[http://www.marxists.org/archive/lenin/works/1920/feb/06b.htm Draft Resolution on the Ukrainian Borotbist Party (Notes)] accessed 24 January 2011 Vasyl Ellan-Blakytny and Shumsky drawn from the Borotbist leadership were elected to the Committee and the Borotbist Central Committee passed a resolution dissolving the Borotbist party and its central committee. All members were instructed to apply for CP(B)U membership. Nearly 4,000 out of approximately 5,000 Borotbists were admitted to the CP(B)U.[http://www.day.kiev.ua/258303/ A great experiment`; Towards the history of national communism in Ukraine] By James Mace, accessed 24 January 2011

@@ -40,7 +40,7 @@
 The party traces its beginning to committees and party's cells of the [[Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] (RSDLP) that existed at the end of the 19th century in all bigger cities and industrial centers on Ukrainian territory which was part of the Russian Empire.<ref name=useyk>Yurchuk, V., Kuras, I. ''[http://leksika.com.ua/10441202/ure/komunistichna_partiya_ukrayini Communist Party of Ukraine (КОМУНІСТИЧНА ПАРТІЯ УКРАЇНИ)]''. [[Ukrainian Soviet Encyclopedia]].</ref><ref name=eoupyrih2007/> Under influence from the [[League of Struggle for the Emancipation of the Working Class]] in [[Saint Petersburg]], in 1897 such organization was also formed in [[Kiev]] and [[Yekaterinoslav]] which also were taking part in preparation and convocation of the [[1st Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] in 1898.<ref name=useyk/> With release of newspaper [[Iskra]] in December of 1900 in Germany, on territory of Ukraine spread out a network of the Lenin's Iskra group and organizations.<ref name=useyk/> Among the most notable activists in Ukraine during that period were [[Ivan Babushkin]], [[Rosalia Zemlyachka]], [[Pyotr Krasikov]], [[Isaak Lalayants]], [[Friedrichs Lengniks]], [[Maxim Litvinov]], [[Grigory Petrovsky]], [[Mykola Skrypnyk]] (Nikolay Skripnik), [[Dmitry Ilyich Ulyanov|Dmitry Ulyanov]], [[Vasiliy Shelgunov]], [[Alexander Schlichter]], [[Alexander Tsiurupa]], and others.<ref name=useyk/> Following the [[2nd Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] (1903) in social-democratic organizations has developed a struggle between Mensheviks and Bolsheviks.<ref name=useyk/> On behalf of [[Vladimir Lenin]], in 1904 [[Vatslav Vorovsky]] with Lalayants and Levitskiy created in [[Odessa]] the Southern Bureau of the RSDLP that led activities of Odessa, Yekaterinoslav, Nikolayev committees, brought together around itself Bolshevik organizations of the South, conducted great deal of work in preparation to the [[3rd Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] in 1905.<ref name=useyk/>
 
 During the [[1905 Russian Revolution]] Bolsheviks in Ukraine guided by decisions of the 3rd Congress led working people to fight against autocracy.<ref name=useyk/> In more than 50 cities and settlements were created Soviets of working deputies.<ref name=useyk/> In December of 1905 Bolsheviks led number of armed uprisings in Ukraine, among which were in [[Horlivka]], Alexandrovsk ([[Zaporizhia]]), [[Kharkiv]].<ref name=useyk/> Kiev, Mykolaiv and many other cities were covered with [[strike action]].<ref name=useyk/> In course of the revolution the RSDLP organizations in Ukraine grew significantly and in 1907 they were accounted for over 20,000 men.<ref name=useyk/>{{efn|name=estimation|Due to [[russification of Ukraine]], the [[Ukrainian Soviet Encyclopedia]] does not differentiate between two homonymic words in both languages (Russian and Ukrainian) that have different semantics. The Russian word for people "chelovek" ({{lang-ru|человек}}) looks as it was adopted in Ukrainian here as <u>[male]</u> men "cholovik" ({{lang-uk|чоловік}}). Given estimation for men, possibly includes estimation for people in whole.}} Organizers and leaders
-of party's activities during this time were Comrade Artyom ([[Fyodor Sergeev]]), [[Vladimir Bonch-Bruyevich]], [[Miron Vladimirov]], [[Kliment Voroshilov]], [[Serafima Hopner|Serafima Gopner]], [[Sergey Ivanovich Gusev|Sergey Gusev]], [[Lidia Knipovich]], [[Gleb Krzhizhanovsky]], [[Grigory Petrovsky]], [[Mykola Skrypnyk|Nikolay Skripnik]], [[Alexander Schlichter]], [[Yemelyan Yaroslavsky]], and others.<ref name=useyk/> During the following year of government reaction in 1907–10 Bolshevik organizations in Ukraine have suffered significant losses, yet continued their revolutionary activities.<ref name=useyk/> Guided by decisions of the 1912 [[Prague Conference]], those Bolsheviks carried out work to expand and strengthen ties with the masses, their international upbringing, preparing workers to new revolutionary battles, were exposing supporters of what was labeled as "[[liquidationism]]", "otzovizm" (recalling representatives from the State Duma), [[trotskyism]] and [[bourgeois nationalism]].<ref name=useyk/> During the years of [[World War I]] (1914–18) the Bolsheviks of Ukraine propagated the Lenin's slogan of transforming the [[imperialist war]]<ref>Brian Becker. ''[https://liberationschool.org/from-inter-imperialist-war-to-global-class-war-understanding-distinct-stages-of-imperialism/ From inter-imperialist war to global class war: Understanding distinct stages of imperialism]''. Liberation School. 20 July 2018</ref><ref>Mervyn F. Bendle. ''[https://quadrant.org.au/magazine/2014/06/imperialist-war-wasnt/ The Imperialist War That Wasn’t]''. Quadrant Online. 25 June 2014</ref> into a [[civil war]] and fought against [[social chauvinism]] and [[revolutionary defeatism]].<ref name=useyk/>
+of party's activities during this time were Comrade Artyom ([[Fyodor Sergeev]]), [[Vladimir Bonch-Bruyevich]], [[Miron Vladimirov]], [[Kliment Voroshilov]], [[Serafima Hopner|Serafima Gopner]], [[Sergey Ivanovich Gusev|Sergey Gusev]], [[Lidia Knipovich]], [[Gleb Krzhizhanovsky]], [[Grigory Petrovsky]], [[Mykola Skrypnyk|Nikolay Skripnik]], [[Alexander Schlichter]], [[Yemelyan Yaroslavsky]], and others.<ref name=useyk/> During the following year of government reaction in 1907–10 Bolshevik organizations in Ukraine have suffered significant losses, yet continued their revolutionary activities.<ref name=useyk/> Guided by decisions of the 1912 [[Prague Conference]], those Bolsheviks carried out work to expand and strengthen ties with the masses, their international upbringing, preparing workers to new revolutionary battles, were exposing supporters of what was labeled as "[[liquidationism]]", "otzovizm" (recalling representatives from the State Duma), [[trotskyism]] and [[bourgeois nationalism]].<ref name=useyk/> During the years of [[World War I]] (1914–18) the Bolsheviks of Ukraine propagated the Lenin's slogan of transforming the [[imperialist war]]<ref>Brian Becker. ''[https://liberationschool.org/from-inter-imperialist-war-to-global-class-war-understanding-distinct-stages-of-imperialism/ From inter-imperialist war to global class war: Understanding distinct stages of imperialism]''. Liberation School. 20 July 2018</ref> into a [[civil war]] and fought against [[social chauvinism]] and [[revolutionary defeatism]].<ref name=useyk/>
 
 During the 1917 [[February Revolution]], known as the February bourgeois democratic revolution in communist jargon, the Bolshevik organizations guided by the Central Committee of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party claimed that they led the struggle of the working people against [[Russian autocracy]], and after overthrowing it launched a struggle for the masses against whom communists named as conciliators and bourgeois nationalists.<ref name=useyk/> The process of differentiation of the Bolsheviks and the Mensheviks in the joint organizations of the RSDLP intensified and as well as the process of creation of independent Bolshevik organizations that on July 1917 accounted for around 33,000 men.<ref name=useyk/>{{efn|name=estimation}}

@@ -50,7 +50,7 @@
 Following the "[[July Days]]" and the semi-legal [[6th Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]], Bolsheviks of Ukraine began to prepare the workers for an armed uprising "for the [[Soviet regime]]" ({{lang-uk|за владу Рад}}, {{lang-ru|за власть Советов}}).<ref name=useyk/> Big help was provided to them by the Central Committee of the RSDLP(b) that maintained connection with more than 50 of its party organizations in Ukraine.<ref name=useyk/> Active role in the preparation process of the masses to the "Socialist Revolution" ([[October Revolution]]) was conducted by [[Vasiliy Averin]], [[Yevgenia Bosch]], [[Kliment Voroshilov]], [[Yan Gamarnik]], [[Serafima Hopner|Serafima Gopner]], [[Volodymyr Zatonsky|Vladimir Zatonsky]], [[Andriy Ivanov|Andrei Ivanov]], [[Emanuel Kviring]], [[Yuriy Kotsiubynsky]], [[Dmitriy Lebed]], [[Grigory Petrovsky]], [[Vitaly Primakov]], [[Fyodor Sergeyev]], {{ill|Ivan Fyodorovich Smirnov|lt=Ivan Smirnov|ru|Смирнов, Иван Фёдорович|uk|Смирнов Іван Федорович}}, and others.<ref name=useyk/> During the summer of 1917 on territory of modern Ukraine were formed two regional (oblast) branches of the [[Russian Social Democratic Labour Party (Bolsheviks)|RSDLP(b)]] of '''[[Southwestern Krai]]''' and '''Donets-Krivoi Rog Basin''' and later in the fall the bureau of the RSDLP(b) military organizations of the '''[[Southwestern Front (Russian Empire)|Southwestern Front]]'''<ref name=useyk/> (due to ongoing [[World War I]]). According to [[Yevgenia Bosch]], the regional branch of the RSDLP(b) was supposed to consist of 7 guberniyas (Governorates): Kiev, Chernigov, Podolia, Volhynia, Poltava, Kherson, and Yekaterinoslav.{{efn|name=bosch|Bosch, Ye., page 22}} Also membership of the party in Ukraine grew significantly in 1917 from 7,000 in April to 50,000 in October.<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> Following the [[October Revolution|Bolshevik coup-d'état]] in [[Petrograd]], at the [[All-Russian Congress of Soviets#Second Congress|2nd All-Russian Congress of Soviets]] among its delegates, there were 65 Bolsheviks from Ukraine.<ref name=useyk/>
 
 {{Campaignbox Bolshevik Uprisings in Ukraine}}
-The very next day after the Petrograd's coup-d'état, on 8–13 November (26–31 October by old style), 1917 Bolsheviks headquartered at the [[Mariyinsky Palace]] attempted to [[Kiev Bolshevik Uprising|secure power in Kiev]] with less success and, after the Bolshevik's victory, the authority in Kiev was secured by the [[Regional Committee in Protection of Revolution in Ukraine]] where important role played the [[Central Council of Ukraine]]. In a week the Central Council adopted its "Third [[Universal (act)|Universal]]" where it condemned the Bolshevik coup-d'état and declared Ukraine in federative union with the [[Russian Republic]] (instead of the [[Soviet Russia]]). In response to that on 26 November 1917 the Bolshevik [[Sovnarkom]] published its [[manifesto]] to the all population "[https://web.archive.org/web/20190422174556/http://istmat.info/node/27999 About struggle with counter-revolutionary insurgency of Kaledin, Kornilov, Dutov, and supported by the Central Rada (О борьбе с контрреволюционным восстанием Каледина, Корнилова, Дутова, поддерживаемым Центральной Радой)]".
+The very next day after the Petrograd's coup-d'état, on 8–13 November (26–31 October by old style), 1917 Bolsheviks in Kiev, who have been headquartered at the [[Mariyinsky Palace]], attempted to [[Kiev Bolshevik Uprising|secure power in Kiev]] with less success and, after the Bolshevik's victory over the Kiev Military District garrison, the authority in Kiev was secured by the [[Regional Committee in Protection of Revolution in Ukraine]] where important role played the [[Central Council of Ukraine]]. In a week the Central Council adopted its "Third [[Universal (act)|Universal]]" where it condemned the Bolshevik coup-d'état and declared Ukraine in federative union with the [[Russian Republic]] (instead of the [[Soviet Russia]]). In response to that on 26 November 1917 the Bolshevik [[Sovnarkom]] published its [[manifesto]] to the all population "[https://web.archive.org/web/20190422174556/http://istmat.info/node/27999 About struggle with counter-revolutionary insurgency of Kaledin, Kornilov, Dutov, and supported by the Central Rada (О борьбе с контрреволюционным восстанием Каледина, Корнилова, Дутова, поддерживаемым Центральной Радой)]".
 
 ===Communist Party of Ukraine===
 The Communist Party (Bolsheviks) of Ukraine was created in July 1918 in Moscow.

On 26 August 1991 the Presidium of the Verkhovna Rada (Ukrainian parliament) suspended and on 30 August 1991 prohibited the Communist Party of Ukraine based on the fact that "the leadership of the Communist Party of Ukraine in its actions supported the [[1991 Soviet coup d'état attempt|coup d'état]]" [in [[Moscow]]].Pyrih, R. ''[http://esu.com.ua/search_articles.php?id=4431 Communist Party of Ukraine of Soviet period (Комуністична партія України Радянської доби)]''. Encyclopedia of Modern Ukraine. Based on parliamentary faction of the Communist Party following its 1991 prohibition, there was created the [[Socialist Party of Ukraine]]. On efforts of some other communists who did not join the Socialist Party, in 1993 in [[Donetsk]] was re-established the [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] soon after the [[Union of Communist Parties – Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] in [[Moscow]]. Some members who joined Socialist Party, after re-establishing of the Communist Party, joined the new political entity among which the most notable was [[Adam Martyniuk]]. Following sanctions against the party in 1991, the party fell apart in similar way as its parent organization (the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]]) having members of such main deviations like Democratic Platform and Interregional Deputy group reorganized into separate political entities. @@ -34,13 +35,14 @@ ==Historical overview== {{see also|Ukrainian People's Republic of Soviets|All-Ukrainian Congress of Soviets}} + ===Russian Bolsheviks in Ukraine=== -The party traces its beginning to committees and party's cells of the [[Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] (RSDLP) that existed at the end of the 19th century in all bigger cities and industrial centers on Ukrainian territory which was part of the Russian Empire.Yurchuk, V., Kuras, I. ''[http://leksika.com.ua/10441202/ure/komunistichna_partiya_ukrayini Communist Party of Ukraine (КОМУНІСТИЧНА ПАРТІЯ УКРАЇНИ)]''. [[Ukrainian Soviet Encyclopedia]]. Under influence from the [[League of Struggle for the Emancipation of the Working Class]] in [[Saint Petersburg]], in 1897 such organization was also formed in [[Kiev]] and [[Yekaterinoslav]] which also were taking part in preparation and convocation of the [[1st Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] in 1898. With release of newspaper [[Iskra]] in December of 1900 in Germany, on territory of Ukraine spread out a network of the Lenin's Iskra group and organizations. Among the most notable activists in Ukraine during that period were [[Ivan Babushkin]], [[Rosalia Zemlyachka]], [[Pyotr Krasikov]], [[Isaak Lalayants]], [[Friedrichs Lengniks]], [[Maxim Litvinov]], [[Grigory Petrovsky]], [[Mykola Skrypnyk]] (Nikolay Skripnik), [[Dmitry Ilyich Ulyanov|Dmitry Ulyanov]], [[Vasiliy Shelgunov]], [[Alexander Schlichter]], [[Alexander Tsiurupa]], and others. Following the [[2nd Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] (1903) in social-democratic organizations has developed a struggle between Mensheviks and Bolsheviks. On behalf of [[Vladimir Lenin]], in 1904 [[Vatslav Vorovsky]] with Lalayants and Levitskiy created in [[Odessa]] the Southern Bureau of the RSDLP that led activities of Odessa, Yekaterinoslav, Nikolayev committees, brought together around itself Bolshevik organizations of the South, conducted great deal of work in preparation to the [[3rd Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] in 1905. - -During the [[1905 Russian Revolution]] Bolsheviks in Ukraine guided by decisions of the 3rd Congress led working people to fight against autocracy. In more than 50 cities and settlements were created Soviets of working deputies. In December of 1905 Bolsheviks led number of armed uprisings in Ukraine, among which were in [[Horlivka]], Alexandrovsk ([[Zaporizhia]]), [[Kharkiv]]. Kiev, Mykolaiv and many other cities were covered with [[strike action]]. In course of the revolution the RSDLP organizations in Ukraine grew significantly and in 1907 they were accounted for over 20,000 men.{{efn|name=estimation|Due to [[russification of Ukraine]], the [[Ukrainian Soviet Encyclopedia]] does not differentiate between two homonymic words in both languages (Russian and Ukrainian) that have different semantics. Following the [[2nd Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] (1903) in social-democratic organizations has developed a struggle between Mensheviks and Bolsheviks. On behalf of [[Vladimir Lenin]], in 1904 [[Vatslav Vorovsky]] with Lalayants and Levitskiy created in [[Odessa]] the Southern Bureau of the RSDLP that led activities of Odessa, Yekaterinoslav, Nikolayev committees, brought together around itself Bolshevik organizations of the South, conducted great deal of work in preparation to the [[3rd Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] in 1905. + +During the [[1905 Russian Revolution]] Bolsheviks in Ukraine guided by decisions of the 3rd Congress led working people to fight against autocracy. Given estimation for men, possibly includes estimation for people in whole.}} Organizers and leaders of party's activities during this time were Comrade Artyom ([[Fyodor Sergeev]]), [[Vladimir Bonch-Bruyevich]], [[Miron Vladimirov]], [[Kliment Voroshilov]], [[Serafima Hopner|Serafima Gopner]], [[Sergey Ivanovich Gusev|Sergey Gusev]], [[Lidia Knipovich]], [[Gleb Krzhizhanovsky]], [[Grigory Petrovsky]], [[Mykola Skrypnyk|Nikolay Skripnik]], [[Alexander Schlichter]], [[Yemelyan Yaroslavsky]], and others. Guided by decisions of the 1912 [[Prague Conference]], those Bolsheviks carried out work to expand and strengthen ties with the masses, their international upbringing, preparing workers to new revolutionary battles, were exposing supporters of what was labeled as "[[liquidationism]]", "otzovizm" (recalling representatives from the State Duma), [[trotskyism]] and [[bourgeois nationalism]]. During the years of [[World War I]] (1914–18) the Bolsheviks of Ukraine propagated the Lenin's slogan of transforming the [[imperialist war]]Brian Becker.
