@@ -46,8 +46,8 @@
 
 Unlike any other Bolshevik organizations in Ukraine that adopted the [[Lenin]]'s [[April Theses]] without discussions, on 23 April 1917 the Kiev party cell approved resolution in which it called the April Theses "yet insufficiently substantiated and developed".<ref name=ehukul2007>Kulchytskyi, S. ''[http://resource.history.org.ua/cgi-bin/eiu/history.exe?Z21ID=&I21DBN=EIU&P21DBN=EIU&S21STN=1&S21REF=10&S21FMT=eiu_all&C21COM=S&S21CNR=20&S21P01=0&S21P02=0&S21P03=TRN=&S21COLORTERMS=0&S21STR=Kvitnevi_tezy_Lenina The Lenin's April Theses (КВІТНЕВІ ТЕЗИ В.ЛЕНІНА)]''. Encyclopedia of History of Ukraine. 2007</ref> On 28 April 1917 at the city's assembly Bolsheviks stated that those theses require further discussion and promised to publish them in their newspaper.<ref name=ehukul2007/> They never did.<ref name=ehukul2007/> At the 7th All-Russian conference of Bolsheviks where the theses were adopted practically unanimously, the Kiev Bolsheviks, led by [[Yurii Pyatakov]] and who had other thought, did not dare to oppose [[Vladimir Lenin]].<ref name=ehukul2007/>
 
-===Struggle for establishment of the Soviet regime in Ukraine===
-Following the "[[July Days]]" and the semi-legal [[6th Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]], Bolsheviks of Ukraine began to prepare the workers for an armed uprising "for the [[Soviet regime]]" ({{lang-uk|за владу Рад}}, {{lang-ru|за власть Советов}}).<ref name=useyk/> Big help was provided to them by the Central Committee of the RSDLP(b) that maintained connection with more than 50 of its party organizations in Ukraine.<ref name=useyk/> Active role in the preparation process of the masses to the "Socialist Revolution" ([[October Revolution]]) was conducted by [[Vasiliy Averin]], [[Yevgenia Bosch]], [[Kliment Voroshilov]], [[Yan Gamarnik]], [[Serafima Hopner|Serafima Gopner]], [[Volodymyr Zatonsky|Vladimir Zatonsky]], [[Andriy Ivanov|Andrei Ivanov]], [[Emanuel Kviring]], [[Yuriy Kotsiubynsky]], [[Dmitriy Lebed]], [[Grigory Petrovsky]], [[Vitaly Primakov]], [[Fyodor Sergeyev]], {{ill|Ivan Fyodorovich Smirnov|lt=Ivan Smirnov|ru|Смирнов, Иван Фёдорович|uk|Смирнов Іван Федорович}}, and others.<ref name=useyk/> During the summer of 1917 on territory of modern Ukraine were formed two regional (oblast) branches of the [[Russian Social Democratic Labour Party (Bolsheviks)|RSDLP(b)]] of '''[[Southwestern Krai]]''' and '''Donets-Krivoi Rog Basin''' and later in the fall the bureau of the RSDLP(b) military organizations of the '''[[Southwestern Front (Russian Empire)|Southwestern Front]]'''<ref name=useyk/> (due to ongoing [[World War I]]). According to [[Yevgenia Bosch]], the regional branch of the RSDLP(b) was supposed to consist of 7 guberniyas (Governorates): Kiev, Chernigov, Podolia, Volhynia, Poltava, Kherson, and Yekaterinoslav.{{efn|name=bosch|Bosch, Ye., page 22}} Also membership of the party in Ukraine grew significantly in 1917 from 7,000 in April to 50,000 in October.<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> Following the [[October Revolution|Bolshevik coup-d'état]] in [[Petrograd]], at the [[All-Russian Congress of Soviets#Second Congress|2nd All-Russian Congress of Soviets]] among its delegates, there were 65 Bolsheviks from Ukraine.<ref name=useyk/>
+===Struggle for establishment of the Soviet power in Ukraine===
+Following the "[[July Days]]" and the semi-legal [[6th Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]], Bolsheviks of Ukraine began to prepare the workers for an armed uprising "for Soviet power" ({{lang-uk|за владу Рад}}, {{lang-ru|за власть Советов}}).<ref name=useyk/> Big help was provided to them by the Central Committee of the RSDLP(b) that maintained connection with more than 50 of its party organizations in Ukraine.<ref name=useyk/> Active role in the preparation process of the masses to the "Socialist Revolution" ([[October Revolution]]) was conducted by [[Vasiliy Averin]], [[Yevgenia Bosch]], [[Kliment Voroshilov]], [[Yan Gamarnik]], [[Serafima Hopner|Serafima Gopner]], [[Volodymyr Zatonsky|Vladimir Zatonsky]], [[Andriy Ivanov|Andrei Ivanov]], [[Emanuel Kviring]], [[Yuriy Kotsiubynsky]], [[Dmitriy Lebed]], [[Grigory Petrovsky]], [[Vitaly Primakov]], [[Fyodor Sergeyev]], {{ill|Ivan Fyodorovich Smirnov|lt=Ivan Smirnov|ru|Смирнов, Иван Фёдорович|uk|Смирнов Іван Федорович}}, and others.<ref name=useyk/> During the summer of 1917 on territory of modern Ukraine were formed two regional (oblast) branches of the [[Russian Social Democratic Labour Party (Bolsheviks)|RSDLP(b)]] of '''[[Southwestern Krai]]''' and '''Donets-Krivoi Rog Basin''' and later in the fall the bureau of the RSDLP(b) military organizations of the '''[[Southwestern Front (Russian Empire)|Southwestern Front]]'''<ref name=useyk/> (due to ongoing [[World War I]]). According to [[Yevgenia Bosch]], the regional branch of the RSDLP(b) was supposed to consist of 7 guberniyas (Governorates): Kiev, Chernigov, Podolia, Volhynia, Poltava, Kherson, and Yekaterinoslav.{{efn|name=bosch|Bosch, Ye., page 22}} Also membership of the party in Ukraine grew significantly in 1917 from 7,000 in April to 50,000 in October.<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> Following the [[October Revolution|Bolshevik coup-d'état]] in [[Petrograd]], at the [[All-Russian Congress of Soviets#Second Congress|2nd All-Russian Congress of Soviets]] among its delegates, there were 65 Bolsheviks from Ukraine.<ref name=useyk/>
 
 {{Campaignbox Bolshevik Uprisings in Ukraine}}
 The very next day after the Petrograd's coup-d'état, on 8–13 November (26–31 October by old style), 1917 Bolsheviks in Kiev, who have been headquartered at the [[Mariyinsky Palace]], attempted to [[Kiev Bolshevik Uprising|secure power in Kiev]] with less success and, after the Bolshevik's victory over the Kiev Military District garrison, the authority in Kiev was secured by the [[Regional Committee in Protection of Revolution in Ukraine]] where important role played the [[Central Council of Ukraine]]. In a week the Central Council adopted its "Third [[Universal (act)|Universal]]" where it condemned the Bolshevik coup-d'état and declared Ukraine in federative union with the [[Russian Republic]] (instead of the [[Soviet Russia]]). In response to that on 26 November 1917 the Bolshevik [[Sovnarkom]] published its [[manifesto]] to the all population "[https://web.archive.org/web/20190422174556/http://istmat.info/node/27999 About struggle with counter-revolutionary insurgency of Kaledin, Kornilov, Dutov, and supported by the Central Rada (О борьбе с контрреволюционным восстанием Каледина, Корнилова, Дутова, поддерживаемым Центральной Радой)]".
comment: /* Struggle for establishment of the Soviet regime in Ukraine */ not 'regime', but 'power', see the slogan 'all power to the soviets'
llm_output:
Changed "regime" to "power" in the section title "Struggle for establishment of the Soviet regime in Ukraine" to "Struggle for establishment of the Soviet power in Ukraine".

Not Weaponised. The change appears to be a linguistic clarification rather than a shift in narrative that would weaponize cultural heritage.

Number of Ukrainian politicians from left faction of the [[Ukrainian Social Democratic Labour Party]] (also known as Left Ukrainian Social Democrats or unofficially as "Ukrainian Bolsheviks") joined the Bolsheviks in January 1918.<ref>Yefimenko, H. changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -31,7 +31,7 @@
 
 The CPU was organized on the basis of [[democratic centralism]],<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> a principle conceived by [[Vladimir Lenin]] that entails democratic and open discussion of policy issues within the party followed by the requirement of total unity in upholding the agreed policies. The CPU's highest body was the Party Congress, convened every held every five years. When the Congress was not in session, the Central Committee was the highest body, but because the Central Committee met twice a year, most duties and responsibilities were vested in the Politburo. The party leader held the office of [[First Secretary of the Communist Party of Ukraine|First Secretary]] who served as the head of government.
 
-Like all other CPSU republican branches, The CPU was committed, in accordance to the party statute,<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> adhered to [[Marxist–Leninist ideology]]<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> based on the writings of Vladimir Lenin and [[Karl Marx]], and formalized under [[Joseph Stalin]]. The party had pursued [[state socialism]],<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> under which all industries were [[nationalized]] and a [[command economy]] was introduced. Prior to the introduction of [[central planning]] was adopted in 1929, Lenin had introduced a [[mixed economy]], commonly referred to as the [[New Economic Policy]], in the 1920s, which allowed to introduce certain [[capitalist]] elements in the [[Soviet economy]].
+Like all other CPSU republican branches, The CPU was committed, in accordance to the party statute,<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> adhered to [[Marxist–Leninist ideology]]<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> based on the writings of Vladimir Lenin and [[Karl Marx]], and formalized under [[Joseph Stalin]]. The party had pursued [[state socialism]],<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> under which all industries were [[nationalized]] and a [[command economy]] was introduced. Prior to the [[Great Break (USSR)|adoption]] of [[central planning]] in 1929, Lenin had introduced a [[mixed economy]], commonly referred to as the [[New Economic Policy]], in the 1920s, which allowed to introduce certain [[capitalist]] elements in the [[Soviet economy]].
 
 ==Historical overview==
 {{see also|Ukrainian People's Republic of Soviets|All-Ukrainian Congress of Soviets}}

Not Weaponised. The change is a minor rephrasing for clarity and does not introduce any weaponised language or narratives related to cultural heritage.

@@ -47,10 +47,10 @@
 Unlike any other Bolshevik organizations in Ukraine that adopted the [[Lenin]]'s [[April Theses]] without discussions, on 23 April 1917 the Kiev party cell approved resolution in which it called the April Theses "yet insufficiently substantiated and developed".<ref name=ehukul2007>Kulchytskyi, S. ''[http://resource.history.org.ua/cgi-bin/eiu/history.exe?Z21ID=&I21DBN=EIU&P21DBN=EIU&S21STN=1&S21REF=10&S21FMT=eiu_all&C21COM=S&S21CNR=20&S21P01=0&S21P02=0&S21P03=TRN=&S21COLORTERMS=0&S21STR=Kvitnevi_tezy_Lenina The Lenin's April Theses (КВІТНЕВІ ТЕЗИ В.ЛЕНІНА)]''. Encyclopedia of History of Ukraine. 2007</ref> On 28 April 1917 at the city's assembly Bolsheviks stated that those theses require further discussion and promised to publish them in their newspaper.<ref name=ehukul2007/> They never did.<ref name=ehukul2007/> At the 7th All-Russian conference of Bolsheviks where the theses were adopted practically unanimously, the Kiev Bolsheviks, led by [[Yurii Pyatakov]] and who had other thought, did not dare to oppose [[Vladimir Lenin]].<ref name=ehukul2007/>
 
 ===Struggle for establishment of the Soviet power in Ukraine===
-Following the "[[July Days]]" and the semi-legal [[6th Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]], Bolsheviks of Ukraine began to prepare the workers for an armed uprising "for Soviet power" ({{lang-uk|за владу Рад}}, {{lang-ru|за власть Советов}}).<ref name=useyk/> Big help was provided to them by the Central Committee of the RSDLP(b) that maintained connection with more than 50 of its party organizations in Ukraine.<ref name=useyk/> Active role in the preparation process of the masses to the "Socialist Revolution" ([[October Revolution]]) was conducted by [[Vasiliy Averin]], [[Yevgenia Bosch]], [[Kliment Voroshilov]], [[Yan Gamarnik]], [[Serafima Hopner|Serafima Gopner]], [[Volodymyr Zatonsky|Vladimir Zatonsky]], [[Andriy Ivanov|Andrei Ivanov]], [[Emanuel Kviring]], [[Yuriy Kotsiubynsky]], [[Dmitriy Lebed]], [[Grigory Petrovsky]], [[Vitaly Primakov]], [[Fyodor Sergeyev]], {{ill|Ivan Fyodorovich Smirnov|lt=Ivan Smirnov|ru|Смирнов, Иван Фёдорович|uk|Смирнов Іван Федорович}}, and others.<ref name=useyk/> During the summer of 1917 on territory of modern Ukraine were formed two regional (oblast) branches of the [[Russian Social Democratic Labour Party (Bolsheviks)|RSDLP(b)]] of '''[[Southwestern Krai]]''' and '''Donets-Krivoi Rog Basin''' and later in the fall the bureau of the RSDLP(b) military organizations of the '''[[Southwestern Front (Russian Empire)|Southwestern Front]]'''<ref name=useyk/> (due to ongoing [[World War I]]). According to [[Yevgenia Bosch]], the regional branch of the RSDLP(b) was supposed to consist of 7 guberniyas (Governorates): Kiev, Chernigov, Podolia, Volhynia, Poltava, Kherson, and Yekaterinoslav.{{efn|name=bosch|Bosch, Ye., page 22}} Also membership of the party in Ukraine grew significantly in 1917 from 7,000 in April to 50,000 in October.<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> Following the [[October Revolution|Bolshevik coup-d'état]] in [[Petrograd]], at the [[All-Russian Congress of Soviets#Second Congress|2nd All-Russian Congress of Soviets]] among its delegates, there were 65 Bolsheviks from Ukraine.<ref name=useyk/>
+Following the "[[July Days]]" and the semi-legal [[6th Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]], Bolsheviks of Ukraine began to prepare the workers for an armed uprising "for Soviet power" ({{lang-uk|за владу Рад}}, {{lang-ru|за власть Советов}}).<ref name=useyk/> Big help was provided to them by the Central Committee of the RSDLP(b) that maintained connection with more than 50 of its party organizations in Ukraine.<ref name=useyk/> Active role in the preparation process of the masses to the "Socialist Revolution" ([[October Revolution]]) was conducted by [[Vasiliy Averin]], [[Yevgenia Bosch]], [[Kliment Voroshilov]], [[Yan Gamarnik]], [[Serafima Hopner|Serafima Gopner]], [[Volodymyr Zatonsky|Vladimir Zatonsky]], [[Andriy Ivanov|Andrei Ivanov]], [[Emanuel Kviring]], [[Yuriy Kotsiubynsky]], [[Dmitriy Lebed]], [[Grigory Petrovsky]], [[Vitaly Primakov]], [[Fyodor Sergeyev]], {{ill|Ivan Fyodorovich Smirnov|lt=Ivan Smirnov|ru|Смирнов, Иван Фёдорович|uk|Смирнов Іван Федорович}}, and others.<ref name=useyk/> During the summer of 1917 on territory of modern Ukraine were formed two regional (oblast) branches of the [[Russian Social Democratic Labour Party (Bolsheviks)|RSDLP(b)]] of '''[[Southwestern Krai]]''' and '''Donets-Krivoi Rog Basin''' and later in the fall the bureau of the RSDLP(b) military organizations of the '''[[Southwestern Front (Russian Empire)|Southwestern Front]]'''<ref name=useyk/> (due to ongoing [[World War I]]). According to [[Yevgenia Bosch]], the regional branch of the RSDLP(b) was supposed to consist of 7 guberniyas (Governorates): Kiev, Chernigov, Podolia, Volhynia, Poltava, Kherson, and Yekaterinoslav.{{efn|name=bosch|Bosch, Ye., page 22}} Also membership of the party in Ukraine grew significantly in 1917 from 7,000 in April to 50,000 in October.<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> Following the [[October Revolution]] in [[Petrograd]], at the [[All-Russian Congress of Soviets#Second Congress|2nd All-Russian Congress of Soviets]] among its delegates, there were 65 Bolsheviks from Ukraine.<ref name=useyk/>
 
 {{Campaignbox Bolshevik Uprisings in Ukraine}}
-The very next day after the Petrograd's coup-d'état, on 8–13 November (26–31 October by old style), 1917 Bolsheviks in Kiev, who have been headquartered at the [[Mariyinsky Palace]], attempted to [[Kiev Bolshevik Uprising|secure power in Kiev]] with less success and, after the Bolshevik's victory over the Kiev Military District garrison, the authority in Kiev was secured by the [[Regional Committee in Protection of Revolution in Ukraine]] where important role played the [[Central Council of Ukraine]]. In a week the Central Council adopted its "Third [[Universal (act)|Universal]]" where it condemned the Bolshevik coup-d'état and declared Ukraine in federative union with the [[Russian Republic]] (instead of the [[Soviet Russia]]). In response to that on 26 November 1917 the Bolshevik [[Sovnarkom]] published its [[manifesto]] to the all population "[https://web.archive.org/web/20190422174556/http://istmat.info/node/27999 About struggle with counter-revolutionary insurgency of Kaledin, Kornilov, Dutov, and supported by the Central Rada (О борьбе с контрреволюционным восстанием Каледина, Корнилова, Дутова, поддерживаемым Центральной Радой)]".
+The very next day after the October Revolution, on 8–13 November (26–31 October by old style), 1917 Bolsheviks in Kiev, who have been headquartered at the [[Mariyinsky Palace]], attempted to [[Kiev Bolshevik Uprising|secure power in Kiev]] with less success and, after the Bolshevik's victory over the Kiev Military District garrison, the authority in Kiev was secured by the [[Regional Committee in Protection of Revolution in Ukraine]] where important role played the [[Central Council of Ukraine]]. In a week the Central Council adopted its "Third [[Universal (act)|Universal]]" where it condemned the Bolshevik coup-d'état and declared Ukraine in federative union with the [[Russian Republic]] (instead of the [[Soviet Russia]]). In response to that on 26 November 1917 the Bolshevik [[Sovnarkom]] published its [[manifesto]] to the all population "[https://web.archive.org/web/20190422174556/http://istmat.info/node/27999 About struggle with counter-revolutionary insurgency of Kaledin, Kornilov, Dutov, and supported by the Central Rada (О борьбе с контрреволюционным восстанием Каледина, Корнилова, Дутова, поддерживаемым Центральной Радой)]".
 
 ===Communist Party of Ukraine===
 The Communist Party (Bolsheviks) of Ukraine was created in July 1918 in Moscow.

---

@@ -40,7 +40,7 @@
 The party traces its beginning to committees and party's cells of the [[Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] (RSDLP) that existed at the end of the 19th century in all bigger cities and industrial centers on Ukrainian territory which was part of the Russian Empire.<ref name=useyk>Yurchuk, V., Kuras, I. ''[http://leksika.com.ua/10441202/ure/komunistichna_partiya_ukrayini Communist Party of Ukraine (КОМУНІСТИЧНА ПАРТІЯ УКРАЇНИ)]''. [[Ukrainian Soviet Encyclopedia]].</ref><ref name=eoupyrih2007/> Under influence from the [[League of Struggle for the Emancipation of the Working Class]] in [[Saint Petersburg]], in 1897 such organization was also formed in [[Kiev]] and [[Yekaterinoslav]] which also were taking part in preparation and convocation of the [[1st Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] in 1898.<ref name=useyk/> With release of newspaper [[Iskra]] in December 1900 in Germany, on territory of Ukraine spread out a network of the Lenin's Iskra group and organizations.<ref name=useyk/> Among the most notable activists in Ukraine during that period were [[Ivan Babushkin]], [[Rosalia Zemlyachka]], [[Pyotr Krasikov]], [[Isaak Lalayants]], [[Friedrichs Lengniks]], [[Maxim Litvinov]], [[Grigory Petrovsky]], [[Mykola Skrypnyk]] (Nikolay Skripnik), [[Dmitry Ilyich Ulyanov|Dmitry Ulyanov]], [[Vasiliy Shelgunov]], [[Alexander Schlichter]], [[Alexander Tsiurupa]], and others.<ref name=useyk/> Following the [[2nd Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] (1903) in social-democratic organizations has developed a struggle between Mensheviks and Bolsheviks.<ref name=useyk/> On behalf of [[Vladimir Lenin]], in 1904 [[Vatslav Vorovsky]] with Lalayants and Levitskiy created in [[Odessa]] the Southern Bureau of the RSDLP that led activities of Odessa, Yekaterinoslav, Nikolayev committees, brought together around itself Bolshevik organizations of the South, conducted great deal of work in preparation to the [[3rd Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] in 1905.<ref name=useyk/>
 
 During the [[1905 Russian Revolution]] Bolsheviks in Ukraine guided by decisions of the 3rd Congress led working people to fight against autocracy.<ref name=useyk/> In more than 50 cities and settlements were created Soviets of working deputies.<ref name=useyk/> In December 1905 Bolsheviks led number of armed uprisings in Ukraine, among which were in [[Horlivka]], Alexandrovsk ([[Zaporizhia]]), [[Kharkiv]].<ref name=useyk/> Kiev, Mykolaiv and many other cities were covered with [[strike action]].<ref name=useyk/> In course of the revolution the RSDLP organizations in Ukraine grew significantly and in 1907 they were accounted for over 20,000 men.<ref name=useyk/>{{efn|name=estimation|Due to [[russification of Ukraine]], the [[Ukrainian Soviet Encyclopedia]] does not differentiate between two homonymic words in both languages (Russian and Ukrainian) that have different semantics. The Russian word for people "chelovek" ({{lang-ru|человек}}) looks as it was adopted in Ukrainian here as <u>[male]</u> men "cholovik" ({{lang-uk|чоловік}}). Given estimation for men, possibly includes estimation for people in whole.}} Organizers and leaders
-of party's activities during this time were Comrade Artyom ([[Fyodor Sergeev]]), [[Vladimir Bonch-Bruyevich]], [[Miron Vladimirov]], [[Kliment Voroshilov]], [[Serafima Hopner|Serafima Gopner]], [[Sergey Ivanovich Gusev|Sergey Gusev]], [[Lidia Knipovich]], [[Gleb Krzhizhanovsky]], [[Grigory Petrovsky]], [[Mykola Skrypnyk|Nikolay Skripnik]], [[Alexander Schlichter]], [[Yemelyan Yaroslavsky]], and others.<ref name=useyk/> During the following year of government reaction in 1907–10 Bolshevik organizations in Ukraine have suffered significant losses, yet continued their revolutionary activities.<ref name=useyk/> Guided by decisions of the 1912 [[Prague Conference]], those Bolsheviks carried out work to expand and strengthen ties with the masses, their international upbringing, preparing workers to new revolutionary battles, were exposing supporters of what was labeled as "[[liquidationism]]", "otzovizm" (recalling representatives from the State Duma), [[trotskyism]] and [[bourgeois nationalism]].<ref name=useyk/> During the years of [[World War I]] (1914–18) the Bolsheviks of Ukraine propagated the Lenin's slogan of transforming the [[imperialist war]]<ref>Brian Becker. ''[https://liberationschool.org/from-inter-imperialist-war-to-global-class-war-understanding-distinct-stages-of-imperialism/ From inter-imperialist war to global class war: Understanding distinct stages of imperialism]''. Liberation School. 20 July 2018</ref> into a [[civil war]] and fought against [[social chauvinism]] and [[revolutionary defeatism]].<ref name=useyk/>
+of party's activities during this time were Comrade Artyom ([[Fyodor Sergeev]]), [[Vladimir Bonch-Bruyevich]], [[Miron Vladimirov]], [[Kliment Voroshilov]], [[Serafima Hopner|Serafima Gopner]], [[Sergey Ivanovich Gusev|Sergey Gusev]], [[Lidia Knipovich]], [[Gleb Krzhizhanovsky]], [[Grigory Petrovsky]], [[Mykola Skrypnyk|Nikolay Skripnik]], [[Alexander Schlichter]], [[Yemelyan Yaroslavsky]], and others.<ref name=useyk/> During the following year of government reaction in 1907–10 Bolshevik organizations in Ukraine have suffered significant losses, yet continued their revolutionary activities.<ref name=useyk/> Guided by decisions of the 1912 [[Prague Conference]], those Bolsheviks carried out work to expand and strengthen ties with the masses, their international upbringing, preparing workers to new revolutionary battles, were exposing supporters of what was labeled as "[[liquidationism]]", "otzovizm" (recalling representatives from the State Duma), [[trotskyism]] and [[bourgeois nationalism]].<ref name=useyk/> During the years of [[World War I]] (1914–18) the Bolsheviks of Ukraine propagated the Lenin's slogan of transforming the [[imperialist war]]<ref>Brian Becker. ''[https://liberationschool.org/from-inter-imperialist-war-to-global-class-war-understanding-distinct-stages-of-imperialism/ From inter-imperialist war to global class war: Understanding distinct stages of imperialism]''. Liberation School. 20 July 2018</ref><ref>[https://livingmarxism.blog/category/first-imperialist-war/ First Imperialist War]. Living Marxism.</ref><ref>[https://kprf.ru/history/date/133465.html The First Imperialist. The critical review of the official version (Первая империалистическая. Критика официальной версии)]. KPRF.ru. 2 August 2018</ref><ref>Aleksandr Gorianin. ''[https://www.svoboda.org/a/24204573.html About actual characteristics of the World War I: imperialist or what other? (О действительном характере Первой Мировой войны: империалистическая или какая-то иная?)]''. [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]]. 19 February 1997</ref> into a [[civil war]] and fought against [[social chauvinism]] and [[revolutionary defeatism]].<ref name=useyk/>
 
 During the 1917 [[February Revolution]], known as the February bourgeois democratic revolution in communist jargon, the Bolshevik organizations guided by the Central Committee of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party claimed that they led the struggle of the working people against [[Russian autocracy]], and after overthrowing it launched a struggle for the masses against whom communists named as conciliators and bourgeois nationalists.<ref name=useyk/> The process of differentiation of the Bolsheviks and the Mensheviks in the joint organizations of the RSDLP intensified and as well as the process of creation of independent Bolshevik organizations that on July 1917 accounted for around 33,000 men.<ref name=useyk/>{{efn|name=estimation}}

+Following the "[[July Days]]" and the semi-legal [[6th Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]], Bolsheviks of Ukraine began to prepare the workers for an armed uprising "for the [[Soviet regime]]" ({{lang-uk|за владу Рад}}, {{lang-ru|за власть Советов}}).<ref name=useyk/> Big help was provided to them by the Central Committee of the RSDLP(b) that maintained connection with more than 50 of its party organizations in Ukraine.<ref name=useyk/> Active role in the preparation process of the masses to the "Socialist Revolution" ([[October Revolution]]) was conducted by [[Vasiliy Averin]], [[Yevgenia Bosch]], [[Kliment Voroshilov]], [[Yan Gamarnik]], [[Serafima Hopner|Serafima Gopner]], [[Volodymyr Zatonsky|Vladimir Zatonsky]], [[Andriy Ivanov|Andrei Ivanov]], [[Emanuel Kviring]], [[Yuriy Kotsiubynsky]], [[Dmitriy Lebed]], [[Grigory Petrovsky]], [[Vitaly Primakov]], [[Fyodor Sergeyev]], {{ill|Ivan Fyodorovich Smirnov|lt=Ivan Smirnov|ru|Смирнов, Иван Фёдорович|uk|Смирнов Іван Федорович}}, and others.<ref name=useyk/> During the summer of 1917 on territory of modern Ukraine were formed two regional (oblast) branches of the [[Russian Social Democratic Labour Party (Bolsheviks)|RSDLP(b)]] of '''[[Southwestern Krai]]''' and '''Donets-Krivoi Rog Basin''' and later in the fall the bureau of the RSDLP(b) military organizations of the '''[[Southwestern Front (Russian Empire)|Southwestern Front]]'''<ref name=useyk/> (due to ongoing [[World War I]]). According to [[Yevgenia Bosch]], the regional branch of the RSDLP(b) was supposed to consist of 7 guberniyas (Governorates): Kiev, Chernigov, Podolia, Volhynia, Poltava, Kherson, and Yekaterinoslav.{{efn|name=bosch|Bosch, Ye., page 22}} Also membership of the party in Ukraine grew significantly in 1917 from 7,000 in April to 50,000 in October.<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> Following the [[October Revolution|Bolshevik coup-d'état]] in [[Petrograd]], at the [[All-Russian Congress of Soviets#Second Congress|2nd All-Russian Congress of Soviets]] among its delegates, there were 65 Bolsheviks from Ukraine.<ref name=useyk/>
 
 {{Campaignbox Bolshevik Uprisings in Ukraine}}
 The very next day after the Petrograd's coup-d'état, on 8–13 November (26–31 October by old style), 1917 Bolsheviks headquartered at the [[Mariyinsky Palace]] attempted to [[Kiev Bolshevik Uprising|secure power in Kiev]] with less success and, after the Bolshevik's victory, the authority in Kiev was secured by the [[Regional Committee in Protection of Revolution in Ukraine]] where important role played the [[Central Council of Ukraine]]. In a week the Central Council adopted its "Third [[Universal (act)|Universal]]" where it condemned the Bolshevik coup-d'état and declared Ukraine in federative union with the [[Russian Republic]] (instead of the [[Soviet Russia]]). In response to that on 26 November 1917 the Bolshevik [[Sovnarkom]] published its [[manifesto]] to the all population "[https://web.archive.org/web/20190422174556/http://istmat.info/node/27999 About struggle with counter-revolutionary insurgency of Kaledin, Kornilov, Dutov, and supported by the Central Rada (О борьбе с контрреволюционным восстанием Каледина, Корнилова, Дутова, поддерживаемым Центральной Радой)]".

 The following list is composed of the secretary of the Central Committee of the party who were the leaders of the Party. The position also was changing names between being called the First Secretary or the General Secretary, depending on a political atmosphere in the Soviet Union. The position was not officially of the head of state, but certainly was very influential, especially within the republic. The longest serving secretary was Vladimir Shcherbitsky with some 17 years as the head of the Communist Party, the second best is split between Stanislav Kosior and Nikita Khrushchev, both of which have 11 years.{{fact|date=October 2020}}

@@ -104,8 +104,8 @@
 This took place in Moscow and decided to call for preparations for an armed uprising against the occupying [[Central Powers]] forces and [[Hetman]] [[Pavlo Skoropadskyi]]’s dictatorship.<ref>[http://encyclopedia2.thefreedictionary.com/Partisan+Movement+of+1918%E2%80%9322 ] accessed 24 January 2011</ref> There were only 15 members in the Central Committee and six candidates. It reversed the decision adopted that April by a preliminary council in Tahanroh to established an independent Ukrainian bolshevik party with a membership in the envisaged Third International apart from the Russian party.{{fact|date=October 2020}}
 
 ====Central Committee====
-Ivan Amosov, [[Andrei Bubnov]], Afanasiy Butsenko, Shulim Gruzman, [[Vladimir Zatonsky]], Lavrentiy Kartvelishvili (excl.), [[Emmanuil Kviring]], [[Stanislaw Kosior]], Isaak Kreisberg, Yuriy Lutovinov, Georgiy Pyatakov, Rafail Farbman (excl.), Pinkhus Rovner, Leonid Tarskiy (Sokolovsky), Isaak Shvarts.

 ===Second Congress, October 1918===

@@ -41,6 +41,8 @@
 
 During the [[1905 Russian Revolution]] Bolsheviks in Ukraine guided by decisions of the 3rd Congress led working people to fight against autocracy.<ref name=useyk/> In more than 50 cities and settlements were created Soviets of working deputies.<ref name=useyk/> In December 1905 Bolsheviks led number of armed uprisings in Ukraine, among which were in [[Horlivka]], Alexandrovsk ([[Zaporizhia]]), [[Kharkiv]].<ref name=useyk/> Kyiv, Mykolaiv and many other cities were covered with [[strike action]].<ref name=useyk/> In course of the revolution the RSDLP organizations in Ukraine grew significantly and in 1907 they were accounted for over 20,000 men.<ref name=useyk/>{{efn|name=estimation|Due to [[russification of Ukraine]], the [[Ukrainian Soviet Encyclopedia]] does not differentiate between two homonymic words in both languages (Russian and Ukrainian) that have different semantics. The Russian word for people "chelovek" ({{lang-ru|человек}}) looks as it was adopted in Ukrainian here as <u>[male]</u> men "cholovik" ({{lang-uk|чоловік}}). Given estimation for men, possibly includes estimation for people in whole.}} Organizers and leaders
 of party's activities during this time were Comrade Artyom ([[Fyodor Sergeev]]), [[Vladimir Bonch-Bruyevich]], [[Miron Vladimirov]], [[Kliment Voroshilov]], [[Serafima Hopner|Serafima Gopner]], [[Sergey Ivanovich Gusev|Sergey Gusev]], [[Lidia Knipovich]], [[Gleb Krzhizhanovsky]], [[Grigory Petrovsky]], [[Mykola Skrypnyk|Nikolay Skripnik]], [[Alexander Schlichter]], [[Yemelyan Yaroslavsky]], and others.<ref name=useyk/> During the following year of government reaction in 1907–10 Bolshevik organizations in Ukraine have suffered significant losses, yet continued their revolutionary activities.<ref name=useyk/> Guided by decisions of the 1912 [[Prague Conference]], those Bolsheviks carried out work to expand and strengthen ties with the masses, their international upbringing, preparing workers to new revolutionary battles, were exposing supporters of what was labeled as "[[liquidationism]]", "otzovizm" (recalling representatives from the State Duma), [[trotskyism]] and [[bourgeois nationalism]].<ref name=useyk/> During the years of [[World War I]] (1914–18) the Bolsheviks of Ukraine propagated the Lenin's slogan of transforming the [[imperialist war]]<ref>Brian Becker. ''[https://liberationschool.org/from-inter-imperialist-war-to-global-class-war-understanding-distinct-stages-of-imperialism/ From inter-imperialist war to global class war: Understanding distinct stages of imperialism]''. Liberation School. 20 July 2018</ref><ref>[https://livingmarxism.blog/category/first-imperialist-war/ First Imperialist War]. Living Marxism.</ref><ref>[https://kprf.ru/history/date/133465.html The First Imperialist. The critical review of the official version (Первая империалистическая. Критика официальной версии)]. KPRF.ru. 2 August 2018</ref><ref>Aleksandr Gorianin. ''[https://www.svoboda.org/a/24204573.html About actual characteristics of the World War I: imperialist or what other? (О действительном характере Первой Мировой войны: империалистическая или какая-то иная?)]''. [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]]. 19 February 1997</ref> into a [[civil war]] and fought against [[social chauvinism]] and [[revolutionary defeatism]].<ref name=useyk/>
+
+Bolshevik Baltin in the "Chronicle of the Revolution" ({{lang-ru|Летопись Революции}}) noted that during the [[World War I]] in December 1914 Kharkiv experienced the most eerie Russian chauvinism (see, [[Great Russian chauvinism]]) which knew no limits when Russian ultra-nationalist [[Black Hundreds]] were assisted by a local police.<ref name=baltin>Балтин, А. "Харьковская организация Р. С.-Д. Р. П. большевиков во время войны." // Летопись Революции. - 1923. No.5. С. 3-20</ref> Baltin also stated that at that time the [[Kharkiv Locomotive Factory]] (employing 6,000 workers) was considered a "citadel of revolutionary movement"<ref name=baltin/> yet due to pressure of the local police and the Russian nationalists the revolutionary life was completely suppressed.<ref name=baltin/> In January 1915 the Kharkiv [[Bolshevik]] organization was accounted of no more than 10 people.<ref name=baltin/> The Bolshevik organization in Kharkiv was revived after arrival of Aleksei Medvedev, Nikolay Lyakhin (Petrograd Bolsheviks) and Maksimov and Maria Skobeeva (Moscow Bolsheviks).<ref name=baltin/> Following the Russian defeat during [[Gorlice–Tarnów Offensive]] and start of the [[Great Retreat (Russian)|Great Retreat]], to Kharkiv from [[Riga]] was evacuated a plant of the Public Company of Electricity ({{lang-ru|Всеобщая Компания Электричества}}) with 4,000 workers.<ref name=baltin/>
 
 During the 1917 [[February Revolution]], known as the February bourgeois democratic revolution in communist jargon, the Bolshevik organizations guided by the Central Committee of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party claimed that they led the struggle of the working people against [[Russian autocracy]], and after overthrowing it launched a struggle for the masses against whom communists named as conciliators and bourgeois nationalists.<ref name=useyk/> The process of differentiation of the Bolsheviks and the Mensheviks in the joint organizations of the RSDLP intensified and as well as the process of creation of independent Bolshevik organizations that in July 1917 accounted for around 33,000 men.<ref name=useyk/>{{efn|name=estimation}}
llm_output:

Not Weaponised. The addition provides historical context regarding the Bolshevik perspective without employing weaponisation terms or narratives that could be seen as politically charged or divisive.

 ===Third Congress, March 1919===
 This congress took place in Kharkov. A new central committee with a majority of [[Left communism|Left Communists]] was elected. This prompted the [[8th Congress of the Russian Communist Party (Bolsheviks)|Eight Congress]] of the [[Russian Communist Party (Bolsheviks)|Russian Communist Party]] to pass the following motion: "It is necessary to have a unified communist party with a unified central committee ... All decisions of the RCP and its leading organs are absolutely binding for all parts of the party, independent of their national composition. The central committees of the Ukrainian, Lettish and Lithuanian communists are conferred the rights of regional committees of the party; they are to be unreservedly subordinate to the central committee of the RCP."<ref>[http://www.whatnextjournal.co.uk/pages/theory/Hollis.html The Self-Determination of Nations: The Theory and Practice (Ukraine and Georgia)] by Annette Franz and Dave Hollis accessed 24 January 2011</ref>
 
-===Fourth Congress, March 17–23, 1920===
+===Fourth Congress, 17–23 March 1920===
 The [[Borotbists]] were forced to dissolve themselves and their erstwhile members were permitted to join the CP(b)U.<ref>[http://www.marxists.org/archive/lenin/works/1920/feb/06b.htm Draft Resolution on the Ukrainian Borotbist Party (Notes)] accessed 24 January 2011</ref> Vasyl Ellan-Blakytny and Shumsky drawn from the Borotbist leadership were elected to the Committee and the Borotbist Central Committee passed a resolution dissolving the Borotbist party and its central committee. All members were instructed to apply for CP(B)U membership. Nearly 4,000 out of approximately 5,000 Borotbists  were admitted to the CP(B)U.<ref>[http://www.day.kiev.ua/258303/ A great experiment`; Towards the history of national communism in Ukraine] By James Mace, accessed 24 January 2011</ref>

With release of newspaper [[Iskra]] in December 1900 in Germany, on territory of Ukraine spread out a network of the Lenin's Iskra group and organizations. Among the most notable activists in Ukraine during that period were [[Ivan Babushkin]], [[Rosalia Zemlyachka]], [[Pyotr Krasikov]], [[Isaak Lalayants]], [[Friedrichs Lengniks]], [[Maxim Litvinov]], [[Grigory Petrovsky]], [[Mykola Skrypnyk]] (Nikolay Skripnik), [[Dmitry Ilyich Ulyanov|Dmitry Ulyanov]], [[Vasiliy Shelgunov]], [[Alexander Schlichter]], [[Alexander Tsiurupa]], and others. Following the [[2nd Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] (1903) in social-democratic organizations has developed a struggle between Mensheviks and Bolsheviks. On behalf of [[Vladimir Lenin]], in 1904 [[Vatslav Vorovsky]] with Lalayants and Levitskiy created in [[Odessa]] the Southern Bureau of the RSDLP that led activities of Odessa, Yekaterinoslav, Nikolayev committees, brought together around itself Bolshevik organizations of the South, conducted great deal of work in preparation to the [[3rd Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] in 1905. +The party traces its beginning to committees and party's cells of the [[Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] (RSDLP) that existed at the end of the 19th century in all bigger cities and industrial centers on Ukrainian territory which was part of the Russian Empire.Yurchuk, V., Kuras, I. ''[http://leksika.com.ua/10441202/ure/komunistichna_partiya_ukrayini Communist Party of Ukraine (КОМУНІСТИЧНА ПАРТІЯ УКРАЇНИ)]''. [[Ukrainian Soviet Encyclopedia]]. Under influence from the [[League of Struggle for the Emancipation of the Working Class]] in [[Saint Petersburg]], in 1897 such organization was also formed in [[Kyiv]] and [[Yekaterinoslav]] which also were taking part in preparation and convocation of the [[1st Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] in 1898. With release of newspaper [[Iskra]] in December 1900 in Germany, on territory of Ukraine spread out a network of the Lenin's Iskra group and organizations. Among the most notable activists in Ukraine during that period were [[Ivan Babushkin]], [[Rosalia Zemlyachka]], [[Pyotr Krasikov]], [[Isaak Lalayants]], [[Friedrichs Lengniks]], [[Maxim Litvinov]], [[Grigory Petrovsky]], [[Mykola Skrypnyk]] (Nikolay Skripnik), [[Dmitry Ilyich Ulyanov|Dmitry Ulyanov]], [[Vasiliy Shelgunov]], [[Alexander Schlichter]], [[Alexander Tsiurupa]], and others. Following the [[2nd Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] (1903) in social-democratic organizations has developed a struggle between Mensheviks and Bolsheviks. On behalf of [[Vladimir Lenin]], in 1904 [[Vatslav Vorovsky]] with Lalayants and Levitskiy created in [[Odessa]] the Southern Bureau of the RSDLP that led activities of Odessa, Yekaterinoslav, Nikolayev committees, brought together around itself Bolshevik organizations of the South, conducted great deal of work in preparation to the [[3rd Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] in 1905. -During the [[1905 Russian Revolution]] Bolsheviks in Ukraine guided by decisions of the 3rd Congress led working people to fight against autocracy. In more than 50 cities and settlements were created Soviets of working deputies. In December 1905 Bolsheviks led number of armed uprisings in Ukraine, among which were in [[Horlivka]], Alexandrovsk ([[Zaporizhia]]), [[Kharkiv]]. Kiev, Mykolaiv and many other cities were covered with [[strike action]]. In course of the revolution the RSDLP organizations in Ukraine grew significantly and in 1907 they were accounted for over 20,000 men.{{efn|name=estimation|Due to [[russification of Ukraine]], the [[Ukrainian Soviet Encyclopedia]] does not differentiate between two homonymic words in both languages (Russian and Ukrainian) that have different semantics. The Russian word for people "chelovek" ({{lang-ru|человек}}) looks as it was adopted in Ukrainian here as [male] men "cholovik" ({{lang-uk|чоловік}}). Given estimation for men, possibly includes estimation for people in whole.}} Organizers and leaders +During the [[1905 Russian Revolution]] Bolsheviks in Ukraine guided by decisions of the 3rd Congress led working people to fight against autocracy. In more than 50 cities and settlements were created Soviets of working deputies. In December 1905 Bolsheviks led number of armed uprisings in Ukraine, among which were in [[Horlivka]], Alexandrovsk ([[Zaporizhia]]), [[Kharkiv]]. Kyiv, Mykolaiv and many other cities were covered with [[strike action]]. In course of the revolution the RSDLP organizations in Ukraine grew significantly and in 1907 they were accounted for over 20,000 men.{{efn|name=estimation|Due to [[russification of Ukraine]], the [[Ukrainian Soviet Encyclopedia]] does not differentiate between two homonymic words in both languages (Russian and Ukrainian) that have different semantics. The Russian word for people "chelovek" ({{lang-ru|человек}}) looks as it was adopted in Ukrainian here as [male] men "cholovik" ({{lang-uk|чоловік}}). Given estimation for men, possibly includes estimation for people in whole.}} Organizers and leaders of party's activities during this time were Comrade Artyom ([[Fyodor Sergeev]]), [[Vladimir Bonch-Bruyevich]], [[Miron Vladimirov]], [[Kliment Voroshilov]], [[Serafima Hopner|Serafima Gopner]], [[Sergey Ivanovich Gusev|Sergey Gusev]], [[Lidia Knipovich]], [[Gleb Krzhizhanovsky]], [[Grigory Petrovsky]], [[Mykola Skrypnyk|Nikolay Skripnik]], [[Alexander Schlichter]], [[Yemelyan Yaroslavsky]], and others. During the following year of government reaction in 1907–10 Bolshevik organizations in Ukraine have suffered significant losses, yet continued their revolutionary activities. Guided by decisions of the 1912 [[Prague Conference]], those Bolsheviks carried out work to expand and strengthen ties with the masses, their international upbringing, preparing workers to new revolutionary battles, were exposing supporters of what was labeled as "[[liquidationism]]", "otzovizm" (recalling representatives from the State Duma), [[trotskyism]] and [[bourgeois nationalism]]. During the years of [[World War I]] (1914–18) the Bolsheviks of Ukraine propagated the Lenin's slogan of transforming the [[imperialist war]]Brian Becker. ''[https://liberationschool.org/from-inter-imperialist-war-to-global-class-war-understanding-distinct-stages-of-imperialism/ From inter-imperialist war to global class war: Understanding distinct stages of imperialism]''. Liberation School. 20 July 2018[https://livingmarxism.blog/category/first-imperialist-war/ First Imperialist War]. Living Marxism.[https://kprf.ru/history/date/133465.html The First Imperialist. The critical review of the official version (Первая империалистическая. Критика официальной версии)]. KPRF.ru. 2 August 2018Aleksandr Gorianin. ''[https://www.svoboda.org/a/24204573.html About actual characteristics of the World War I: imperialist or what other? (О действительном характере Первой Мировой войны: империалистическая или какая-то иная?)]''. [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]]. 19 February 1997 into a [[civil war]] and fought against [[social chauvinism]] and [[revolutionary defeatism]]. During the 1917 [[February Revolution]], known as the February bourgeois democratic revolution in communist jargon, the Bolshevik organizations guided by the Central Committee of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party claimed that they led the struggle of the working people against [[Russian autocracy]], and after overthrowing it launched a struggle for the masses against whom communists named as conciliators and bourgeois nationalists. The process of differentiation of the Bolsheviks and the Mensheviks in the joint organizations of the RSDLP intensified and as well as the process of creation of independent Bolshevik organizations that on July 1917 accounted for around 33,000 men.{{efn|name=estimation}} -According to [[Yevgenia Bosch]], the Kiev party organization after the February Revolution accounted for only near 200 members{{efn|name=bosch11|Bosch, Ye., page 11}} and it mainly was concentrated on elections to the Soviet of Workers' Deputies.{{efn|name=bosch11}} The performance of the party organization was far from stellar and huge advantage in the soviet (council) was secured by what Bosch called "petty bourgeois parties".{{efn|name=bosch11}} The majority in the soviet was formed by [[Mensheviks]].{{efn|name=bosch11}} The soviet's executive committee ([[ispolkom]]) was also dominated by Mensheviks and [[Bundists]], while Bolsheviks managed to have own representative Maks  ===Third Congress, March 1919===
 This congress took place in Kharkov. A new central committee with a majority of [[Left communism|Left Communists]] was elected. This prompted the [[8th Congress of the Russian Communist Party (Bolsheviks)|Eight Congress]] of the [[Russian Communist Party (Bolsheviks)|Russian Communist Party]] to pass the following motion: "It is necessary to have a unified communist party with a unified central committee ... All decisions of the RCP and its leading organs are absolutely binding for all parts of the party, independent of their national composition. The central committees of the Ukrainian, Lettish and Lithuanian communists are conferred the rights of regional committees of the party; they are to be unreservedly subordinate to the central committee of the RCP."<ref>[http://www.whatnextjournal.co.uk/pages/theory/Hollis.html The Self-Determination of Nations: The Theory and Practice (Ukraine and Georgia)] by Annette Franz and Dave Hollis accessed 24 January 2011</ref>

+During the 1917 [[February Revolution]], known as the February bourgeois democratic revolution in communist jargon, the Bolshevik organizations guided by the Central Committee of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party claimed that they led the struggle of the working people against [[Russian autocracy]], and after overthrowing it launched a struggle for the masses against whom communists named as conciliators and bourgeois nationalists.<ref name=useyk/> The process of differentiation of the Bolsheviks and the Mensheviks in the joint organizations of the RSDLP intensified and as well as the process of creation of independent Bolshevik organizations that in July 1917 accounted for around 33,000 men.<ref name=useyk/>{{efn|name=estimation}}
 
 According to [[Yevgenia Bosch]], the Kyiv party organization after the February Revolution accounted for only near 200 members{{efn|name=bosch11|Bosch, Ye., page 11}} and it mainly was concentrated on elections to the Soviet of Workers' Deputies.{{efn|name=bosch11}} The performance of the party organization was far from stellar and huge advantage in the soviet (council) was secured by what Bosch called "petty bourgeois parties".{{efn|name=bosch11}} The majority in the soviet was formed by [[Mensheviks]].{{efn|name=bosch11}} The soviet's executive committee ([[ispolkom]]) was also dominated by Mensheviks and [[Bundists]], while Bolsheviks managed to have own representative Maks Savelyev.{{efn|name=bosch11}} The Kyiv party organization chose not to participate in elections to the Soviet of Soldiers' Deputies due to lack of relations with local military.{{efn|name=bosch11}} Also the Kyiv Bolsheviks chose to ignore the [[All-Ukrainian National Congress]] that was convened on proposition of the [[Central Council of Ukraine]] on {{OldStyleDate|18 – 20 April|1917|5 – 7 April}}.{{efn|name=bosch12|Bosch, Ye., page 12}} The most important role for the organization was participation in the [[International Workers' Day|1 May]] street demonstration to the point that the Bolsheviks decided to conducted own one in spite that the event was already organized by the Soviet of Workers' Deputies.{{efn|name=bosch12}}

+The Communist Party (Bolsheviks) of Ukraine was created on July 5–12, 1918 in Moscow during the 1st Party Congress. ''[http://resource.history.org.ua/cgi-bin/eiu/history.exe?Z21ID=&I21DBN=EIU&P21DBN=EIU&S21STN=1&S21REF=10&S21FMT=eiu_all&C21COM=S&S21CNR=20&S21P01=0&S21P02=0&S21P03=TRN=&S21COLORTERMS=0&S21STR=Kom_partiya_Ukr_Radyanska_doba Communist Party of Ukraine, the Soviet period (КОМУНІСТИЧНА ПАРТІЯ УКРАЇНИ РАДЯНСЬКОЇ ДОБИ)]''. Encyclopedia of History of Ukraine. 2007</ref> The CPU was the sole governing party was founded in 1918 as the '''Communist Party (Bolsheviks) of Ukraine''' (CP(b)U) until 1952, when it became the ''Communist Party of Ukraine''. On 26 August 1991 the Presidium of the Verkhovna Rada (Ukrainian parliament) suspended and on 30 August 1991 prohibited the Communist Party of Ukraine based on the fact that "the leadership of the Communist Party of Ukraine in its actions supported the [[1991 Soviet coup d'état attempt|coup d'état]]" [in [[Moscow]]].<ref>Pyrih, R. ''[http://esu.com.ua/search_articles.php?id=4431 Communist Party of Ukraine of Soviet period (Комуністична партія України Радянської доби)]''. Encyclopedia of Modern Ukraine.</ref> Based on parliamentary faction of the Communist Party following its 1991 prohibition, there was created the [[Socialist Party of Ukraine]]. On efforts of some other communists who did not join the Socialist Party, in 1993 in [[Donetsk]] was re-established the [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] soon after the [[Union of Communist Parties – Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] in [[Moscow]]. Some members who joined Socialist Party, after re-establishing of the Communist Party, joined the new political entity among which the most notable was [[Adam Martyniuk]]. Following sanctions against the party in 1991, the party fell apart in similar way as its parent organization (the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]]) having members of such main deviations like Democratic Platform and Interregional Deputy group reorganized into separate political entities.
+The '''Communist Party of Ukraine'''  ({{lang-uk|Комуністична Партія України}} ''Komunistychna Partiya Ukrayiny'', КПУ, ''KPU''; {{lang-ru|Коммунистическая партия Украины}}), was the founding and ruling political party of the [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]] operated as a republican branch ([[union republics]]) of the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] (CPSU).<ref name=eoupyrih2007>Pyrih, R. ''[http://resource.history.org.ua/cgi-bin/eiu/history.exe?Z21ID=&I21DBN=EIU&P21DBN=EIU&S21STN=1&S21REF=10&S21FMT=eiu_all&C21COM=S&S21CNR=20&S21P01=0&S21P02=0&S21P03=TRN=&S21COLORTERMS=0&S21STR=Kom_partiya_Ukr_Radyanska_doba Communist Party of Ukraine, the Soviet period (КОМУНІСТИЧНА ПАРТІЯ УКРАЇНИ РАДЯНСЬКОЇ ДОБИ)]''. Encyclopedia of History of Ukraine. 2007</ref> Founded as the '''Communist Party (Bolsheviks) of Ukraine''' (CP(b)U) in 1918 in [[Moscow]], [[Russian SFSR]], it was the sole governing party in [[Ukraine]]. In 1952 it became the ''Communist Party of Ukraine''. 
 
-The CPU was organized on the basis of [[democratic centralism]],<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> a principle conceived by [[Vladimir Lenin]] that entails democratic and open discussion of policy issues within the party followed by the requirement of total unity in upholding the agreed policies. The CPU's highest body was the Party Congress, convened every held every five years. When the Congress was not in session, the Central Committee was the highest body, but because the Central Committee met twice a year, most duties and responsibilities were vested in the Politburo. The party leader held the office of [[First Secretary of the Communist Party of Ukraine|First Secretary]] who served as the head of government.
+According to the CPU statute it was organized on the basis of [[democratic centralism]],<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> a principle conceived by [[Vladimir Lenin]] that entails democratic and open discussion of policy issues within the party followed by the requirement of total unity in upholding the agreed policies. The CPU's highest body was the Party Congress, convened every held every five years. When the Congress was not in session, the Central Committee was the highest body, but because the Central Committee met twice a year, most duties and responsibilities were vested in the Politburo. The party leader held the office of [[First Secretary of the Communist Party of Ukraine|First Secretary]] who served as the head of government.
+
+On 26 August 1991 the Presidium of the Verkhovna Rada (Ukrainian parliament) suspended and on 30 August 1991 prohibited the Communist Party of Ukraine based on the fact that "the leadership of the Communist Party of Ukraine in its actions supported the [[1991 Soviet coup d'état attempt|coup d'état]]" [in [[Moscow]]].<ref>Pyrih, R. ''[http://esu.com.ua/search_articles.php?id=4431 Communist Party of Ukraine of Soviet period (Комуністична партія України Радянської доби)]''. Encyclopedia of Modern Ukraine.</ref> Based on parliamentary faction of the Communist Party following its 1991 prohibition, there was created the [[Socialist Party of Ukraine]]. On efforts of some other communist cells across Ukraine that did not join the Socialist Party, in 1993 in [[Donetsk]] was re-established the [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] as a political party of independent Ukraine, while joining the [[Union of Communist Parties – Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] out of [[Moscow]]. Some members who joined Socialist Party, after re-establishing of the Communist Party, joined the new political entity among which the most notable was [[Adam Martyniuk]]. 
+
+Following sanctions against the party in 1991, the party fell apart in similar way as its parent organization (the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]]) having members of such main deviations like Democratic Platform and Interregional Deputy group reorganized into separate political entities.
 
 Like all other CPSU republican branches, The CPU was committed, in accordance to the party statute,<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> adhered to [[Marxist–Leninist ideology]]<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> based on the writings of Vladimir Lenin and [[Karl Marx]], and formalized under [[Joseph Stalin]]. The party had pursued [[state socialism]],<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> under which all industries were [[nationalized]] and a [[command economy]] was introduced. Prior to the [[Great Break (USSR)|adoption]] of [[central planning]] in 1929, Lenin had introduced a [[mixed economy]], commonly referred to as the [[New Economic Policy]], in the 1920s, which allowed to introduce certain [[capitalist]] elements in the [[Soviet economy]].

@@ -127,6 +127,37 @@
 From 1919 to 1934 all meetings were conducted in [[Kharkiv]], capital of the [[Ukrainian SSR]].
 There were three major Committees and several Bureaus. Each committee had members and candidates to members each with certain degree of obligations. The members and candidates to the committees were elected at the Party Congress. The number of members varied from one gathering to the next usually in ascending sequence. During the [[Great Purge]] the numbers remarkably declined as well as one of the committees, Central Control Committee, was disbanded. The first members were elected in 1918, 15 members of the Central Committee, six candidates as well as three members and two candidates of the Revision Committee. In 1920 the Central Control Committee was formed and by 1934 the Party accounted for some 191 members and 45 candidates in all committees. In 1937 there were only 71 members and 40 candidates in two committees. By 1990 the number of members grew just over 300 members.{{citation needed|date=August 2019}}

@@ -59,7 +59,7 @@
 Following the "[[July Days]]" and the semi-legal [[6th Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]], Bolsheviks of Ukraine began to prepare the workers for an armed uprising "for Soviet power" ({{lang-uk|за владу Рад}}, {{lang-ru|за власть Советов}}).<ref name=useyk/> Big help was provided to them by the Central Committee of the RSDLP(b) that maintained connection with more than 50 of its party organizations in Ukraine.<ref name=useyk/> Active role in the preparation process of the masses to the "Socialist Revolution" ([[October Revolution]]) was conducted by [[Vasiliy Averin]], [[Yevgenia Bosch]], [[Kliment Voroshilov]], [[Yan Gamarnik]], [[Serafima Hopner|Serafima Gopner]], [[Volodymyr Zatonsky|Vladimir Zatonsky]], [[Andriy Ivanov|Andrei Ivanov]], [[Emanuel Kviring]], [[Yuriy Kotsiubynsky]], [[Dmitriy Lebed]], [[Grigory Petrovsky]], [[Vitaly Primakov]], [[Fyodor Sergeyev]], {{ill|Ivan Fyodorovich Smirnov|lt=Ivan Smirnov|ru|Смирнов, Иван Фёдорович|uk|Смирнов Іван Федорович}}, and others.<ref name=useyk/> During the summer of 1917 on territory of modern Ukraine were formed two regional (oblast) branches of the [[Russian Social Democratic Labour Party (Bolsheviks)|RSDLP(b)]] of '''[[Southwestern Krai]]''' and '''Donets-Krivoi Rog Basin''' and later in the fall the bureau of the RSDLP(b) military organizations of the '''[[Southwestern Front (Russian Empire)|Southwestern Front]]'''<ref name=useyk/> (due to ongoing [[World War I]]). According to [[Yevgenia Bosch]], the regional branch of the RSDLP(b) was supposed to consist of 7 guberniyas (Governorates): Kyiv, Chernihiv, Podolia, Volhynia, Poltava, Kherson, and Yekaterinoslav.{{efn|name=bosch|Bosch, Ye., page 22}} Also membership of the party in Ukraine grew significantly in 1917 from 7,000 in April to 50,000 in October.<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> Following the [[October Revolution]] in [[Petrograd]], at the [[All-Russian Congress of Soviets#Second Congress|2nd All-Russian Congress of Soviets]] among its delegates, there were 65 Bolsheviks from Ukraine.<ref name=useyk/>
 
 {{Campaignbox Bolshevik Uprisings in Ukraine}}
-The very next day after the October Revolution, on 8–13 November (26–31 October by old style), 1917 Bolsheviks in Kyiv, who have been headquartered at the [[Mariyinsky Palace]], attempted to [[Kyiv Bolshevik Uprising|secure power in Kyiv]] with less success and, after the Bolshevik's victory over the Kyiv Military District garrison, the authority in Kyiv was secured by the [[Regional Committee in Protection of Revolution in Ukraine]] where important role played the [[Central Council of Ukraine]]. In a week the Central Council adopted its "Third [[Universal (act)|Universal]]" where it condemned the Bolshevik coup-d'état and declared Ukraine in federative union with the [[Russian Republic]] (instead of the [[Soviet Russia]]). In response to that on 26 November 1917 the Bolshevik [[Sovnarkom]] published its [[manifesto]] to the all population "[https://web.archive.org/web/20190422174556/http://istmat.info/node/27999 About struggle with counter-revolutionary insurgency of Kaledin, Kornilov, Dutov, and supported by the Central Rada (О борьбе с контрреволюционным восстанием Каледина, Корнилова, Дутова, поддерживаемым Центральной Радой)]".
+The very next day after the October Revolution, on 8–13 November (26–31 October by old style), 1917 Bolsheviks in Kyiv, who have been headquartered at the [[Mariinskyi Palace]], attempted to [[Kyiv Bolshevik Uprising|secure power in Kyiv]] with less success and, after the Bolshevik's victory over the Kyiv Military District garrison, the authority in Kyiv was secured by the [[Regional Committee in Protection of Revolution in Ukraine]] where important role played the [[Central Council of Ukraine]]. In a week the Central Council adopted its "Third [[Universal (act)|Universal]]" where it condemned the Bolshevik coup-d'état and declared Ukraine in federative union with the [[Russian Republic]] (instead of the [[Soviet Russia]]). In response to that on 26 November 1917 the Bolshevik [[Sovnarkom]] published its [[manifesto]] to the all population "[https://web.archive.org/web/20190422174556/http://istmat.info/node/27999 About struggle with counter-revolutionary insurgency of Kaledin, Kornilov, Dutov, and supported by the Central Rada (О борьбе с контрреволюционным восстанием Каледина, Корнилова, Дутова, поддерживаемым Центральной Радой)]".
 
 ===Communist Party of Ukraine===
 The Communist Party (Bolsheviks) of Ukraine was created on 5–12 July 1918 in Moscow during the 1st Party Congress. During the congress there was established a central committee of 15 members and 6 candidates to membership:<ref>[http://www.knowbysight.info/1_UKRA/11750.asp Центральный Комитет, избранный I-м съездом КП(б) Украины 12.7.1918, члены].</ref> Ivan Amosov, Andrei Bubnov, Afanasi Butsenko, Shulim Gruzman, Vladimir Zatonski, Lavreti Kartvelishvili, Emmanuel Kviring, Stanisław Kosior, Isaak Kreisberg, Iuri Lutovinov, Georgi Piatakov, Rafail Farbman, Pinkhus Rovner, Leonid Tarski, Isaak Shvarts; Ian Gamarnik, Dmitri Lebed, Mikhail Maiorov, Nikolai Skrypnik, Petr Slynko, Iakov, Iakovlev.

On October 24, 1990, article 6 on the monopoly of the Communist Party of Ukraine on power was excluded from the Constitution of the Ukrainian SSR.<ref>[https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/404-12 Про зміни і доповнення Конституції (Основного Закону) Української РСР]</ref>
+On 13 October 1952 the party officially was renamed as the '''Communist Party of Ukraine'''.<ref>[http://www.knowbysight.info/1_UKRA/04996.asp Коммунистическая партия Украины]</ref> On October 24, 1990, article 6 on the monopoly of the Communist Party of Ukraine on power was excluded from the Constitution of the Ukrainian SSR.<ref>[https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/404-12 Про зміни і доповнення Конституції (Основного Закону) Української РСР]</ref>
 
 On 26 August 1991 the Communist Party was outlawed in Ukraine. Different sectors reconstituted themselves in different parties. One group led by moderate members under [[Oleksandr Moroz]] formed the [[Socialist Party of Ukraine]] (SPU) out of most of the former members, a group of agrarians led by [[Serhiy Dovhan]] and [[Oleksandr Tkachenko (politician)|Oleksandr Tkachenko]] formed the [[Peasant Party of Ukraine]] (SelPU), and another group, the [[Communist Party of Ukraine]], was re-created in 1993 in [[Donetsk]] under the leadership of [[Petro Symonenko]] when the ban was lifted. The remaining members either changed political direction or created their own left-wing parties such as the Vitrenko bloc, Social-Democratic (United) party, and others.
 {{History of Ukraine}}

--- 
+++ 
@@ -30,13 +30,13 @@
 {{History of Soviet government of Ukraine}}
 The '''Communist Party of Ukraine'''  ({{lang-uk|Комуністична Партія України}} ''Komunistychna Partiya Ukrayiny'', КПУ, ''KPU''; {{lang-ru|Коммунистическая партия Украины}}), was the founding and ruling political party of the [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]] operated as a republican branch ([[union republics]]) of the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] (CPSU).<ref name=eoupyrih2007>Pyrih, R. ''[http://resource.history.org.ua/cgi-bin/eiu/history.exe?Z21ID=&I21DBN=EIU&P21DBN=EIU&S21STN=1&S21REF=10&S21FMT=eiu_all&C21COM=S&S21CNR=20&S21P01=0&S21P02=0&S21P03=TRN=&S21COLORTERMS=0&S21STR=Kom_partiya_Ukr_Radyanska_doba Communist Party of Ukraine, the Soviet period (КОМУНІСТИЧНА ПАРТІЯ УКРАЇНИ РАДЯНСЬКОЇ ДОБИ)]''. Encyclopedia of History of Ukraine. 2007</ref> No decision of the [[government of Ukraine]] (Council of Ministers) was adopted without approval of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of Ukraine. The Communist Party of Ukraine is not one and the same party as the [[Ukrainian Communist Party]] or [[Ukrainian Communist Party (Borotbists)]]. 
 
-Founded as the '''Communist Party (Bolsheviks) of Ukraine''' (CP(b)U) in 1918 in [[Moscow]], [[Russian SFSR]], it was the sole governing party in [[Ukraine]]. While the [[Ukraine People's Republic]] had its own political parties of communist ideologies, the Communist Party of Ukraine was created out of the party of Russian Bolsheviks in Ukraine known as the RSDRP(b) – Social-Democracy of Ukraine. In 1952 it became the ''Communist Party of Ukraine''. According to the CPU statute it was organized on the basis of [[democratic centralism]],<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> a principle conceived by [[Vladimir Lenin]] that entails democratic and open discussion of policy issues within the party followed by the requirement of total unity in upholding the agreed policies. The CPU's highest body was the Party Congress, convened every held every five years. When the Congress was not in session, the Central Committee was the highest body, but because the Central Committee met twice a year, most duties and responsibilities were vested in the Politburo. The party leader held the office of [[First Secretary of the Communist Party of Ukraine|First Secretary]] who served as the head of government.
-
-On 26 August 1991 the Verkhovna Rada (Ukrainian parliament) suspended<ref>[https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/1435-12 УКАЗ ПРЕЗИДІЇ ВЕРХОВНОЇ РАДИ УКРАЇНИ «Про тимчасове припинення діяльності Компартії України»]</ref> and on 30 August 1991 prohibited the Communist Party of Ukraine based on the fact that "the leadership of the Communist Party of Ukraine in its actions supported the [[1991 Soviet coup d'état attempt|coup d'état]]" [in [[Moscow]]].<ref>Ukrainian Parliament Presidium Ukase. ''[https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/1468-12 About banning of activities of the Communist Party of Ukraine (Про заборону діяльності Компартії України)]''. ''[http://esu.com.ua/search_articles.php?id=4431 Communist Party of Ukraine of Soviet period (Комуністична партія України Радянської доби)]''. Encyclopedia of Modern Ukraine.</ref> Based on parliamentary faction of the Communist Party following its 1991 prohibition, there was created the [[Socialist Party of Ukraine]]. On efforts of some other communist cells across Ukraine that did not join the Socialist Party, in 1993 in [[Donetsk]] was re-established the [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] as a political party of independent Ukraine, while joining the [[Union of Communist Parties – Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] out of [[Moscow]]. Some members who joined Socialist Party, after re-establishing of the Communist Party, joined the new political entity among which the most notable was [[Adam Martyniuk]]. 
+Founded as the '''Communist Party (Bolsheviks) of Ukraine''' (CP(b)U) in 1918 in [[Moscow]], [[Russian SFSR]], it was the sole governing party in [[Ukraine]]. While the [[Ukraine People's Republic]] had its own political parties of communist ideologies, the Communist Party of Ukraine was created out of the party of Russian Bolsheviks in Ukraine known as the RSDRP(b) – Social-Democracy of Ukraine. In 1952 it became the ''Communist Party of Ukraine''. 
+
+According to the CPU statute it was organized on the basis of [[democratic centralism]],<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> a principle conceived by [[Vladimir Lenin]] that entails democratic and open discussion of policy issues within the party followed by the requirement of total unity in upholding the agreed policies. The CPU's highest body was the Party Congress, convened every held every five years. When the Congress was not in session, the Central Committee was the highest body, but because the Central Committee met twice a year, most duties and responsibilities were vested in the Politburo. The party leader held the office of [[First Secretary of the Communist Party of Ukraine|First Secretary]] who served as the head of government.
+
+Like all other CPSU republican branches, The CPU was committed, in accordance to the party statute,<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> adhered to [[Marxist–Leninist ideology]]<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> based on the writings of Vladimir Lenin and [[Karl Marx]], and formalized under [[Joseph Stalin]]. The party had pursued [[state socialism]],<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> under which all industries were [[nationalized]] and a [[command economy]] was introduced. Prior to the [[Great Break (USSR)|adoption]] of [[central planning]] in 1929, Lenin had introduced a [[mixed economy]], commonly referred to as the [[New Economic Policy]], in the 1920s, which allowed to introduce certain [[capitalist]] elements in the [[Soviet economy]]. This lasted until 26 August 1991 when the Verkhovna Rada (Ukrainian parliament) suspended<ref>[https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/1435-12 УКАЗ ПРЕЗИДІЇ ВЕРХОВНОЇ РАДИ УКРАЇНИ «Про тимчасове припинення діяльності Компартії України»]</ref> and on 30 August 1991 prohibited the Communist Party of Ukraine based on the fact that "the leadership of the Communist Party of Ukraine in its actions supported the [[1991 Soviet coup d'état attempt|coup d'état]]" [in [[Moscow]]].<ref>Ukrainian Parliament Presidium Ukase. ''[https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/1468-12 About banning of activities of the Communist Party of Ukraine (Про заборону діяльності Компартії України)]''. [[Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine]]. 30 August 1991</ref><ref>Pyrih, R. ''[http://esu.com.ua/search_articles.php?id=4431 Communist Party of Ukraine of Soviet period (Комуністична партія України Радянської доби)]''. Encyclopedia of Modern Ukraine.</ref> Based on parliamentary faction of the Communist Party following its 1991 prohibition, there was created the [[Socialist Party of Ukraine]]. On efforts of some other communist cells across Ukraine that did not join the Socialist Party, in 1993 in [[Donetsk]] was re-established the [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] as a political party of independent Ukraine, while joining the [[Union of Communist Parties – Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] out of [[Moscow]]. Some members who joined Socialist Party, after re-establishing of the Communist Party, joined the new political entity among which the most notable was [[Adam Martyniuk]]. 
 
 Following sanctions against the party in 1991, the party fell apart in similar way as its parent organization (the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]]) having members of such main deviations like Democratic Platform and Interregional Deputy group reorganized into separate political entities.
-
-Like all other CPSU republican branches, The CPU was committed, in accordance to the party statute,<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> adhered to [[Marxist–Leninist ideology]]<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> based on the writings of Vladimir Lenin and [[Karl Marx]], and formalized under [[Joseph Stalin]]. The party had pursued [[state socialism]],<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> under which all industries were [[nationalized]] and a [[command economy]] was introduced. Prior to the [[Great Break (USSR)|adoption]] of [[central planning]] in 1929, Lenin had introduced a [[mixed economy]], commonly referred to as the [[New Economic Policy]], in the 1920s, which allowed to introduce certain [[capitalist]] elements in the [[Soviet economy]].

On October 24, 1990, article 6 on the monopoly of the Communist Party of Ukraine on power was excluded from the Constitution of the Ukrainian SSR.<ref>[https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/404-12 Про зміни і доповнення Конституції (Основного Закону) Української РСР]</ref>
+
 On 26 August 1991 the Communist Party was outlawed in Ukraine. Different sectors reconstituted themselves in different parties. One group led by moderate members under [[Oleksandr Moroz]] formed the [[Socialist Party of Ukraine]] (SPU) out of most of the former members, a group of agrarians led by [[Serhiy Dovhan]] and [[Oleksandr Tkachenko (politician)|Oleksandr Tkachenko]] formed the [[Peasant Party of Ukraine]] (SelPU), and another group, the [[Communist Party of Ukraine]], was re-created in 1993 in [[Donetsk]] under the leadership of [[Petro Symonenko]] when the ban was lifted. The remaining members either changed political direction or created their own left-wing parties such as the Vitrenko bloc, Social-Democratic (United) party, and others.

 The very next day after the October Revolution, on 8–13 November (26–31 October by old style), 1917 Bolsheviks in Kyiv, who have been headquartered at the [[Mariinskyi Palace]], attempted to [[Kyiv Bolshevik Uprising|secure power in Kyiv]] with less success and, after the Bolshevik's victory over the Kyiv Military District garrison, the authority in Kyiv was secured by the [[Regional Committee in Protection of Revolution in Ukraine]] where important role played the [[Central Council of Ukraine]]. In a week the Central Council adopted its "Third [[Universal (act)|Universal]]" where it condemned the Bolshevik coup-d'état and declared Ukraine in federative union with the [[Russian Republic]] (instead of the [[Soviet Russia]]). In response to that on 26 November 1917 the Bolshevik [[Sovnarkom]] published its [[manifesto]] to the all population "[https://web.archive.org/web/20190422174556/http://istmat.info/node/27999 About struggle with counter-revolutionary insurgency of Kaledin, Kornilov, Dutov, and supported by the Central Rada (О борьбе с контрреволюционным восстанием Каледина, Корнилова, Дутова, поддерживаемым Центральной Радой)]".
 
 ===Communist Party of Ukraine===
-The Communist Party (Bolsheviks) of Ukraine was created on 5–12 July 1918 in Moscow during the 1st Party Congress. During the congress there was established a central committee of 15 members and 6 candidates to membership:<ref>[http://www.knowbysight.info/1_UKRA/11750.asp Центральный Комитет, избранный I-м съездом КП(б) Украины 12.7.1918, члены].</ref> Ivan Amosov, [[Andrei Bubnov]], Afanasi Butsenko, Shulim Gruzman, Vladimir Zatonski, Lavreti Kartvelishvili, [[Emanuel Kviring|Emmanuel Kviring]], [[Stanisław Kosior]], [[Isaak Kreisberg]], Iuri Lutovinov, Georgi Piatakov, [[Rafail Farbman]], [[Pinkhus Rovner]], Leonid Tarski, Isaak Shvarts; Ian Gamarnik, [[Dmitri Lebedev (military personnel)|Dmitri Lebed]], Mikhail Maiorov, Nikolai Skrypnik, Petr Slynko, Iakov, Iakovlev.
+{{also|Treaty of Brest-Litovsk}}
+The Communist Party (Bolsheviks) of Ukraine was created on 5–12 July 1918 in Moscow during the 1st Party Congress. Decisive factor of establishing autonomous branch were conditions of the [[Treaty of Brest-Litovsk]] according to which Ukraine was leaving the [[Russian Federation]]. During the congress there was established a central committee of 15 members and 6 candidates to membership:<ref>[http://www.knowbysight.info/1_UKRA/11750.asp Центральный Комитет, избранный I-м съездом КП(б) Украины 12.7.1918, члены].</ref> Ivan Amosov, [[Andrei Bubnov]], Afanasi Butsenko, Shulim Gruzman, Vladimir Zatonski, Lavreti Kartvelishvili, [[Emanuel Kviring|Emmanuel Kviring]], [[Stanisław Kosior]], [[Isaak Kreisberg]], Iuri Lutovinov, Georgi Piatakov, [[Rafail Farbman]], [[Pinkhus Rovner]], Leonid Tarski, Isaak Shvarts; Ian Gamarnik, [[Dmitri Lebedev (military personnel)|Dmitri Lebed]], Mikhail Maiorov, Nikolai Skrypnik, Petr Slynko, Iakov, Iakovlev.
 
 Most of its constituent members were former members of the Russian [[Bolshevik]]s who in 1917 pronounced themselves "[[Communist Party of the Soviet Union|RSDRP(b)]] – Social-Democracy of Ukraine"<ref>Yefimenko, H. ''[https://www.jnsm.com.ua/h/07051918T/ Creation of the Communist Party (Bolsheviks) of Ukraine (Створення Комуністичної партії (більшовиків) України)]''. V tsei den istorii. 5 July 2018</ref> and with the help of the [[Vladimir Antonov-Ovseyenko|Antonov-Ovseyenko]] [[Group of forces in battle with the counterrevolution in the South of Russia|expeditionary forces of Petrograd and Moscow Red Guards]] instigated a civil war in Ukraine by routing local Red Guards. Number of Ukrainian politicians from left faction of the [[Ukrainian Social Democratic Labour Party]] (also known as Left Ukrainian Social Democrats or unofficially as "Ukrainian Bolsheviks") joined the Bolsheviks in January 1918.<ref>Yefimenko, H. ''[http://www.dsnews.ua/nasha_revolyutsiya_1917/vpered-do-sovitskoyi-rosiyi-yak-ukrayinski-komunisti-nepravilniy-22102018200000 To the Soviet Russia. How the Ukrainian Communists "incorrect direction" were electing (До совітської Росії. Як комуністи України "неправильний напрям" обрали)]''. DS News. 22 October 2018</ref>

Added context about the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk and its impact on the establishment of the Communist Party of Ukraine.

Not Weaponised – The addition provides historical context regarding the political landscape during the formation of the Communist Party of Ukraine without employing weaponised language or narratives.

 During the 1917 [[February Revolution]], known as the February bourgeois democratic revolution in communist jargon, the Bolshevik organizations guided by the Central Committee of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party claimed that they led the struggle of the working people against [[Russian autocracy]], and after overthrowing it launched a struggle for the masses against whom communists named as conciliators and bourgeois nationalists.<ref name=useyk/> The process of differentiation of the Bolsheviks and the Mensheviks in the joint organizations of the RSDLP intensified and as well as the process of creation of independent Bolshevik organizations that in July 1917 accounted for around 33,000 men.<ref name=useyk/>{{efn|name=estimation}}
 
-According to [[Yevgenia Bosch]], the Kyiv party organization after the February Revolution accounted for only near 200 members{{efn|name=bosch11|Bosch, Ye., page 11}} and it mainly was concentrated on elections to the Soviet of Workers' Deputies.{{efn|name=bosch11}} The performance of the party organization was far from stellar and huge advantage in the soviet (council) was secured by what Bosch called "petty bourgeois parties".{{efn|name=bosch11}} The majority in the soviet was formed by [[Mensheviks]].{{efn|name=bosch11}} The soviet's executive committee ([[ispolkom]]) was also dominated by Mensheviks and [[Bundists]], while Bolsheviks managed to have own representative Maks Savelyev.{{efn|name=bosch11}} The Kyiv party organization chose not to participate in elections to the Soviet of Soldiers' Deputies due to lack of relations with local military.{{efn|name=bosch11}} Also the Kyiv Bolsheviks chose to ignore the [[All-Ukrainian National Congress]] that was convened on proposition of the [[Central Council of Ukraine]] on {{OldStyleDate|18 – 20 April|1917|5 – 7 April}}.{{efn|name=bosch12|Bosch, Ye., page 12}} The most important role for the organization was participation in the [[International Workers' Day|1 May]] street demonstration to the point that the Bolsheviks decided to conducted own one in spite that the event was already organized by the Soviet of Workers' Deputies.{{efn|name=bosch12}}
