@@ -53,7 +53,7 @@
 
 According to [[Yevgenia Bosch]], the Kyiv party organization after the [[February Revolution]] accounted for only near 200 members{{efn|name=bosch11|Bosch, Ye., page 11}} and it mainly was concentrated on elections to the Soviet of Workers' Deputies.{{efn|name=bosch11}} The performance of the party organization was far from stellar and huge advantage in the [[Soviet (council)|soviet]] (council) was secured by what Bosch called "[[Petite bourgeoisie|petty bourgeois]] parties".{{efn|name=bosch11}} The majority in the soviet was formed by [[Mensheviks]].{{efn|name=bosch11}} The soviet's executive committee ([[ispolkom]]) was also dominated by Mensheviks and [[Bundists]], while Bolsheviks managed to have own representative Maks Savelyev.{{efn|name=bosch11}} The Kyiv party organization chose not to participate in elections to the Soviet of Soldiers' Deputies due to lack of relations with local military.{{efn|name=bosch11}} Also the Kyiv Bolsheviks chose to ignore the [[All-Ukrainian National Congress]] that was convened on proposition of the [[Central Council of Ukraine]] on {{OldStyleDate|18 – 20 April|1917|5 – 7 April}}.{{efn|name=bosch12|Bosch, Ye., page 12}} The most important role for the organization was participation in the [[International Workers' Day|1 May]] street demonstration to the point that the Bolsheviks decided to conducted own one in spite that the event was already organized by the Soviet of Workers' Deputies.{{efn|name=bosch12}}
 
-Unlike any other Bolshevik organizations in Ukraine that adopted the [[Lenin]]'s [[April Theses]] without discussions, on 23 April 1917 the [[Kyiv]] party cell approved resolution in which it called the April Theses "yet insufficiently substantiated and developed".<ref name=ehukul2007>Kulchytskyi, S. ''[http://resource.history.org.ua/cgi-bin/eiu/history.exe?Z21ID=&I21DBN=EIU&P21DBN=EIU&S21STN=1&S21REF=10&S21FMT=eiu_all&C21COM=S&S21CNR=20&S21P01=0&S21P02=0&S21P03=TRN=&S21COLORTERMS=0&S21STR=Kvitnevi_tezy_Lenina The Lenin's April Theses (КВІТНЕВІ ТЕЗИ В.ЛЕНІНА)]''. Encyclopedia of History of Ukraine. 2007</ref> On 28 April 1917, at the city's assembly Bolsheviks stated that those theses require further discussion and promised to publish them in their newspaper.<ref name=ehukul2007/> They never did.<ref name=ehukul2007/> At the 7th All-Russian conference of Bolsheviks where the theses were adopted practically unanimously, the Kyiv Bolsheviks, led by [[Yurii Pyatakov]] and who had other thought, did not dare to oppose [[Vladimir Lenin]].<ref name=ehukul2007/>
+Unlike any other Bolshevik organizations in Ukraine that adopted the [[Lenin]]'s [[April Theses]] without discussions, on 23 April 1917, the [[Kyiv]] party cell approved resolution in which it called the April Theses "yet insufficiently substantiated and developed".<ref name=ehukul2007>Kulchytskyi, S. ''[http://resource.history.org.ua/cgi-bin/eiu/history.exe?Z21ID=&I21DBN=EIU&P21DBN=EIU&S21STN=1&S21REF=10&S21FMT=eiu_all&C21COM=S&S21CNR=20&S21P01=0&S21P02=0&S21P03=TRN=&S21COLORTERMS=0&S21STR=Kvitnevi_tezy_Lenina The Lenin's April Theses (КВІТНЕВІ ТЕЗИ В.ЛЕНІНА)]''. Encyclopedia of History of Ukraine. 2007</ref> On 28 April 1917, at the city's assembly Bolsheviks stated that those theses require further discussion and promised to publish them in their newspaper.<ref name=ehukul2007/> They never did.<ref name=ehukul2007/> At the 7th All-Russian conference of Bolsheviks where the theses were adopted practically unanimously, the Kyiv Bolsheviks, led by [[Yurii Pyatakov]] and who had other thought, did not dare to oppose [[Vladimir Lenin]].<ref name=ehukul2007/>
 
 ===Struggle for establishment of the Soviet power in Ukraine===
 Following the "[[July Days]]" and the semi-legal [[6th Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]], Bolsheviks of Ukraine began to prepare the workers for an armed uprising "for Soviet power" ({{langx|uk|за владу Рад}}, {{langx|ru|за власть Советов}}).<ref name=useyk/> Big help was provided to them by the Central Committee of the Petrograd-based RSDLP(b) that maintained connection with more than 50 of its party organizations in Ukraine.<ref name=useyk/> Active role in the preparation process of the masses to the "Socialist Revolution" ([[October Revolution]]) was conducted by [[Vasiliy Averin]], [[Yevgenia Bosch]], [[Kliment Voroshilov]], [[Yan Gamarnik]], [[Serafima Hopner|Serafima Gopner]], [[Volodymyr Zatonsky|Vladimir Zatonsky]], [[Andriy Ivanov|Andrei Ivanov]], [[Emanuel Kviring]], [[Yuriy Kotsiubynsky]], [[Dmitriy Lebed]], [[Grigory Petrovsky]], [[Vitaly Primakov]], [[Fyodor Sergeyev]], {{ill|Ivan Fyodorovich Smirnov|lt=Ivan Smirnov|ru|Смирнов, Иван Фёдорович|uk|Смирнов Іван Федорович}}, and others.<ref name=useyk/> During the summer of 1917 on territory of modern Ukraine were formed two regional (oblast) branches of the [[Russian Social Democratic Labour Party (Bolsheviks)|RSDLP(b)]] of '''[[Southwestern Krai]]''' and '''Donets-Krivoi Rog Basin''' and later in the fall the bureau of the RSDLP(b) military organizations of the '''[[Southwestern Front (Russian Empire)|Southwestern Front]]'''<ref name=useyk/> (due to ongoing [[World War I]]). According to [[Yevgenia Bosch]], the regional branch of the RSDLP(b) was supposed to consist of 7 guberniyas (Governorates): Kyiv, Chernihiv, Podolia, Volhynia, Poltava, Kherson, and Yekaterinoslav.{{efn|name=bosch|Bosch, Ye., page 22}} Also membership of the party in Ukraine grew significantly in 1917 from 7,000 in April to 50,000 in October.<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> Following the [[October Revolution]] in [[Petrograd]], at the [[All-Russian Congress of Soviets#Second Congress|2nd All-Russian Congress of Soviets]] among its delegates, there were 65 Bolsheviks from Ukraine.<ref name=useyk/>

On 25 September 1952, the committee was renamed into the Bureau of the Central Committee (CC) of CP(b)U, and in October the same year as the Bureau of the CC CPU. On 10 October 1952 it became the Presidium of the CC CPU. On 26 June 1966 again the bureau was finally left with its original name as the Politburo of the CC CPU.
 At first it consisted of five members and later another one was added. The first Politburo included [[Andriy Bubnov]], [[Emanuel Kviring]], [[Vladimir Mescheryakov]], [[Georgiy Pyatakov]], [[Christian Rakovsky]], and later [[Stanislav Kosior]], all centrists.
-From 23 March until 15 April 1920 there was elected a Provisional Bureau which the next day was ratified by the Russian Communist Party (Bolsheviks).
+From 23 March until 15 April 1920, there was elected a Provisional Bureau which the next day was ratified by the Russian Communist Party (Bolsheviks).
 
 ===Orgburo===
 Along with Politburo the party like its Russian counterpart had its own [[Orgburo]] that was created the same day as Politburo.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -37,7 +37,9 @@
 
 Founded as the '''Communist Party (Bolsheviks) of Ukraine''' (CP(b)U) in 1918 in [[Moscow]], [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|Russian SFSR]], it was the sole governing party in Ukraine during its time in Soviet Russia and the Soviet Union. While the anti-Bolshevik [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] had its own political parties of socialist ideologies, the Communist Party of Ukraine was created out of the party of Russian Bolsheviks in Ukraine known as the RSDRP(b) – Social-Democracy of Ukraine. The party was denied the right to have a separate party statute and was governed by the statute of the Russian Communist Party (Bolsheviks), All-Union Communist Party (Bolsheviks) and Communist Party of the Soviet Union. In 1952, the party was renamed as the ''Communist Party of Ukraine''.
 
-Like all other CPSU republican branches, the CPU was committed, in accordance to the CPSU party statute,<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> to adherence to [[Marxist–Leninist ideology]]<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> based on the writings of Vladimir Lenin and [[Karl Marx]], and formalized under [[Joseph Stalin]]. The party had pursued [[state socialism]],<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> under which all industries were [[nationalized]] and a [[command economy]] was introduced. Prior to the [[Great Break (USSR)|adoption]] of [[central planning]] in 1929, Lenin had introduced a [[mixed economy]], commonly referred to as the [[New Economic Policy]], in the 1920s, which allowed to introduce certain [[capitalist]] elements in the [[Economy of the Soviet Union|Soviet economy]] after the disastrous experience of [[war communism]]. This lasted until 26 August 1991, when the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukrainian parliament) suspended<ref>[https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/1435-12 УКАЗ ПРЕЗИДІЇ ВЕРХОВНОЇ РАДИ УКРАЇНИ «Про тимчасове припинення діяльності Компартії України»]</ref> and on 30 August 1991 prohibited the Communist Party of Ukraine based on the fact that "the leadership of the Communist Party of Ukraine in its actions supported the [[1991 Soviet coup d'état attempt|coup d'état]]" [in [[Moscow]]].<ref>Ukrainian Parliament Presidium Ukase. ''[https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/1468-12 About banning of activities of the Communist Party of Ukraine (Про заборону діяльності Компартії України)]''. [[Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine]]. 30 August 1991</ref><ref>Pyrih, R. ''[http://esu.com.ua/search_articles.php?id=4431 Communist Party of Ukraine of Soviet period (Комуністична партія України Радянської доби)]''. Encyclopedia of Modern Ukraine.</ref> From the parliamentary faction of the Communist Party, following its 1991 prohibition, the [[Socialist Party of Ukraine]] was created. Due to efforts of some other communist cells across Ukraine that did not join the Socialist Party, the [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] was re-established in 1993 in Russian-speaking [[Donetsk]] as a communist political party of independent Ukraine, while joining the [[Union of Communist Parties – Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] from [[Moscow]]. Some members who joined the Socialist Party, joined the new political entity after its re-establishment, among whom the most notable was [[Adam Martyniuk]]. Following sanctions against the party in 1991, the party fell apart in a similar way to its parent organization (the Communist Party of the Soviet Union), having members of such main deviations like Democratic Platform and Interregional Deputy group reorganized into separate political entities. The ban lasted until 2001 and in May 2002, the older party was merged into the 1993 CPU.<ref name="kommersant.ru">[https://www.kommersant.ru/doc/324054 Леонида Кучму исключили из партии]</ref><ref name="ria.ru">[https://ria.ru/20020527/155482.html Президент Украины Леонид Кучма, бывший президент Леонид Кравчук и экс-спикер парламента Иван Плющ исключены из рядов Компартии Украины]</ref> Following the 2014 [[Revolution of Dignity]], all communist parties on the territory of Ukraine were outlawed and banned, with the ideology criminalized.<ref>[https://www.kpu.ua/ru/page/statute The Communist Party of Ukraine statute (Статут Комуністичної партії України)] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220214183439/https://www.kpu.ua/ru/page/statute |date=14 February 2022 }}. Communist Party of Ukraine (www.kpu.ua)</ref>
+Like all other CPSU republican branches, the CPU was committed, in accordance to the CPSU party statute,<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> to adherence to [[Marxist–Leninist ideology]]<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> based on the writings of Vladimir Lenin and [[Karl Marx]], and formalized under [[Joseph Stalin]]. The party had pursued [[state socialism]],<ref name=eoupyrih2007/> under which all industries were [[nationalized]] and a [[command economy]] was introduced. Prior to the [[Great Break (USSR)|adoption]] of [[central planning]] in 1929, Lenin had introduced a [[mixed economy]], commonly referred to as the [[New Economic Policy]], in the 1920s, which allowed to introduce certain [[capitalist]] elements in the [[Economy of the Soviet Union|Soviet economy]] after the disastrous experience of [[war communism]]. This lasted until 26 August 1991, when the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukrainian parliament) suspended<ref>[https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/1435-12 УКАЗ ПРЕЗИДІЇ ВЕРХОВНОЇ РАДИ УКРАЇНИ «Про тимчасове припинення діяльності Компартії України»]</ref> and on 30 August 1991 prohibited the Communist Party of Ukraine based on the fact that "the leadership of the Communist Party of Ukraine in its actions supported the [[1991 Soviet coup d'état attempt|coup d'état]]" [in [[Moscow]]].<ref>Ukrainian Parliament Presidium Ukase. ''[https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/1468-12 About banning of activities of the Communist Party of Ukraine (Про заборону діяльності Компартії України)]''. [[Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine]]. 30 August 1991</ref><ref>Pyrih, R. ''[http://esu.com.ua/search_articles.php?id=4431 Communist Party of Ukraine of Soviet period (Комуністична партія України Радянської доби)]''. Encyclopedia of Modern Ukraine.</ref> From the parliamentary faction of the Communist Party, following its 1991 prohibition, the [[Socialist Party of Ukraine]] was created. 
+
+Due to efforts of some other communist cells across Ukraine that did not join the Socialist Party, the [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] was re-established in 1993 in Russian-speaking [[Donetsk]] as a communist political party of independent Ukraine, while joining the [[Union of Communist Parties – Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] from [[Moscow]]. Some members who joined the Socialist Party, joined the new political entity after its re-establishment, among whom the most notable was [[Adam Martyniuk]]. Following sanctions against the party in 1991, the party fell apart in a similar way to its parent organization (the Communist Party of the Soviet Union), having members of such main deviations like Democratic Platform and Interregional Deputy group reorganized into separate political entities. The ban lasted until 2001 and in May 2002, the older party was merged into the 1993 CPU.<ref name="kommersant.ru">[https://www.kommersant.ru/doc/324054 Леонида Кучму исключили из партии]</ref><ref name="ria.ru">[https://ria.ru/20020527/155482.html Президент Украины Леонид Кучма, бывший президент Леонид Кравчук и экс-спикер парламента Иван Плющ исключены из рядов Компартии Украины]</ref> Following the 2014 [[Revolution of Dignity]], all communist parties on the territory of Ukraine were outlawed and banned, with the ideology criminalized.<ref>[https://www.kpu.ua/ru/page/statute The Communist Party of Ukraine statute (Статут Комуністичної партії України)] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220214183439/https://www.kpu.ua/ru/page/statute |date=14 February 2022 }}. Communist Party of Ukraine (www.kpu.ua)</ref>

The change made in this revision is the addition of a paragraph detailing the re-establishment of the Communist Party of Ukraine in 1993 in Russian-speaking Donetsk, along with its affiliation with the Union of Communist Parties and the context of its formation after the 1991 prohibition.

**Weaponised**: The addition emphasizes the Russian-speaking context of the re-established party, which could be interpreted as an attempt to frame the narrative around the legitimacy and cultural identity of Russian speakers in Ukraine.
